--------------------

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
attention to detail, good memory, ability to pick up knowledge quickly

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing the qualities you bring. What is your current role, and what kind of work do you do day to day?

[USER]
test sofware, fixes and new functionality

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you tested a new featureâ€”what you did from start to finish?

[USER]
i read the details, decided on test scenarios, test it and wrote up detials on what i did and if it passed test or failed

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
honest and hard worker

[ASSISTANT]
When you think of a good job, what makes it good for the person doing it?

[USER]
doing the job well

[ASSISTANT]
What needs to be in place for someone to be able to do the job well?

[USER]
have the tools, resources and skills

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
at the moment it doesnt impact it that much. i can use it to help write sql statements for me quickly

[ASSISTANT]
In that example with the SQL, what parts did it do and what parts did you handle yourself?

[USER]
i gave it details of tables and asked it to write the sql so i can get the info i need

[ASSISTANT]
Did it make any mistakes or give you something you had to tweak, and if so, how did you handle that?

[USER]
it didnt quite work so i gave it the error message and it worked after that

[ASSISTANT]
When it didnâ€™t work the first time and then worked after you sent the error, what went through your mind at each of those moments?

[USER]
nothing, probablt still quicker than me

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to writing the SQL yourself before, how does doing it with AI change the way you work through the task?

[USER]
makes it quicker as im not that great at sql

[ASSISTANT]
What do you tend to do with the time you save when it generates the SQL faster?

[USER]
get more work done

[ASSISTANT]
Besides SQL, are there other parts of your testing or development work where you use it? If so, whatâ€™s a recent example?

[USER]
i give it a least of the issues that have been raised and when i need to search for one i get it to look at the list and try and find anything related

[ASSISTANT]
Walk me through the last time you used it to search the issuesâ€”what did you feed in, what did it give you back, and what did you do with the result?

[USER]
i gave it excel export of the issues list, then said look for anything related to email contacts and it gave me a list of relevant issues

[ASSISTANT]
How did you check whether that list it returned matched what you would have found yourself?

[USER]
cos i could remember them but didnt know the issue number

[ASSISTANT]
What was your gut response when you saw the list it produced from the issuesâ€”did it feel spot on, surprising, or something else?

[USER]
felt correct

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
its not affected it

[ASSISTANT]
Even if it hasnâ€™t changed dynamics, have you noticed coworkers or managers talking about using it, or asking you to use it in any way?

[USER]
we all use it, no one cares

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future, is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if it could do it perfectly?

[USER]
the testing as i dont want to lose my job

[ASSISTANT]
Why is doing the testing yourself important for you to keep?

[USER]
otherwise i would lose my job

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over the testing, how do you think it would change your role on the team or how you work with others?

[USER]
i wouldnt have a job

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
nothing really i enjoy it all

[ASSISTANT]
What makes you want to keep doing all parts yourself rather than hand any of them to an AI?

[USER]
i enjoy it

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
being able to choose what you do and when you do it

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
i have a list of fixes and new functionality, i can choose what i start on and in what order

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
if there is something that a client is waiting for, it means i have to prioritise testing that first

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
no

[ASSISTANT]

Interview 6
Username: 60e5cb4ca01a593fce9a379d
Date: 12/12/2025 21:04:24
Duration: 0.00 minutes
--------------------

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
All our teammates has less work now.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. Can you tell me about your role and what your team is responsible for day to day?

[USER]
My role is a ETL developer. I am responsible to develop the ETL solutions required by the application.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Meeting with business analysts and get the data mapping documents and design the data flows and pipelines using ETL tools.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about a job you consider good, what makes it good for you personally?

[USER]
If i developed an good application then i will considered it as good job

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a good application, what tells you itâ€™s good in your eyes?

[USER]
Good means no bugs

[ASSISTANT]
Besides having no bugs, what else matters to you when you judge a job as good?

[USER]
Accuracy of the results

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI impacts me to write optimised code

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used AI to optimize an ETL job, step by step? What did you ask it for, and what did you do with the output?

[USER]
AI helped me with optimized code to get accurate results

[ASSISTANT]
What was the specific task or query you were optimizing, and what change did AI suggest?

[USER]
Time for the study is completing. Can you give me the code

[ASSISTANT]
I hear you are short on time. What SQL or transformation were you working on when you asked for help, and what did it propose to change?

[USER]
I have to write a SQL code which has multiple joins in it. AI helped me to write a optimized SQL

[ASSISTANT]
In that SQL with multiple joins, what did the AI actually produce, and what did you add or change before you ran it?

[USER]
AI broken down the SQL and gave me correlated sub query to write optimized code.

[ASSISTANT]
What went through your mind when you saw the suggestion to switch to correlated subqueries?

[USER]
I felt surprised.

[ASSISTANT]
How did the correlated subquery version perform compared to your original joins when you ran it?

[USER]
Original joins took lot of lines in the code but correlated sub query helped me to write less lines

[ASSISTANT]
When you tested that version, how did the execution time and resource usage compare to the original joins?

[USER]
Give me the code. Time is running out.

[ASSISTANT]
I canâ€™t provide code in this interview, but Iâ€™d like to understand your experience. When you ran both versions on the same dataset, what did you notice in the runtime or in the query plan?

[USER]
correlated sub query took very less time to process.

[ASSISTANT]
How did you check that the correlated subquery version was giving the right results before you put it into production?

Interview 7
Username: 636675b4dd6bb79382d46c2b
Date: 12/12/2025 21:03:04
Duration: 21.45 minutes
--------------------

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
Inventory Manager

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Good pay and benefits

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond pay and benefits, what else matters most to you in a job?

[USER]
Being able to progress in your role and develop

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about the day to day, what makes a job feel worthwhile when you head home?

[USER]
Feeling like I'd ticked off my tasks and being ahead on the workload

[ASSISTANT]
When you say develop, what does that look like in practice for you?

[USER]
Learning new skills, things that will be able to progress your experience and career

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
At the moment it doesn't really impact my work

[ASSISTANT]
Could you walk me through a recent day at work and tell me which tools or systems you rely on as you go?

[USER]
I use SAP and Excel every day in my role

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about one specific task you handle in SAP or Excel, and talk me through how you complete it from start to finish?

[USER]
I need to compile weekly Shrinkage Report. I use AFO which pulls data from SAP into excel, format it and reduce the data to minimise the file size and refresh a dashboard to update the report

[ASSISTANT]
In that shrinkage report example, which steps does the system handle for you and which parts do you do by hand?

[USER]
I need to retrieve the weekly data through the AFO refresh, this means manually updating the reporting dates. Once the data is refreshed, I copy it into the spreadsheet. I built the dashboard with slicers, so once the new data is in then all I have to do is refresh all

[ASSISTANT]
When you run that process, do errors ever crop up, like mismatched dates or odd figures, and how do you catch and fix them?

[USER]
sometimes I accidentally copy the data into the wrong cell so I have to backtrack to avoid breaking the report

[ASSISTANT]
When that happens, what goes through your mind, and how do you react in the moment?

[USER]
I get a bit annoyed because it's a simple mistake to avoid

[ASSISTANT]
When this process goes smoothly and youâ€™re done quicker, what do you usually do with the time youâ€™ve freed up?

[USER]
It's hard to quantify that, I would just start working on another task

[ASSISTANT]
How does doing the shrinkage report now compare to a few years ago, if you think backâ€”has anything about the workflow or tools changed in ways that mattered to you?

[USER]
Before I used to pull shrinkage numbers on an ad hoc basis, so it wasn't formalised. By building the dashboard it allows it to be standardised, and I spent a lot of time doing these reports from scratch

[ASSISTANT]
When you shifted from ad hoc pulls to the dashboard, what stands out to you about how that change felt in your day to day work?

[USER]
It felt like I was in more control and added more value

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I don't think it has

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Team Management

[ASSISTANT]
What makes team management the thing you want to keep in your own hands?

[USER]
Because I want it to have a personal and human element, I think it's important

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI started handling parts of team management, how do you think that would change your relationships with your team or your role day to day?

[USER]
I think it would create a rift between team members

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a time when the human element in managing your team really mattered?

[USER]
When a team member has performance or personal issues outside of work. It's important to recognise that and come to a solution

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Task tracking and meeting summaries

[ASSISTANT]
Why would you like to give up task tracking and meeting summaries?

[USER]
Because it's tiring and hard to keep track of

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled task tracking and meeting summaries, would it change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
I don't think they would be aware of any changes

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
Try and keep up to date with the latest developments in technology

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example of what keeping up to date with technology looks like in practice in your role?

[USER]
Understanding new systems and tools and how they can be used

[ASSISTANT]
I can see two ways someone might understand what you said. Do you mean keeping up with tech so you can choose how you do the work rather than follow a fixed process, or do you mean it helps you shape what work gets done in the first place, or is it something else altogether?

[USER]
I mean how to can stay competitive in your role or industry. For both positive and negative impacts

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work now or could in the near future?

[USER]
No I think that covers everything

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you very much for your answers! Looking back at this interview, how well does it summarize how experience of AI is changing and might change your work: 1 (it describes poorly how AI might change my work), 2 (it partially describes how AI might change my work), 3 (it describes well how AI might change my work), 4 (it describes very well how AI might change my work). Please only reply with the associated number.

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

Interview 8
Username: 5ec62902bb44c16b842128f9
Date: 12/12/2025 21:01:17
Duration: 15.94 minutes
--------------------

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I'm a manager at a small technology service provider.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
I would say great benefits, good pay, and a positive atmosphere. The work environment is crucial.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a positive atmosphere and that the work environment is crucial, what does that look like day to day for you?

[USER]
Positive conversations, good energy, a vibe you can feel, and promoting the objectives of the organization.

[ASSISTANT]
Which of those stands out as most important to you right now?

[USER]
Good energy!

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
It makes me feel like my days are counted, as well as helps me when I'm using it for tasks.

[ASSISTANT]
Could you tell me about a recent time you used it for a taskâ€”what was the task, and how did you use it?

[USER]
I had to generate some ideas for marketing and I used chatgpt to help me conjure some unique ideas. I also used it to create categories and group some factors in a list so I could better deal with them.

[ASSISTANT]
In that marketing ideas task, what parts did it do, and what parts did you handle yourself?

[USER]
It provided to me the message to convey to the consumer and I provided the key elements to include in the message.

[ASSISTANT]
Did you end up revising the message it proposed, and if so, how did you go about making those changes?

[USER]
No, I was able to use the message it provided without revisiting or modifying it because of how concise it was.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned it makes you feel like your days are countedâ€”what went through your mind the first time that feeling hit you?

[USER]
The first time that feeling hit me was when I realized that AI could do parts of my job without me.

[ASSISTANT]
When that realization landed, what was your gut response, and what did you do right after?

[USER]
I had anxiety and was nauseous like I wanted to throw up. I went to get a cup of water and walk around.

[ASSISTANT]
In the list-grouping task you mentioned, how did it sort things for you, and what did you check or change before using the categories?

[USER]
It created groups so I could prioritize things based on difficulty and time. I checked what was in the groups after it sorted them.

[ASSISTANT]
When you checked those groups, did anything seem off to you, and how did you handle it?

[USER]
Nothing seemed off and I was content

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to doing those tasks without AI, what changed in your workflow that day?

[USER]
That would of consumed hours of my day but it only consumed minutes, nothing else changed that day.

[ASSISTANT]
What stands out to you about finishing those tasks in minutes instead of hours?

[USER]
The power behind AI and it's potential

[ASSISTANT]
When you use it now, how does it affect your confidence in the final output?

[USER]
It makes me feel like a less than

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
It's made me view people as not living up to their true potential, including myself.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent interaction where that thought came up, and what happened?

[USER]
Talking to a technician about why he didn't follow inventory protocol and procedures. It instantly came up in my mind.

[ASSISTANT]
In that conversation with the technician, what did you say, and how did he respond?

[USER]
I asked him why he didn't follow the procedure, he said it was a mistake and I asked if it was the first time hes made that mistake.

[ASSISTANT]
When that thought came up in the moment, how did it shape the rest of that conversation with him?

[USER]
It was not positive but it was well needed.

[ASSISTANT]
Since that conversation, have you changed anything about how you coach your team or set expectations?

[USER]
No.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
No.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes you say thereâ€™s nothing youâ€™d want to keepâ€”whatâ€™s behind that view for you?

[USER]
I'd rather delegate the tasks and save my time.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over those tasks, how would that change your relationships with your teammates or your role on the team?

[USER]
I'd have less stress overall.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Inventory

[ASSISTANT]
What makes inventory the thing youâ€™d hand overâ€”what about it makes you want to delegate it to AI?

[USER]
It's a waste of time in the grand scheme of things, but it's necessary to be done

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled inventory, would that change how others see your contribution to the team, or would it mostly change your day-to-day stress?

[USER]
Stress levels would lower and I would be more happy in the office.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
To be able to do the things you want, how you want, and when you want.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example from your own job of doing things you want, how you want, and when you want? What did that look like on a real day?

[USER]
It starts with me choosing what tasks to do and follows by me taking breaks when I want. I have the leisure to take a lunch at the time I want and depending on how I feel when I get back is how I will approach the pending tasks.

[ASSISTANT]
Since you started using AI, has anything shifted in how you decide what to tackle first or when to pause? What changed, if anything?

[USER]
No, I still follow the same procedures.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t talked about and you want to add?

[USER]
Not really, I just take things at face value and don't try to overthink or overdo them.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for your time and insights. Just to confirm, thereâ€™s nothing else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work?

Thank you very much for your answers! Interview 12
Username: 636675b4dd6bb79382d46c2b
Date: 12/12/2025 20:27:25
Duration: 34.47 minutes
--------------------

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I work in inventory management as part of supply chain

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. Could you walk me through a typical day on the job and the kinds of decisions or tasks you handle?

[USER]
typical day would be running reports and assessing any issues. I am always needing to try and resolve issues and improve capacity and throughput in my distribution centre

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
job security, ability to progress and develop your skills. Gooding working environment and team members. Good pay

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks. Of the things you just named, which matter most to you right now, and why?

[USER]
Good pay, because of the pressures of cost of living, it is the bottom line to why I work at a company

[ASSISTANT]
When you talk about the ability to progress and develop your skills, what does that look like for you in practice?

[USER]
being able to learn and expand your skillset. Ideally it means being able to develop you so you can move to a higher level within the company or look externally. You don't want to stay stuck or stagnant in the job market

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
at the moment it doesn't really impact me, although I am worried at what it could mean for my job security in the future

[ASSISTANT]
Have you used any AI-enabled tools at work, or tried any on your own for work tasks, even just to experiment?

[USER]
yes I occasionally use it mostly for help with excel or coding queries. And sometimes for summarising text

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used it to solve something in Excel?

[USER]
I needed to figure out how to link two separate sheets using Power Query

[ASSISTANT]
In that Power Query example, what did you ask the tool for, and what specific steps did it suggest that you then carried out?

[USER]
I asked how I could link two or sheets in sharepoint to draw in updated data in a table. It suggested the ways I could do this with specific links in the sharepoint sites

[ASSISTANT]
In that case, which parts did you do yourself and which parts did the tool effectively handle for you?

[USER]
I followed the steps, however, it took several iterations and changes to my prompt to be successful

[ASSISTANT]
When you were iterating those prompts and troubleshooting, what was going through your mind?

[USER]
I was thinking how to communicate effectively with the tool. I am also mindful of not sharing specific company information or files on the tool. So I needed to be clear in what I was asking with placeholders in my prompt for certain parameters

[ASSISTANT]
Did it give you any steps that turned out to be wrong or unhelpful, and if so, how did you handle that?

[USER]
yes, as I mentioned it took several iterations. Each time it didn't quite work I would go back to the tool respond that it didn't work. I would expand on my needs or try to be clearer in what the issue was

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It allowed me to take the idea and actually put it into practice. Before using the tool I would rely on youtube or google searches to troubleshoot ideas like this

[ASSISTANT]
Did using the tool save you time on that task?

[USER]
Yes

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I can't quantify that, as this is not a daily task

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
My manager uses AI quite a lot now, and expects me to use it more

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Yes, more as a suggestion, but as something that might be helpful and be more efficient

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
it made me a little uneasy that that is the expectation

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
that it would have to become the norm to use AI in day to day work

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
because it would be very impersonal to outsource it to AI

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I think it would create a rift between me and my team

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Because it can be tiring and hard to keep on top of

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I don't think they would notice

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
A good portion of the initial implementation was AI, the only aspect that were mine were small tweaks that I added

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
overarching design wise, the AI did a great job. However, for security aspects, the AI was lacking in that respect so I had to do it personally

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I was thinking thank god I caught these gaps, and the team and I implemented fixes so that It would not be an issue once shipped out.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Overall, our company has just moved faster, although we finished quicker, that also means the amount of task we need to accomplish has greatly increased.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
They require the most time commitment and they are the most unrelated to my job position. As a software engineer, my job is to develop and innovate not to fix and to explain. That should be more IT tailored

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It would be to be able to do whatever you want, to understand that your career is safe, and to know the fact that even if AI gets more advanced, AI would still need to compete with you and it can not replace you. Sadly my field is different since AI could replace me at some point once it gets advanced enough, but for jobs that have more of a creative outlook, they would have the autonomy to compete with AI and not fear AI would take their role.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
We have an AI quota to meet at my job, for this reason, daily tasks from development to simple small tweaks all have to go through AI. The only aspect that is my call is during code meets where the team would disagree on an AI implementation and there I can have my own creative outlet.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

For codes which donâ€™t pass the threshold or have potential safety concerns I manually review these

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
The biggest change is that I spend less time on repetitive tasks and more time understanding what the numbers truly mean. AI speeds up the busy work, so my day feels more focused, efficient, and centered on real decisions today.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. Could you tell me what you do for work?

[USER]
Iâ€™m a data analyst. I work with numbers, reports, and trends to help my organization make better decisions. My job is to turn raw data into clear, useful insights.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
A good job offers fair pay, steady hours, and clear expectations. It gives people respect, chances to grow, and work that feels useful. It also provides an environment where employees feel supported, safe, and able to balance life and work.

[ASSISTANT]
If you had to pick the two or three that matter most to you personally, which would you choose?

[USER]
The two things that matter most to me are having more time for real analysis and feeling less pressure from repetitive tasks. These changes make my day smoother and let me focus on clear insights that truly help my team move forward..

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI impacts my work by speeding up routine tasks like cleaning data, generating charts, and summarizing reports. This lets me focus on deeper analysis, spotting trends, and providing actionable insights, making my work more efficient, accurate, and strategically valuable..

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a recent project where you used AI, step by step, from the moment you got the data to the final deliverable?

[USER]
Sure. Recently, I worked on a customer retention analysis. First, I received the raw dataset and uploaded it to an AI tool, which cleaned missing values, standardized formats, and flagged duplicates. Next, it generated summaries and visualizations, which I reviewed carefully, corrected context-specific errors, and added my own interpretations. Finally, I wrote insights and recommendations, combined them with the AI charts, and delivered a polished report to my team.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned correcting context-specific errors. Can you describe one specific error you caught in that project, and what went through your mind when you spotted it?

[USER]
One error the AI flagged was a rare but valid customer code as a duplicate. When I spotted it, I felt cautious and reminded myself not to trust the AI blindly. I double-checked the source data, confirmed it was legitimate, and restored it to keep the dataset accurate..

[ASSISTANT]
In that retention project, which parts did the AI handle end to end, and which parts did you take the lead on?

[USER]
The AI handled data cleaning, identifying duplicates, standardizing formats, and generating initial charts and summaries. I took the lead on reviewing those outputs, correcting context-specific issues, interpreting trends, writing insights, and crafting recommendations to ensure the final report was accurate and meaningful..

[ASSISTANT]
When you were reviewing and correcting the AIâ€™s outputs on that project, what stood out to you about how that part of the work felt?

[USER]
Reviewing and correcting the AIâ€™s outputs felt like a mix of relief and responsibility. It was faster than doing everything manually, but I had to stay alert and use judgment to catch errors, making that part of the work both efficient and mentally engaging..

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved on that project once the routine steps were faster?

[USER]
With the time saved, I focused on deeper analysis, like identifying why certain customers were leaving and spotting actionable trends. I also refined recommendations, added context from other data sources, and ensured the final report was clear, accurate, and strategically valuable for my team.

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to doing a similar retention analysis before using these tools, what changed in how you planned and executed the work?

[USER]
Compared to before, I now spend far less time on cleaning and formatting data, which allows me to plan earlier and focus on interpreting results. The workflow feels more strategic, and I can explore insights more thoroughly instead of getting bogged down in repetitive manual tasks..

[ASSISTANT]
When you deliver a report that involved these tools, how does your confidence in the results compare to when you did everything manually, and why?

[USER]
I feel just as confident, sometimes even more, but for a different reason. The AI speeds up the heavy lifting, but my confidence still comes from double-checking the data myself. The mix of automation and my own review makes the final results feel solid..

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a time you chose not to use the AI on a task, and what led you to make that call?

[USER]
I skipped using AI on a sensitive financial dataset because the numbers were complex, context-heavy, and required careful judgment. I worried the tool might mislabel unusual entries as errors, so I handled everything manually to keep full control and avoid mistakes..

[ASSISTANT]
When you use these tools on a project, how do you document or explain which parts the tool helped with and which parts you did yourself?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
When AI generates code for you now, how do you decide itâ€™s ready to deployâ€”what checks or reviews do you run before putting it into production?

[USER]
I go through it and make sure that it doesn't have any bugs or vulnerabilities that I can see

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
AI has changed the conversations that I have. Instead of talking about the different ways to code projects, we talk about how AI has revolutionized the IT world

[ASSISTANT]
When those conversations shifted, how did your teammates respondâ€”did anything change in how you collaborate day to day?

[USER]
Most people responded positively. There will always be some that are stuck in the old school mindset that think AI is only bad, but I have had mostly positive interactions

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if it could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I would never want to hand over interactions with my team. I like dealing with people

[ASSISTANT]
Why are those interactions with your team important for you to keep personally?

[USER]
They are important because it brings me fulfillment. I don't think that AI would be able to replace human to human interactions

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over team interactions, how do you think it would change your relationships with your teammates or your role on the team?

[USER]
I think that things would become much more impersonal. I feel that I would lose connection with my team

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I would give coding and writing reports over to AI

[ASSISTANT]
What makes coding and writing reports the ones youâ€™d be most ready to hand off?

[USER]
I personally do not like coding and I feel that AI would do a better job at writing reports

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled those, would it change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
I don't think it would change how other see my contributions. As long as I am a good manager, I don't think anyone would see me any differently

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would tell them that having autonomy in your job is having some type of say in what you do on a day to day basis. For example, the ability to work from home or the ability to decide what type of projects you want to work on.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from the past few months where you felt you really had that kind of say over your day to day, and what happened?

[USER]
I have the ability to work from the office or work from home. I do not get to decide what I want to work on, but hope to have that opportunity in the future

[ASSISTANT]
When you talked about having a say, do you mean more about choosing where and when you work, or more about choosing what you work on and how you do itâ€”or is it something else entirely? Which of those matters most to you right now, and why?

[USER]
Having a say to me means both being able to choose where and when you work and what you work on. To me, being able to choose where you work is the most important because I enjoy being able to work in the comfort of my own home.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about a recent day when choosing to work from home changed how you approached your tasks or interacted with your teamâ€”what stands out from that day?

[USER]
Last week, I was able to work from home and I just had a positive outlook the whole day. I did not have to sit in traffic or pay extra for gas. Having this positive outlook makes me have more positive interactions with my team

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for sharing all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is impacting your work that we havenâ€™t covered?

[USER]
No, I think that covers everything.

[ASSISTANT]

Interview 23
Username: 5ba8e80089390100019064ed

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I manage a team of IT professionals supporting a set of computer systems for a hospital

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
One where you are paid a living wage, have good work life balance, and are treated with respect by your employer, boss, and colleagues.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say being treated with respect, what does that look like in your day to day interactions?

[USER]
People are polite but also trust you in your duties

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about good work life balance, what does that look like in a typical week for you?

[USER]
That I would have time each day to spend with my family and engage in personal pursuits without fear of being called or messaged by my employer outside of a true emergency.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about a living wage, what tells you the pay is truly sufficient for your situation?

[USER]
That I can pay for all of my essentials based on my budget while also being able to save a bit for a rainy day, my retirement, my children's education, etc.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
There are some products that certain vendors are offering now that utilize AI for our clinicians that we assist with the implementation of. We also have a few Microsoft Office AI tools turned on like meeting transcription, but I don't tend to use it much.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent implementation where one of those AI-enabled products was involved, and walk me through what you and your team actually did?

[USER]
Our part was very small and we mainly were involved in assisting the vendor get some new vendor-provided workstations on the network. I believe the use case was around mammography image analysis

[ASSISTANT]
In that mammography project, what specific steps did you or your team take to get those workstations live, and what did the vendor handle?

[USER]
basically we had some existing workstations that were not capable of performing the AI functions and we had to swap them out and get them whitelisted on the network based on MAC address. Once that was done, we scheduled some testing sessions with the application teams to make sure all the data flowed correctly connectivity-wise.

[ASSISTANT]
During that rollout, did anything not work as expected, and if so, how did you handle it?

[USER]
no, it went pretty smooth once we got going

[ASSISTANT]
What, if anything, felt different to you about supporting that clinical tool compared to a more typical software or hardware rollout?

[USER]
well all I support are clinical tools, so it was pretty normal

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you tried the meeting transcription tool, or chose not to use it, and what led you to that choice?

[USER]
some of my colleagues like it and turn it on, but I tend not to like it. If I need to take notes, I tend to want to take them myself as it keeps me more engaged in the conversation, and it leads me to ask better questions. If I just rely on the AI, I will tune out.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™ve been in meetings where others have the transcription running, what stands out to you about how it changes the flow of the conversation, if at all?

[USER]
I think people tend to rely on it and they are also not as engaged. I find that they don't do things as well like nail down follow-ups verbally and ensure accountabilities are well understood since they think the AI will just handle it.

[ASSISTANT]
Have you ever had a moment where an AI-produced output in your workflow needed correction, and what did you do in that situation?

[USER]
Not with the transcription as I rarely use it or review its output when someone else has. I have on occasion used AI to help wordsmith things I've already drafted for communication. There have been times when its output has not been correct, and I have had to go back and tweak it again, but I expected that and would never just send what it outputs blind.

[ASSISTANT]
When you noticed those wording mistakes from the AI, what went through your mind in the moment, and how did you decide what to keep versus rewrite yourself?

[USER]
I kind of chuckled but I understood it didn't really know my work. It was fine for me to go back and rewrite since it was just minor tweaks from there and most of the heavy lifting was already done by then.

[ASSISTANT]
When you use it for wordsmithing, does it change how long that task takes for you compared to doing it all yourself, and what do you tend to do with that time?

[USER]
not really, but I like that it offers some suggestions that differ from my usual style as I find that sometimes I can be repetitive.

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond those tools, has anything about your teamâ€™s priorities or the kinds of tickets you see changed because of AI-enabled systems?

[USER]
not thus far. Because of the sensitive nature of our work with protected health information, my employer has been reticent to roll out AI widely.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
none

[ASSISTANT]
Has the use of tools like transcription ever come up in conversations about expectations in meetings with your team or with clinicians?

[USER]
no

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I think final decision making in general should always be with the human. Otherwise, we would have to hold AI accountable for those decisions, and then who is liable for mistakes? The AI company? LOL, they'd never go for that.

[ASSISTANT]
When you picture an AI making the final call instead of you, what goes through your mind about what would be lost in how those decisions get made?

[USER]
someone to blame if the decision goes poorly

[ASSISTANT]
Aside from liability, what is important to you about being the one to make the final call?

[USER]
well as a leader, it's a large part of my job, without that, what's the point of hiring me?

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI started making the final calls, how do you think that would change your relationships with your team or with clinicians you support?

[USER]
I would no longer have a job since it would be doing my job for me

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I'd love it if my office tools were more integrated with AI where it could read and summarize email threads that are lengthy that I get added to late, possibly recommending responses based on previous responses to other similar threads. Scheduling meetings would also be nice as well as better search tools to find emails about things without having to know exact search strings.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes those email and scheduling tasks the right kind to hand off, from your point of view?

[USER]
they involve pretty routine tasks with low risk and there's enough data available digitally to do it

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
To be trusted by your leaders to make your own decisions in the field that are in the best interest of the organization

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example of what that looks like in practice?

[USER]
It's not having to check with your leader on every little decision about how to do something but instead only going to them when there's an escalation needed

[ASSISTANT]
Could you walk me through a recent decision you made without checking in first, and how you knew it was the right call?

[USER]
We had a request to bring on a new system, and my analyst asked me how to enter a detail on the request. It was something I wasn't familiar with, but I knew from experience what was most likely needed there, so I told him what to put. I could have gone to my director, but it was too small of an issue to escalate. I doubt I'm wrong, and if I am, I'll take the hit.

[ASSISTANT]
How do you decide where that line is between a small call you make on the spot and something you escalateâ€”what cues do you pay attention to?

[USER]
level of risk involved in the decision, uncertainty, and whether other teams are involved/affected

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything we have not covered about how AI is affecting your work that you want to add?

[USER]
no

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about the last time you did this, what was the specific issue you were troubleshooting, and how did what the AI surfaced shape your next steps?

[USER]
That specific issue we were troubleshooting was database related. There was a very peculiar, intermittent error from a production database. It was so peculiar and rare that even googling it didn't yield much helpful result. With the help of AI, we eventually got to learn about an edge case of that particular version of the database and fixed it by applying a patch.

[ASSISTANT]
In that database incident, which parts did the work go to the AI and which parts did you or your team do yourselves?

[USER]
AI did the research part of the work given the context and my team did the rest (patching and giving AI the context of the problem)

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I was amazed and wonder who and how AI was trained on this one.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Applying the patch was really a no-brainer solution so the confidence in the diagnosis was quite high.

[ASSISTANT]
In that case or others, has the AI ever sent you down an unhelpful or wrong path, and if so, how did you handle it?

[USER]
Not in the professional context but has happened in the personal context

[ASSISTANT]
In your day to day work, when the AI parses logs or surfaces a likely cause, how do you check its take before acting on it?

[USER]
We always fact check (at least try our best to) AI's findings. I can't tell my boss that AI messed up when we blindly follow AI's suggestions.

[ASSISTANT]
When AI speeds up the log digging, what do you usually end up spending that freed up time on?

[USER]
We spend the free time on other projects.

[ASSISTANT]
How does doing this kind of troubleshooting with AI compare to how you handled it before you had these tools?

[USER]
Troubleshooting with AI saves us a lot of time and resource.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
AI has not affected my working relationship at all

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I would never delegate managing of my underlings to AI

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I know more than AI would ever know about how to interact and utilize my team and its members. It's almost impossible (in terms of time and cost) to train AI to do this kind of managing work for my team.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I don't think this would change because ultimately I am the one who calls the shot regardless of the presence of AI

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I asked for flexible work hours. I made the case that I'd be as effective working at 11pm than I would at 7am. I was granted flexible work hours and my team ran smoother after that.

[ASSISTANT]

Stay on top of everything and proactively look for issues and problems.

[USER]

In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
A good job pays fairly, feels stable, and treats people with respect. It gives you some control over your time, clear expectations, and room to grow without burning you out. Good leadership and a decent work life balance matter a lot too.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Fair pay, control over my time, and not feeling burned out matter most to me. [ASSISTANT]
When you say control over your time, what does that look like in a typical week for you?

[USER]
It means I can set my own schedule most days, like doing deep work in the morning, taking a break midday, and finishing up later if I need to. I can move meetings around, block off time for errands or appointments, and choose how many projects I take on at once. The only times it gets tight is when thereâ€™s a deadline or a client has an urgent issue.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI helps me move faster on a lot of the day to day stuff. I use it to brainstorm solutions, generate rough code snippets, write or clean up documentation, and rephrase client emails so they are clear and professional. It also helps when I am debugging, like giving me a checklist of what to look at or explaining an error message in plain English.

It does not replace my job, but it cuts down the time I spend stuck or doing repetitive work. I still have to review everything, test it, and make sure it fits the clientâ€™s setup, because AI can be confidently wrong or miss edge cases.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used it on a projectâ€”what were you trying to do?

[USER]
Yeah, last time was this week on a client site that was running slow after a plugin update. I was trying to figure out what was causing the slowdown and what I could change without breaking anything. I used AI to help me outline a quick troubleshooting plan, suggest what logs and metrics to check, and give me a couple ideas for caching and database cleanup, then I went and tested everything myself before making changes.

[ASSISTANT]
In that troubleshooting case, which parts did the tool generate for you, and which parts did you handle yourself?

[USER]
The tool generated the rough plan and the list of likely causes, like checking server load, slow queries, plugin conflicts, and caching settings, and it gave me some example commands and steps to try. I handled pulling the actual logs, running the checks, doing the testing in staging, and deciding what changes were safe for that specific site. I also did the final cleanup and monitored it after to make sure performance stayed normal.

[ASSISTANT]
In that case, did any of its suggestions turn out to be off base or risky, and how did you handle that when you spotted it?

[USER]
Yeah, a couple suggestions were a little risky for that situation, like being too aggressive with database cleanup and disabling certain plugins to test on the live site. I handled it by doing everything in a staging copy first, double checking the plugin docs, and making sure I had a fresh backup before touching production. If something sounded generic or too broad, I treated it like a starting point and verified it before I acted on it.

[ASSISTANT]
When you were working through that slowdown with the toolâ€™s plan in hand, what was going through your mind as you followed it step by step?

[USER]
I was basically thinking, this is a decent checklist, but I need to prove it with real data. I was focused on not making the problem worse, keeping changes reversible, and finding the simplest explanation first. I was also watching the clock a bit, because clients want it fixed fast, but Iâ€™d rather take an extra hour than break the site.

[ASSISTANT]
When you were reviewing and adjusting its suggestions, what did that feel like for you in the moment?

[USER]
It felt like having a junior assistant tossing out ideas, some helpful, some not. I was moving quicker because I was not staring at a blank wall, but I still had to stay sharp and not get lazy about verifying things. It was a mix of relief and skepticism, like, thanks for the direction, but Iâ€™m still the one responsible if it goes wrong.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Before AI, I would have done the same basic process, but it would have been slower and more manual. I would be bouncing between docs, old notes, and forum posts to build my own checklist, and sometimes Iâ€™d miss an angle until later. With AI, I get a solid starting plan in minutes, so I spend more time testing and fixing instead of searching and second guessing.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Yeah, recently I was building a small contact and quote request flow for a client site, basically a form that validates input, blocks obvious spam, and sends the data to their CRM. I had the tool generate a first pass at the validation logic and a helper function to format the payload the way the CRM expects, then I refactored it to match the project style, added better error handling, and wrote tests around the edge cases.

I treated what it gave me like a rough draft. I still reviewed it line by line, checked security stuff like sanitization and rate limiting, and made sure it actually worked with the clientâ€™s backend and hosting setup.

[ASSISTANT]
Has it ever produced something that passed your initial checks but later caused an issue in staging or production? What happened?

[USER]
Yeah, thatâ€™s happened. It generated a helper that looked fine at first, linted clean, and worked in a basic test, but in staging it caused weird edge case failures with certain characters and empty fields. It also made a bad assumption about how the API handled null values, so the CRM would reject some submissions.

I caught it because I started seeing inconsistent form results and a few error responses in the logs. I fixed it by tightening the validation, normalizing the payload consistently, adding a couple extra tests for those edge cases, and then rolling a small patch. After that I started being stricter about testing with messy real world input instead of just the happy path.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
Itâ€™s mostly made things smoother because I can respond faster and communicate more clearly with clients. I use it to tighten up explanations, scope notes, and status updates, so thereâ€™s less back and forth and fewer misunderstandings.

On the flip side, it can raise expectations, like some clients assume everything should be instant now. With other developers, itâ€™s kind of neutral, it helps me share a clearer plan or snippet, but I still have to make sure Iâ€™m not sending something unvetted.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future, is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Yeah, I would not want to hand over the final judgment and accountability parts, like deciding whatâ€™s safe to change on a live site, how to balance cost versus risk, and when to tell a client no. Even if it could do it perfectly, I think the trust piece matters, clients want a real person owning the decision and taking responsibility.

I also would not want to fully outsource the relationship side, like understanding what a client actually means, calming them down when something breaks, and guiding them through tradeoffs. That human back and forth is a big part of why projects succeed.

[ASSISTANT]
What is it about you being the one to make the call that matters most to your clients, from your point of view?

[USER]
I think clients care that a real person is listening to their situation and not just following a script. They want someone who understands their business, knows the history of the site, and can explain the risk in plain terms, then stand behind the decision if something goes sideways.

Also, when money and downtime are on the line, they want confidence and accountability, like, whoâ€™s actually responsible and whoâ€™s fixing it if it breaks. AI can help with options, but it canâ€™t replace that trust relationship.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI started making those calls instead of you, how do you think that would change your relationships with clients or your place on the project?

[USER]
It would make the relationship feel more transactional, like Iâ€™m just there to run the tool and relay the answer. Clients might trust me less because Iâ€™m not really the decision maker anymore, and if something goes wrong they would still look at me like, why did you let the AI do that.

On the project side, it would push me more into a supervisor role, checking and approving instead of actively problem solving. That could be fine sometimes, but it also makes it harder to show my value, because the thing clients pay for is judgment, communication, and owning the outcome.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I would happily hand over the repetitive busywork, like writing boilerplate code, converting data formats, and doing first pass debugging suggestions. Iâ€™d also love it to handle scheduling, meeting notes, and turning a messy client email thread into a clean task list. That stuff eats time and doesnâ€™t really need my brain.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes those specific tasks good candidates to hand offâ€”what is it about them that youâ€™d be happiest to stop doing yourself?

[USER]
They are mostly predictable and repetitive, so they donâ€™t feel like the best use of my time. They also have a lot of context switching, like jumping between emails, tickets, and tiny code edits, which drains my focus fast.

If AI can take the first swing and turn that stuff into something organized and close to correct, I get to spend my energy on the parts that actually need a human, like architecture decisions, tricky bugs, and talking things through with the client.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over those busywork tasks, would it change how clients or collaborators see your contribution?

[USER]
I think most clients would see it as a win as long as the results are solid, because they mainly care about speed, quality, and clarity. If I can deliver faster and with fewer mistakes, they usually do not care how I got there.

With collaborators, it depends. Some people might assume I am doing less, but I think good developers will recognize that the value is still in the decisions, the review, and making everything work in the real environment. I would just have to be transparent about what was AI assisted and make sure I am still owning the outcome.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would tell them autonomy means you are trusted to figure out the how, not just follow instructions. You get to choose your tools, your workflow, and often your schedule, and you can push back when something is a bad idea or not realistic.

Today it also means being able to manage your attention, because there are a million distractions and AI makes it even easier to move fast without thinking. Real autonomy is still you setting standards, making the call, and taking responsibility for the outcome.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example from this year when you set the standards and made the call, and what that looked like in practice?

[USER]
Yeah, earlier this year a client wanted me to rush a redesign straight onto their live site because they had a promo coming up. I set the standard that we do changes in staging first, we take a full backup, we do a performance check, and we have a rollback plan, even if it costs a little more time.

In practice that meant I pushed back on the timeline, set up a staging copy, ran through the key pages on mobile and desktop, and had the client approve the final version before we deployed. The promo launched fine, and the big value for them was they did not have any downtime or surprise bugs during the week they needed things to be perfect.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
no, that covers it.

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
When you were relying on those AI flags, what was your gut responseâ€”what stands out to you about how that part of the process felt?

[USER]
The AI made the process feel faster to me, and it made it  more focused because it narrowed down where to look for me.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking back to before you used these tools, how is doing a cleanup now different from then?

[USER]
Data clean ups then were much more manual and time consuming. i had to scan large datasets myself to find where the issues likely is and how to fix them.

[ASSISTANT]
You also mentioned pattern detection. Can you tell me about a time the tool surfaced a pattern that changed what you did next?

[USER]
The tool highlighted a repeated pattern linked to a specific data source, therefore instead of fixing records individually, i opted to trace its upstream and fix the root cause.

[ASSISTANT]
In that upstream fix example, which parts did the tool handle and which parts did you handle yourself?

[USER]
The tool identified the recurring pattern and pointed me to where the inconsistencies were happening. I handled the interpretation, and traced the issue upstream.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
Positively i will say

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a recent example of a positive change in how you worked with a colleague or manager because of these tools?

[USER]
AI had recently  helped me surface data issues and insights faster, which made my conversations with my manager more focused and very well productive.

[ASSISTANT]
What stood out to you about that conversation with your managerâ€”what did they say or do that felt different from before?

[USER]
what stood out for me was how the conversation shifted from questioning the data to discussing decisions,  i felt valued.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Yes, it has.

[ASSISTANT]
In what way has the split changedâ€”who does what now compared to before?

[USER]
AI now handles much of the initial scanning and flagging, so as a team we spend less time on manual checks and more time dividing up validation, and root cause analysis.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Are we close to rounding up?

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It is important to me because those decisions are where responsibility and trust really sit, and breach of trust is unforgivable in my line of work

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
My role will most likely change from contributing insight to executing outputs.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
That would be repetitive and time consuming tasks.

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
My contribution will become clearer.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I would say to them that autonomy is more about being trusted to make decisions, and take responsibility for outcomes, than working alone.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

can we round up

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I will say AI has affected my work positively, it has shifted my role from doing more manual work to doing more thinking and communicating which is quite awesome.

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

Interview 35

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
How much longer that I would still have a job and felt really bad for a lot of my friends and coworkers who just were gone

[ASSISTANT]
That sounds like a really tough period. Could you tell me what your role is and what your day to day looked like around that time?

[USER]
Strictly speaking I'm web developer but for about 6 years I've been what they have called me is a technical lead which I lima lead a team of six which includes a few web developers a keyway and a screwmaster

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. What does leading that team involve for you on a typical day?

[USER]
Sorry that should say scrum master. But yes we have several meetings each week talking about the types of things that we're all doing and going to be doing and I have code reviews with them and we disseminate work

[ASSISTANT]
I appreciate you clarifying, and thanks for walking me through your routine. In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
For me it is being able to use one's skills and getting paid a decent wage and having an employer who cares about your well-being be it physical or career etc and just having that work life balance that everybody talks about

[ASSISTANT]
Of the things you mentioned, which one matters most to you right now, and why?

[USER]
For me it's the work-life balance aspect because while I do appreciate the salary and that is something I don't want to go away what's really important is spending time with my family

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about a healthy week, what does that balance look like in practice for you?

[USER]
Well I work a hybrid schedule so I'm able to work from home a little bit and that allows me to pop in and out sometimes to help kids with their homework and things like this but I also want to be able to collaborate and have relationships with my teammates too

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
For me AI is both exciting and a little scary. The problem is that we started our company out with copilot for everybody to use however they want to use it and that was rolled out to everybody really quick. Now there are other tools we are allowing rolling out like quad code and cursor but it isn't a limited fashion so not everybody has access to them right away. So right now the impact is slower than I'd like it to be but it still is very useful in allowing me to learn concepts and skills that I don't understand or don't have

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used one of these tools on a specific piece of work? What was the task, and how did you use the tool step by step?

[USER]
Well a lot of my teammates are using Claude code and cursor right now but I don't have access yet unbelievably. So I still rely on Microsoft co-pilot both as a chatbot but also inside visual studio. Anyway my team has a lot of front-end developers but a little bit back and as well. But most recently we have been charged with improving SEO. Not only in terms of how fast the page loads but in terms of content and working with the marketing team and the content editors and everything. So I've been using Microsoft co-pilot along with our scrum Master to churn out a plan to figure out how to improve our SEO and AEO and GEO and all the O's

[ASSISTANT]
In that SEO planning example, what parts did Copilot actually produce, and what parts did you and your scrum master create yourselves?

[USER]
We are very open and new to SEO in terms of marketing and content. We are more experts in page speed and things to do with lighthouse reports. So we were just ideating in brainstorming and both my scrum master and I did this separately. We fed it what our basic goals were and then we asked AI what types of things that we would need to do to achieve those goals we gave it as much context as we could in terms of what our business was and the types of contact that we had out there already

[ASSISTANT]
When Copilot gave you those suggestions, what did you keep and act on, and what did you set aside?

[USER]
What we did is that we each came up with sort of a battle plan and mine was more from a technical side of things and hers was more from what she had heard from marketing. We ended up combining them noting which goals were higher priorities and which ones we had already accomplished and which ones we were not going to worry about right away. Some of it may no sense for us but other parts made a lot of sense and it helped us sort of formulate how and when we were going to move forward. And then we took all that and created a notion doc from it

[ASSISTANT]
Were there any suggestions from Copilot that were off base or just not workable for your context, and how did you handle those?

[USER]
Yes some were definitely off base and I was able to sort of call those out as being either nonsensical or not appropriate to our business case. What ended up happening was that the scrum Masters document was very fluffy and a lot of noise and we had to spend a lot of time going about eliminating things that she thought sounded great but just did not apply to our case

[ASSISTANT]
When you realized a lot of it was fluff or not a fit, what went through your mind, and how did you approach the conversation with your scrum master about trimming it down?

[USER]
Well I was open to ideas and acting on things that I had previously thought of before but I also wanted to make sure that we didn't spend all of our time burning new things but instead that we actually accomplished some low-hanging fruit tasks quickly and made our marketing partners and others happy and we sort of iterated on the document and kept a few things around to think about later

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to doing this kind of planning before these tools were around, how did the process and the pace feel different this time?

[USER]
The process felt more rushed and well there were less people in the room. Because a number of them had been let go or left. So part of it was that we are listening to podcasts and during doing research and querying AI about what we can do for SEO and AEO but there are more let's just say non-technical people that are producing these documents and that they just expect you to do work from this AI output almost like a CEO might hand you a mock-up of a website and say just build it when there are gaps in technical details so it feels a little rushed and a little bit flimsy

[ASSISTANT]
When you get one of those AIâ€‘generated docs from a nonâ€‘technical colleague, what do you do first to turn it into something you can actually build?

[USER]
Firstly I remove as many emoticons I can but I also try to boil it down into things that are technically feasible

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used Copilot inside Visual Studio on an actual coding task? What were you trying to build, and how did you use or modify its suggestions?

[USER]
Well my main application right now is a.net framework 4.8 that has code that is up to 15 years old. So I haven't actually found co-pilot within visual studio that useful. This is code that I've lived with for all these years and while I have experimented with it hasn't produced results that made me any more productive. If anything it can help me with syntax and sort of autocomplete type things but I'm not yet at a point where I can rewrite entire application in a different language or something like that

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a time when Copilot actually helped you learn or crack something you were stuck on? What was the moment it clicked, and what did you do next?

[USER]
Well it can help with things like the vulnerable code and security issues. I'm not a security expert at all so I can give it some code and it can help me identify where there is a vulnerability either in my code or some related library and it can explain terms very quickly and in fact much more quickly than it would take me to look them up old school and Google or stack overflow

[ASSISTANT]
When it flagged a vulnerability, what steps did you take to check whether it was right before making any changes?

[USER]
Any code whether it's generated by AI or not falls under a review process with my peers so there is that at the base level but then when there is a security risk we also bring in a security reviewer as well and they sign off on it and sometimes I never really know on my own if something is truly fixed so it helps to have that purity process in place

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
That is a really good question. I think that it has both hurt and helped. It has helped because more people are stepping up to innovate and contribute and so there is more collaboration. On the other hand everybody thinks that they're an expert and it can be a little bit overwhelming and can put a little bit of a strain on those relationships

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent moment when these tools clearly improved collaboration on your team? What happened, and what stands out to you about it?

[USER]
Well I think that the AI itself didn't improve collaboration it was just that it gave us more to talk about. So it wasn't like we said hey I hey I said to do this and let's do this it was hey we have our own ideas AI has these ideas and it just sort of promoted more discussion and it allowed a number of people to speak up that maybe wouldn't have spoken up before

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a time when these tools created strain or tension with a colleague or stakeholder? What happened, and how did you handle it?

[USER]
Well it is definitely uncomfortable with my scrum master because she is high energy and likes to encourage us to get things done which is fine except for she will hear request from a stakeholder put it in AI crank out a document that is not necessarily technically sound and say go do this and you can do that by Friday right? When it may not be something that can be done for three Fridays from now it's hard to have the conversation about it with her because she is well meeting and don't want to put her down in any way

[ASSISTANT]
In that moment when she handed you the doc and a tight deadline, what did you say or do to reset the scope or the timeline?

[USER]
Well fortunately we didn't promise her anything about when we would get it done she would just ask us what our progress was and then try to explain to her what we had done and what we still had to do in any blockers that we had and it's kind of live with her asking and asking. We just get it done when we get it done

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I like the little maintenance tasks and one off tasks that people ask me to do that they do because maybe at the last one of the company that was having to do it. I don't think AI could ever replace some of these custom ad hoc legacy tasks. If it could I would be sad because I really enjoy doing that

[ASSISTANT]
What makes those ad hoc legacy tasks satisfying for you to keep doing yourself rather than handing them to a tool?

[USER]
Well I don't know that a tool be at AI or not could do some of these things. Basically the folds are using a tool but then there's one or two things that they can't or won't do that I know how to do and it just makes me feel useful and it really type of thing or these are types of things that would not be worth modifying and we're adding AI to anyway

[ASSISTANT]
If a tool did take over those ad hoc legacy tasks, how do you think that would change your role on the team or your relationships with the folks who ask you for help?

[USER]
Well if it did as you say then I would probably have less relationships with people

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Well part of it is taking notes and meetings and forming action items and we already do that with AI but it is just not very good at it so it is not useful at all if it were useful I would love it

[ASSISTANT]
When you say the meeting notes and action items arenâ€™t very good yet, what typically goes wrong in them?

[USER]
Well the two major tools that we use in that regard right now are zoom meetings and slack puddles. Slack is a little better than zoom but it did not understand the context enough to know that next item is suggesting is not real. It just doesn't get it quite right. The summaries are a little better as to what was said but the action item aren't so you can't have a list of 10 action items were set of been of them are bad seven of them are bad

[ASSISTANT]
If the notes and action items were accurate and reliable, how would that change how you run meetings or what you do right after them?

[USER]
Yes 100% it would. We could turn these action items into work tickets for example and just streamline a lot of things

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
The biggest thing right now I feel is that at my company and a lot of companies we have the ability to innovate and move up the ladder by thinking in ways that are new and useful and can make the company money and really AI I feel levels to playing field for people in my role but in a lot of rules because it gives them easier access to powerful tools

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from your own job where you had that kind of freedom to try a new idea, and what you actually did?

[USER]
Well right now it is the SEO example that I gave earlier. I am no SEO expert at all. We got rid of the director of SEO or whatever he was called 6 months ago and now for some reason this falls to my team. So we are expected to learn and do very quickly these things that this other person did. So we just as I mentioned brainstormed and came up with you with a few action items and just experimented basically in production and try to determine if that improved our SEO which is difficult to do actually

[ASSISTANT]
In your current role, what is a concrete decision you can make on your own without checking with someone else?

[USER]
Well I am sort of a gatekeeper of code going to production so well and I also have yours of experience on my particular application so I am able to push certain things to production without going through QA as long as they don't break any security guard rails we have in place.

[ASSISTANT]
For that young person, how would they know they truly have itâ€”what could they decide on their own, and what responsibilities would come with that?

[USER]
I would say if they have to ask if they have it or not then they don't have it. But if you are good at what you do and you are comfortable with the risk then you will probably be rewarded for those responsibilities that will come with that.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t talked about?

[USER]
I think we've covered it all today thank you.

[ASSISTANT]
