[USER]
A good job for me as a data analyst,  is one where my work feels useful, my skills are valued and I'm well paid fairly

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI impacts my work by helping me process large datasets faster and spot patterns I might miss manually. It can automate routine tasks like cleaning data or generating reports, which frees me to focus on deeper analysis and more strategic, decision-driving insights.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about the last time you used AI to clean a dataset. What did it do, and what did you handle yourself?

[USER]

I handled the context-specific decisions myself, like deciding which rows to keep or remove, adjusting outliers, and ensuring the cleaned data matched the project goals.

[USER]
Last time I used AI to clean a dataset, it automatically identified missing values, standardized formats, and flagged duplicates. I handled the context-specific decisions myself, like deciding which rows to keep or remove and ensuring the cleaned data matched the project goals.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
The AI sometimes flagged unusual but valid entries as errors, like rare customer codes. I caught these by cross-checking against the source data and patterns I knew were legitimate, then manually corrected or restored them to ensure the dataset stayed accurate.

[ASSISTANT]
What went through your mind when you saw those valid entries being flagged?

[USER]
I felt cautious because it reminded me that AI can be helpful but still miss context. I knew I had to doubleâ€‘check things myself, trust my own judgment.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a recent time you used AI to generate a report, step by step from start to finish?

[USER]
Sure. Recently, I generated a monthly sales performance report using AI. First, I uploaded the raw sales data and defined the metrics I wanted, like revenue by region and top-selling products. Then, the AI cleaned the data, summarized trends, and created charts. I reviewed the output, checked for errors or unusual spikes, and adjusted labels or explanations as needed. Finally, I added context from my own analysis, wrote a short narrative, and shared the polished report with my team.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Establishing a role for the AI - starting off with "you are a/an..." and forcing it to scope itself within that role seems to help it from straying off-topic too much and increase it's success rate

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
When you say meaning or purpose, what does that look like for you in day to day terms?

[USER]
I try to see how my work links up to something bigger than the job itself. I also like to be tangible results from my work. For example fixing someone's work pc lets them do their job and I can directly see that.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a decent work life balance, what does that look like in practice for you?

[USER]
You have time and energy to do stuff in your personal life

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
It helps me be more productive but I also think it might also lower the quality of said work but I think the extra efficiency it brings probably outweighs the lower quality.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used AI on a specific ticket, step by step? What did you do first, and where did AI come in?

[USER]
The last time I used AI on a ticket was when a user reported slow access to a shared drive, I collected basic diag first. I fed those results into an AI tool to quickly summarize the likely cause and draft the next troubleshooting steps. I then used it to generate a clean user update and a small PowerShell snippet, which I reviewed and adjusted before taking action.

[ASSISTANT]
Did the AI make any mistakes in the summary or the PowerShell, and how did you handle that?

[USER]
Yes it made a few mistakes but I just ran over it myself and touched up the mistakes and it worked fine.

[ASSISTANT]
When you spotted those mistakes, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
Well I know LLM's are not perfect so it was to be expected.

[ASSISTANT]
How did handling this ticket with AI compare to how you used to handle similar issues before?

[USER]
It was probably like 25% faster than without an AI

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved on that ticket?

[USER]
All I did was get to my other work faster

[ASSISTANT]
When you use AI on a ticket like that, do you find yourself feeling more confident in the outcome or doubleâ€‘checking more than usual? What leads you there?

[USER]
Well I always check over stuff the AI spits out but after I ran over the info myself I felt confident.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re reviewing or correcting what the AI produced, does that feel like youâ€™re really using your skill, or more like cleanup work? What stands out to you about that part of the process?

[USER]
I still have to know what i'm doing to interface with the stuff

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a time when the AIâ€™s suggestion would have caused a problem if you had followed it as written? What happened and how did you catch it?

[USER]
AI once suggested fixing a slow-login issue by deleting a user's local profile folder, but it missed that the folder contained locally stored project data. Before running the command, I checked the profile size and saw the unsynced files, which would have been lost. I instead backed up the data first and used a safer repair method, which prevented any data loss.

[ASSISTANT]
Aside from troubleshooting tickets, are there other parts of your role where AI has changed how you work?

[USER]
Yeah, LLMs have sped up alot of non troubleshooting stuff in my job. I used it to draft a clearer documentation and internal KB articles, to generate first pass versions of training materials on user guides and to automate repetitive tasks like writing boilerplate scripts or email templates. it's also user for quickly summarizing long policy updates or vendor release notes so I can focus on what actually affects our environment.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
gonna be honest I don't really think it has changed much on my end at leas yet.

[ASSISTANT]
Have your managerâ€™s expectations around speed or volume shifted as youâ€™ve started using these tools?

[USER]
Not that I have noticed but they might just not be telling me

[ASSISTANT]
Have any of your coworkers talked with you about using AI on tickets or docs? What kinds of reactions or norms are you seeing on your team, if any?

[USER]
Yes multiple have talked about it. Pretty much everyone I work with utilizes AI. Even though some might not love it. Its undeniable that it increases productivity.

[ASSISTANT]
Have any users or clients reacted to updates or materials you produced with AI, and what was that interaction like?

[USER]
Nope not that I have seen

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Yes I think any parts that involve trust that only a human can provide is super important.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent situation at work where that kind of trust really mattered? What happened?

[USER]
A few weeks ago an employee was close to breaking down because a spreadsheet they spent days on would not open and they thought it was gone. Instead of jumping straight into technical jargon I sat with them and walked them through what they did and reassured them that we could recover the data if need be. I think that human interaction mattered it kept them from panicking and helped us work together until we restored the data.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I just dont think an LLM can replace that kind of human touch so to say.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI tried to handle that kind of situation end to end, how do you think it would change how your coworkers see you or your role on the team?

[USER]
I am not sure to be honest but I dont think it would be positive.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Any kind of work that requires mindless data entry.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Its boring and isnt that complicated.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over the data entry, how do you think it would change how others see your contribution on the team, if at all?

[USER]
I dont think anyone would care.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would tell them autonomy means having the know how, skills, and confidence to make decisions about how to solve problems without waiting for step-by-step instructions, while knowing when to escalate or seek input.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example from the past month when you made a call without waiting for instructions, and what checks you used to be sure it was the right move?

[USER]
Last month a user reported that Outlook kept crashing when sending large attachments. Instead of immediately escalating, I first checked their mailbox size, add-ins, and recent updates. I decided to temporarily move large attachments to OneDrive and adjust their Outlook cache settings. I verified the fix by having the user test sending a large file and confirming no crashed, then documented the steps in the ticket.

[ASSISTANT]
What tells you itâ€™s time to escalate rather than proceed on your ownâ€”what specific signals do you look for?

[USER]
When its either a some what risky situation or if after repeated troubleshooting I cant find an answer.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Mostly the technical side

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Not really tbh

[ASSISTANT]

Interview 54

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I work with autistic individuals

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
The core characteristics are treating employees ethically, paying a decent living wage, not requiring unethical behavior in the workplace, etc.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say treating employees ethically, what does that look like day to day in a workplace?

[USER]
That would include being respectful to workers, not requiring unpaid work, not insulting workers, etc.

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond ethical treatment and fair pay, what else matters most to you in a good job?

[USER]
Being able to work on things I'm interested in

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I use AI to help format session notes and convert my voice to text descriptions of sessions into grammatically correct notes

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used it to produce a session note, step by step? What did you do first, and what did the AI do?

[USER]
First I would write paper notes in the session, then later I would read the session notes out loud on my PC with my PC mic and then use voice to text conversion software to convert the notes into text, and whilst doing that I'm also adding additional details I think of at the moment, then I take that big block of text and give it to the AI to clean up, convert words that might have been misheard into the right words, etc. Then I'll proofread that for any errors, and then I have a text to voice program read the notes back to me to make sure it all flows well.  The AI just helps me to correct grammar, add punctuation, correct misheard words, etc. I do nearly all the work myself and I quadruple check the AI every step of the way because I know it constantly makes mistakes.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example of a mistake it made recently, and tell me how you handled it?

[USER]
For example, sometimes it doesn't create sentences that flow well and I'll go in and manually change the structure, remove periods, add semicolons, etc.

[ASSISTANT]
When you catch those flow issues or misheard words, what goes through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
I think "Oh, it didn't do what I wanted, let me rectify that"

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to before you used these tools, how has your workflow for notes changed, if at all?

[USER]
It's a little faster, because I used to use Grammarly for spell checking and grammar and the AI does it slightly faster

[ASSISTANT]
When you read through the AI-polished note, do you feel more confident in the final write-up or less, and what leads you to that judgment?

[USER]
I feel alright, I mean it's basically just saving me a little time

[ASSISTANT]
What do you usually do with the time you save on notes?

[USER]
I work on other projects because I live in Southern California, the most expensive place in almost all the US to live. I work about 16+ hours a day every day and all I ever do is work because employers refuse to pay a decent pay for highly educated workers in 2025.

[ASSISTANT]
Are there any other parts of your work where you bring these tools in, beyond preparing session notes?

[USER]
No

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I don't think it has made much difference

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I wouldn't want to handle the actual interactions I have with the autistic people because I don't think AI can read human emotions the way a human can

[ASSISTANT]
Why is that part of the work important for you to keep?

[USER]
It's important to keep a human connection

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent moment when being face to face changed how you worked with someone? What stands out to you about that moment?

[USER]
I was recently working with someone in person and I could tell they were upset so I changed my attitude.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over those person-to-person interactions, how do you think it would change your relationships with your clients or your role on the team?

[USER]
I don't know what I would do as a large part of my job is the in person interactions. I would feel as if I had nothing to do.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
There are some tedious work related activities that I would delegate, such as bureaucratic paperwork, tedious filling in forms, etc.

[ASSISTANT]
Why would you like to give up those paperwork and form-filling tasks?

[USER]
I would give those up because I don't enjoy doing them

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled those forms, how do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team, if at all?

[USER]
I don't think it would change anything because I don't think anyone would know.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would tell them that autonomy is a double edged sword and the good thing is the freedom but the bad thing is you have handle everything yourself and it gets overwhelming sometimes

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example of what that freedom looks like in practice in your day to day work?

[USER]
Freedom is being able to arrange my own schedule with work, depending on availability of the autistic people.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent time when handling everything yourself felt like too much?

[USER]
Well, recently I have been working a lot and arranging the sessions, handling phone calls from the parents, making lesson plans, etc., does get to be a lot sometimes, especially because I don't get paid for a lot of it.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say you have to handle everything yourself, what kinds of decisions are you making on your own that weigh on you the most?

[USER]
The hardest decisions are trying to juggle all the things I need to do, such as work related stuff, planning things with my girlfriend, paying for my living expenses (I live alone), and making a budget and sticking to it (my GF likes to go out to eat a lot and I cannot afford it and it leads to problems sometimes).

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for sharing all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t covered?

[USER]
Well, one problem that has arisen is that I used to do freelance tech writing work on the side and all those jobs have been replaced with AI, and it's hard when you live in the US that has no social safety net at all and if you don't have a job you will likely just die of starvation, and all the jobs are being taken by robots.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I feel this covers the main points

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am an IT professional

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
I think what I most value/look for in a job is good work environment, good salary, and a good work/life balance though the last one is more or less a pipedream

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a good work environment, what does that look like day to day for you?

[USER]
Management trusting those below them, coworkers being cooperative not necessarily nice but able to work together and a safe environment for workers.

[ASSISTANT]
When you mentioned work and life balance being a pipedream, what makes it hard to achieve in your line of work?

[USER]
In my current role I am on call a lot and if I were to try and jobshop a bit I think I would need to be on call more or less everywhere I go, so its just  bit tough at the moment

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a good salary, what makes it feel fair to you?

[USER]
Fair market value basically, or to be more specific alot of the better companies/recruiters will bake in salary/col adjustments into starting salary

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
Management has tried a lot to implement more and more AI programs for tasks they deem "monotonous" or think me and my team shouldn't be bothered doing and I can't seem to convince them how bad of an idea this is  given theyre handling sensitive details and often make mistakes

[ASSISTANT]
Could you walk me through a recent example of one of those tasksâ€”what the AI was set up to do, what you did, and what actually happened?

[USER]
Okay so we have a ticket system for basically everything, issues/equipment requests/general questions etc. Management has tried to implement an AI chatbot so one of me or my team wouldn't have to monitor the tickets and on the initial rollout there were quite a few issues of the AI marking tickets resolved that they hadn't even responded to. Instead of immediately letting management know(because they're too stubborn to fix it initially) I let the AI do a bit more damage before I decided to inform them and when I did they immediately rescinded the AI chatbot.

[ASSISTANT]
What went through your mind when you saw tickets getting closed without any response?

[USER]
My immediate thoughts were something along the lines of I told you so

[ASSISTANT]
After you noticed it happening, what did you do step by step before you told management?

[USER]
I documented everything, the initial problems and the subsequent ones and then spoke to management and showed them everything

[ASSISTANT]
What happened for the people who had their tickets closedâ€”did any of them reach out, and how did you handle those cases?

[USER]
Thankfully the volume wasn't large enough that it was insurmountable but I was putting out the respective fires as they came up and luckily didn't need to bring anyone else in on it

[ASSISTANT]
In that rollout, what did the chatbot actually do compared to what you would normally do when you monitor tickets?

[USER]
As a ticket came in the chatbot would give a default greeting, ask how it could help(which just forces them to restate their problem and likely aggrevate them) and then using keywords/buzzwords would try its best to help them

[ASSISTANT]
How did working tickets during that period compare to how you handled them before the chatbotâ€”what changed in your pace or workflow?

[USER]
I basically only interacted with the tickets when the chatbot hit a wall, and then they were farmed out to me. It interrupted my workflow as I had to learn about the ticket way after the issue had arose

[ASSISTANT]
When those stalled tickets landed on your plate after the chatbot hit a wall, what stands out to you about how you reacted in the moment?

[USER]
Usually just anger or frustration because I could've sold this instantly as I saw the ticket but management decided the bot was a better idea.

[ASSISTANT]
Looking back on that rollout, what, if anything, worked well for you?

[USER]
Truthfully, nothing I can't recall a single thing that was better as all it did was anger me that people couldn't get help in a timely manner and would think its my teams fault but in reality we had no control over it

[ASSISTANT]
Besides the ticket chatbot, has anything else using AI touched your work lately?

[USER]
No, but management has encouraged us to introduce any sort of AI assistance to our daily workflow if we think it would help

[ASSISTANT]
Have you tried bringing any AI tools into your own workflow so far? If so, what did you try and what happened?

[USER]
No I have no real desire to bring any AI tools into my own workflow

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
It has made it a bit harder to trust my newer coworkers as theres no way for me to know how competent someone is anymore

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent moment with a newer coworker when you werenâ€™t sure what they could handle on their own? What happened?

[USER]
We had a newer hire come in from a different department and he was just a junior technician so we weren't really worried even if he wasn't super knowledgeable the things we would have to help him with wouldn't be major but we were very wrong as three days into his tenure he got phished and we had to completely reboot all our servers

[ASSISTANT]
When that happened, how did it change the way you and the team interacted with him in the days that followed?

[USER]
Initially we were all a bit frustrated but recognized its not his fault he was thrust here and also wasn't properly taught protocols as he was sort of rushed into the role

[ASSISTANT]
After that, did you change anything about how you coordinate or review each otherâ€™s work?

[USER]
For the junior technicians we did a sort of senior buddy system where they'd have to check everything you did and when they trusted you enough we'd give them a bit of a longer leash

[ASSISTANT]
After the chatbot episode, did anything shift in how you talk with management or how much they listen when you raise concerns?

[USER]
No, I think my team has too much contempt for management for any promising discussions. We basically only talk to them when we have to.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Anything to do with sensitive details, I already dont trust companies with them in general given how poor most security is and how little they seem to care about data management

[ASSISTANT]
Can you share a specific type of sensitive task you handle, and what risks you see if an AI took that on?

[USER]
Yeah when onboarding new employees we handle all the information to store on our servers and sanitize it/password protect it once its there and I wouldn't ever trust AI with any form of sensitive information

[ASSISTANT]
Why is keeping that onboarding and data handling work in your own hands important to you?

[USER]
If any of that data got out it could be used/abused by bad actors to harm those who trusted us with it

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over that onboarding and data handling, how do you think it would change your role on the team or the way teammates rely on you?

[USER]
I think me and my teammates would both think less of management to a point we don't view them as capable

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I cannot think of any, I don't trust AI to do anything of importance and theres no task I do that I don't deem important in some capacity otherwise I wouldnt be doing it

[ASSISTANT]
What, if anything, would need to be true for you to feel okay handing even a small, lowâ€‘risk piece of your work to a system like that?

[USER]
I think there would need to be alot of safeguards/redunancies in place for me to feel comfortable deferring any work to an AI system.

[ASSISTANT]
What kinds of safeguards or redundancies would matter most to you before youâ€™d trust a system with even a tiny piece of work?

[USER]
Basically before AI acts in any capacity someone would be babysitting it checking every decision it makes etc

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
At this point autonomy in our field is management or those above you trusting you to do what you were hired to do, maybe not with complete impunity but without constant micromanagement

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from your job of what that trust looks like in practice? For instance, a time when you felt you were left to handle something without being hovered over.

[USER]
Yeah we had a big client migrating their business to our company and we had to transfer all their  previous data to our systems and my boss used to insist on doing this himself and then about a year or so ago started deferring the bigger projects to me and my team and would usually still hover around making sure we didn't mess up, but with this client he trusted us to complete this migration all on our own and it felt pretty big for us.

[ASSISTANT]
In that migration, what were the key calls you and your team made without needing signâ€‘off, and how did those choices shape the outcome?

[USER]
It wasn't about any specific calls it was moreso that he trusted us to get the little things right.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me one of those little things you handled during that migration and what difference it made in the end?

[USER]
Yeah usually when a client comes to us from another company we like to take them out to dinner and the liason is usually my boss but instead this time he sent me and I looked into the clients background and found out he was korean and decided to take him out to korean bbq and it went over really well.

[ASSISTANT]
If a new hire asked you how to earn that kind of trust from a supervisor in their first few months, what would you tell them to do?

[USER]
Do your job, if you're ever confused ask questions. It is far better to ask questions than to go in blind and hope you'll figure out.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t covered?

[USER]
Nope, I think I've said my peace

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a recent coding task where you used it, step by step?

[USER]
yep! I recently had to write an automated test for a new feature we were building. I wrote out the steps, gave copilot access to the code files, then asked it to write the test with those steps in cypress. then I ran the test, fixed the errors, created a pull request

[ASSISTANT]
In that example, which parts did it handle, and which parts did you do yourself?

[USER]
it handled creating the outline of the test and writing out the cypress steps, I handled running it/testing it/fixing it

[ASSISTANT]
Did it make any mistakes in that test, and if so, what did you run into?

[USER]
yes, it used some methods that didn't exist, and I had to change some variable names that weren't descriptive enough

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I was pretty mad that it basically made up cypress functions that didn't exist, but also I understand that ai isn't perfect

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
it did make it a lot easier to get started and I didn't have to look up syntax

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I wrote more tests

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
it feels like a mixture of both

[ASSISTANT]
When you use it on a highâ€‘stakes change, does it leave you feeling more confident in the result or less, and what drives that reaction?

[USER]
I think it makes me a little more nervous, since it might not have the context it needs to not break other things

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
my relationships with coworkers/

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
being able to visually confirm that nothing is broken

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I would still probably be double checking, as well as doing the rest of my job

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]
probably not

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I would probably to a check, as well as remove words that maybe I wouldn't normally use

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I would ask it to create a boiler plate code file, then I could fill in the functions/methods with the code. then you dont have to do the monotonous part

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
when its running into errors, repeating itself, etc.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I recently asked it to fix my test, but it ended up re-arranging it all and adding comments EVERYWHERE. I removed the comments, they were unnecessary and just added more lines that didn't need to be there.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I think ai is doing great, but we need to make sure it still has human supervision!

[USER]
that's all!

Interview 59
Username: 6786d5ddfc32db55097ed259
Date: 12/12/2025 19:12:24
Duration: 40.23 minutes
--------------------

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I'm a programmer/analyst

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks. Could you tell me a bit about what your work looks like day to day, for example the kinds of projects you take on or what a typical day involves?

[USER]
My daily tasks vary; I work with student data for a large school district, so I deal with all kinds of data-related issues. I do a bit of work with SQL and Crystal, for creating custom reports.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Pleasant work environment--low stress, conducive to productivity, amiable co-workers and supervisors, etc. Tasks that though challenging are rewarding and promote a sense of purpose.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about a lowâ€‘stress environment in practice, what does that look like day to day in your workplace?

[USER]
I work in a suite with 10 others, but we all have our own space, we all get along, and and collaborate when necessary. It's quiet, comfortable, and allows me to work in peace.

[ASSISTANT]
When a task feels challenging in a good way for you, what about it makes it feel worthwhile or gives you that sense of purpose?

[USER]
I like to know that when I've successfully completed a challenging task that the outcome is useful and/or helpful to someone or a number of people. Since I work with student data, it's a good feeling to know that I am ultimately helping administrators make decisions for the benefit of students.

[ASSISTANT]
Of everything youâ€™ve mentioned so far, what feels absolutely nonâ€‘negotiable for you in a good job?

[USER]
Reasonable work load in a low-pressure environment.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
As of right now, it's fairly minimal. We have no official AI implementation in our company and I don't know of plans to go that route.

[ASSISTANT]
Got it. Have you personally tried using any AI tools, even informally, on any of your tasks like SQL, Crystal reports, or data cleanup? If so, can you tell me about the last time?

[USER]
Yes, I use AI a few times a week to ask general information or to help me work through a coding question. It depends on the nature of the inquiry though because I work with seasoned programmers whose knowledge is vast.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a recent time you used it for a coding question, step by step from what you asked to what you ended up doing?

[USER]
I can't recall a specific example at the moment; I'd have to look through my history to see if something is there worth mentioning.

[ASSISTANT]
No problem. When you ask a coding question in general, what do you usually put into the prompt, and what do you do with the response once you get it?

[USER]
I only general questions about how to formulate a query since the specifics depend on the information in our databases. Unrelated to SQL, I have had AI assist with a powershell script that to assist me with filtering out certain platforms when I run system updates.

[ASSISTANT]
In that PowerShell script example for filtering platforms during updates, which parts did the tool generate, and what did you end up changing or adding yourself?

[USER]
AI generated the majority of the script since my powershell knowledge is pretty basic.

[ASSISTANT]
When you got that script back, how did you test it and what, if anything, did you tweak before putting it into use?

[USER]
I ran the first iteration and it returned a couple of errors, so I fed those errors to the bot and it modified the script. A couple of more rounds of small tweaks and it got to where it was doing what I wanted, so I was pleased with it.

[ASSISTANT]
As you were going back and forth fixing those errors, what went through your mind about the toolâ€™s suggestions and your own role in steering it?

[USER]
I was pretty impressed with its ability to problem solve in this particular case. I've given it other coding prompts related to web coding, and that was a mess. While it did ok with basics, for some reason more complex instructions proved to be a revolving door of fixes and errors.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about one time the web coding help went off the rails and what you did to resolve it or decide to stop?

[USER]
I was building a simple web page/site just for fun (not to be publically visible) partly to test the bot's ability to code. I can do simple HTML and CSS, but wanted to see how efficitient it could be. Basics were fine, but more complex CSS really proved to be troublesome. After a few hours of going in circles, I abandoned the project because it was more work--even with AI--than I wanted to invest in a small side project.

[ASSISTANT]
How did getting that PowerShell task done with the tool compare to how you would have handled it before you had access to it?

[USER]
It drastically reduced the amount of time I would have needed to write it all myself. I could have figured it out eventually, but this was a matter of minutes; it would have probably taken me a few hours to get it the way it ultimately came out.

[ASSISTANT]
When you hit a snag, how do you decide whether to ask an AI tool, look through documentation, or turn to one of the seasoned programmers on your team?

[USER]
It depends on what I'm trying to do. For simple queries, I just look through some tutorials or documentation to figure it out; sometimes I'll ask a bot. If it's more complex and I need to know specifics about data the bot doesn't have access to, I'll ask a coworker.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
Interpersonally you mean?

[ASSISTANT]
Yes, with colleagues, managers, or clients. Since you started using these tools, have your interactions with any of them changed in any noticeable way?

[USER]
Not at all

[ASSISTANT]
Do you and your coworkers ever talk about these tools at all, even casually, or is it mostly something you use on your own?

[USER]
It's on my own; I don't recall AI ever coming up in our coding discussions. These guys are seasonsed programming professionals and I would venture to say they have ZERO interest/need in using AI for anything coding related, at least in SQL.

[ASSISTANT]
Have you noticed any shift in what your manager expects from you in terms of speed or output since you started using these tools, or has that stayed the same?

[USER]
No, because using AI has never been discussed with us. For SQL, since AI doesn't have access to our databases, there is probably little concern for management about us using it. Since I am by far the most junior programmer here, I'm surely the only one using it for actual work-related tasks, so it's probably not an issue. I NEVER input even as much as a table name from our database when I ask AI about coding, so I think I'm ok.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
The only thing I would be willing to allow AI to do would be to scan my daily data reports and report to me what issues need to be fixed in the system. I would be hesitant though because those reports contain student PII.

[ASSISTANT]
What is one part of your job you would want to keep doing yourself, even if a tool could do it perfectly?

[USER]
The actual management of student data in our SIS. It's 90% interacting with a GUI, so I don't know how AI would tackle that, but that's the majority of my job, so I wouldn't want to put myself out of work.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes doing that handsâ€‘on data work something you want to keep in your own hands?

[USER]
One upside to AI is efficiency; however, I would feel more comfortable, at least initially, if I could see myself the data I'm altering, inputting, etc. I feel more confident if I know I did the task myself.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Scanning data reports

[ASSISTANT]
Why would you like to give up scanning data reports?

[USER]
It's tedious and pretty boring--it's poring over thousands of rows on a spreadsheet looking for anomolies.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI were to scan those reports for you, what safeguards or conditions would you need in place to feel comfortable given the student PII?

[USER]
Preferably that the scanned data is not networked in any way. That's probably unrealistic, but ideally the bot would be hosted locally on-site and all traffic would be internal--no internet-facing connections.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
That my work is my work and not that of someone else or a bot. I think AI is promising in a lot of ways, but I don't want AI to displace people for positions where the personal component of work is removed. Some tasks are perfectly suited for AI, but though I manage data, I also communicate that data to other people and I want them to know I did the work and did it well. Autonomy would, in part, be a lack of dependence on AI to accomplish quality work.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example from the past few months when you made a decision or built something where you could say, this was my work and not the toolâ€™s? What did that look like in practice?

[USER]
I built a query recently that was the basis of a custom report for a district administrator. It was more complext than what I normally do so I had to get a coworker to guide me through a part of it, but at the end, I was happy with it and proud of it actually. It was clean, efficient, and made for a good report. I worked out the details, with guidance from my co-worker, and it was exactly what was requested, so that was very satisfying.

[ASSISTANT]
In that report query, what were the parts you decided and owned yourself, and what did your coworker specifically help you with?

[USER]
He helpe me with a subquery that was necessary to pull a specific bit of data that would have taken much more work to do differently. I was a little stuck, so he showed me how to accomplish what I needed in a simpler way.

[ASSISTANT]
If that young person asked how to balance using these tools sometimes and still have the work be recognizably theirs, what concrete habits or guardrails would you suggest?

[USER]
I would probably say that use tools to help you when necessary--that's what tools are for. AI is a tool, but it can be more than that if let it, and I mean in a negative way. Yes, bots can code, but you the programmer have to know the language well enough to see what the bots might be doing incorrectly or inefficiently. They're assitants.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for sharing all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t touched on?

[USER]
I think I've covered the gist of it.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you very much for your answers! Looking back at this interview, how well does it summarize how experience of AI is changing and might change your work: 1 (it describes poorly how AI might change my work), 2 (it partially describes how AI might change my work), 3 (it describes well how AI might change my work), 4 (it describes very well how AI might change my work). Please only reply with the associated number.

[USER]
3

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for taking the time to share your experiences today. Your insights were very helpful, and I appreciate the thoughtful examples you provided. If anything else comes to mind later, feel free to reach out.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI has greatly improved the speed and efficiency of my work.  It takes care of the tedious tasks, such as log checks, simple troubleshooting procedures, and script writing, so I can concentrate on the more difficult issues.  Additionally, it assists me in identifying problems before they become serious, such as reporting strange network patterns.  Although it doesn't take the place of the job, it does make my day easier and free up my time for tasks that genuinely require human intelligence.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about the last time you used it to write a script. What did it do, and what did you do?

[USER]
A few weeks ago was the last time I used AI for a script.  To extract system logs from a group of machines and arrange them according to error level, I needed a short PowerShell script.  The AI produced a clean base script in a matter of seconds after I told it what I needed.  Adding a few filters, changing the output format, and ensuring that it worked well with our network configuration were all part of my tweaking.  I tightened the skeleton provided by the AI to make it function as we required.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Yes, it wasn't flawless.  It didn't format the output precisely as I wanted and overlooked a few edge cases, such as handling offline machines.  I discovered it by first executing the script in a test environment.  I then modified the output formatting and added error handling for offline machines.  AI provided me with a strong foundation, but I still needed to prepare it for production.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
To be honest, I thought, "Yep, figures," at first.  AI comes close, but you still need to monitor it.  I simply went into problem-solving mode instead of being irritated.  I made sure it wouldn't choke in the actual environment, checked where it broke, and filled in the gaps.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I used the extra time to troubleshoot a tricky network issue that needed hands-on attention.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

I now spend more time fixing actual problems rather than looking for them because the tools identify problems early and expedite the tedious labor.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am a QA Tester

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
i'd say a good job provides a comfortable life for the worker and their family as well as alowing freedom from the job to enjoy said life. Work/life balance and fair compensation are important in what I would consider a good job.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a comfortable life, what does that look like for you day to day?

[USER]
I'd say all basic needs are met,t and there is no stress over food or gas or things like that. Plus some spare capital to have fun with here and there, go out to eat, go on vacation etc.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about freedom from the job to enjoy life, what would your ideal schedule or boundaries look like?

[USER]
Ideally, I'd like to see us get to a point where 3 days full-time, or 24 hours, is the new 40 hours and anything over would be considered overtime.  So 3 days on, 4 days off a week.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say fair compensation, how do you judge whatâ€™s fair in your field?

[USER]
I'd say fair would be in line with the average or above in my area, compared to others who do the same or similar job.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I work with AI some to provide scripts that I need for testing. I also work to help train AI models

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used it to generate a test script, step by step?

[USER]
I can't give specifis per NDA but I needed some a python script to automate UI testing using Selenium

[ASSISTANT]
In that Selenium example, which parts did the AI draft and which parts did you handle yourself?

[USER]
I established the test cases and used AI to draft a few scripts for parts that would be better served being autmated

[ASSISTANT]
What kinds of changes did you make to the AIâ€‘drafted Selenium scripts before you felt comfortable running them?

[USER]
Now that I think about it, I did need to adjust the page locators for the scripts to run properly. But otherwise it was good

[ASSISTANT]
When you realized the locators needed adjustment, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
INot much becasue I kind of expected that to heppen becaause the site changes often. It was no big deal

[ASSISTANT]
About how much time did using it save you on that Selenium task, compared to writing the script yourself?

[USER]
I'd say probably 30+%

[ASSISTANT]
After using those AIâ€‘drafted scripts, how did you gauge whether you could trust them before running them in your full test run?

[USER]
I did a few small tests runs first

[ASSISTANT]
During those small test runs, what were you watching for, and what stood out to you that told you it was safe to roll into the full run?

[USER]
It was just a matter if the test completed or not. If the python code produced runs fine, then theres not much else I need since these are typically small segmented test scripts

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned helping to train models. What does your part in that process look like, step by step?

[USER]
it typically involves sxs comparison of two models' results to a user query, in which I have to determine based on several factors and guidlines, which of the two model respones is better, then include proper data annotation and reasoning

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re deciding which of the two model responses is better, what are the main things you look for?

[USER]
comprehensiveness, factuality, backstory guidelines are probably the main ones

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re doing that sideâ€‘byâ€‘side judging, what is the experience like for you in the momentâ€”whatâ€™s the mental effort or pace feel like as you work through a batch?

[USER]
depends on the subject matter. Some model responses can require extensive research for verification, and if it is a subject matter I don't care for, it just makes it more taxing for me. The pace overall is steady, but sometimes the brain power used can be a lot, and it can be pretty draining.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about your QA work overall, has using AI changed the way you plan or sequence your testing work in a typical week?

[USER]
I'd say not really at this time

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I don't think it really has. There are people I've worked with before AI was everywhere and our relationships are still the same

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
For QA, not really. Eventually, most of the process will be automated and run by AI; it just makes sense economically and for efficiency purposes. For AI model training, I would absolutely never want to hand that job over to AI, as that would just mean AI was training itself, which is not a feedback loop that would prove beneficial in my (and most people's) opinion.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes human oversight in model training essential, in your view?

[USER]
Models can have hallucinations and issues with factuality, which if left unchecked, could potentially cause issues with models that are trained from said model and vice versa.  Plus humans are the ones using AI so they should never be taken out of the picture completely.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over most of the judging and feedback in model training, how do you think that would change your role on the team or your relationships with others?

[USER]
I wouldn't have any work for that particular team anymore, and so my contract would be cancelled, and I wouldn't have much working relationship with them anymore.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I can't really think of anything that I would give over fully to AI but more augmentation with bug/issue report generation to speed up the process if possible

[ASSISTANT]
What makes bug or issue report generation a good fit for AI to help with in your workflow?

[USER]
Sometimes bug reports can feel repetitive if there are a lot of them and it would be nice if those could be produced with less action from the tester

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I'd say autonomy is when you are given the freedom to do your job how you see fit. You're still going to have a boss and people you have to answer to, but when it comes down to doing your work, you are the one who decides how to go about it.  A quick example in my mind for a young person would be to think of a fast-food worker. If you were a fast food worker and a customer asked for a refund, would you be able to provide the refund? Or would you have to get a manager/higher up to do it? If you can provide the refund without the manager, you have autonomy at that job. If you are required to get a manager, you do not have autonomy.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from your QA work where you had that kind of discretion to decide how to do the job?

[USER]
We often do exploratory testing, and while there are best practices, it's essentially up to the testers how to proceed with the testing itself.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about a recent exploratory session when you chose your own path through the product. What choices did you make in the moment, and what told you those were the right moves?

[USER]
I try to follow paths that a typical customer/user would take, as well as paths I would take if I were a customer/user myself.  I don't know for sure if they're the right moves or not, it's kind of just a gut feeling, and I try not to overthink it because you never know what a customer/user might do so there's really no bad exploratory testing .

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through one specific time when your own path in exploratory testing led you to uncover a real issueâ€”what you clicked first, what you tried next, and how you captured and reported it?

[USER]
I was testing a sports streaming app. I'd followed a happy path from Home to a particular streaming video. After that was successful, I just delved deeper into the affiliated paths from said streaming video and found an issue with an associated "similar" video recommendation, which was then captured via screen recording, and a bug report was filed with video and annotation regarding the issue.

[ASSISTANT]
In practice, what kinds of constraints shape how much freedom you have on a given project?

[USER]
Namely time.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t covered?

[USER]
Not that I can think of at the moment. Do you think AI will take all of our jobs in a few years like some people are saying?

[ASSISTANT]
I hear the concern, and there are lots of views on that, but for today Iâ€™ll stick to your experience. Thank you again for sharing it.

Thank you very much for your answers! [USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

Interview 73
Username: 6659e5dd37d39ea5bd9a99ad

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I was a QA for software products but recently beginning to do website and app development

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Not too far of a commute, good coworkers, fair boss, good pay, must be a good fit for the resume because I am always thinking of the future not just the current day.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about good coworkers, what does that look like day to day in how people act or work together?

[USER]
A good coworker to me is someone personable that also gets their job done, and does not try to step ontop of you to climb the corporate ladder or gain benefits with anyone else. So someone who is generally kind who actually would like to get to know you and is easy to work with.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a fair boss, what makes that fair in your experience?

[USER]
A fair boss cares about you to some degree outside of work or how you are doing in life. Is not shy to do a performance review or avoid it like some people have before. Smart and encouraging/powerful presence. But not powerful in an intimidating way, but a leader everyone looks up to.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a good fit for your resume, what does that mean in practice for the kinds of roles or projects you take on?

[USER]
When I say a good fit for my resume I mean when I go to a job im not looking to spend the rest of my career there, but It will be a building block in my life if that makes sense.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI impacts my work greatly, as I am 24 and trying to work in the world of software engineering, where AI tools are taking over.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent task where you used an AI tool in your development or QA work? What did you use it for?

[USER]
I used AI to help me write unit tests for automated QA testing in javascript. We use AI tools like codex and copilot to help build apps, and AI site builders like bolt to build websites via "vibe coding".

[ASSISTANT]
In that unit test example, which parts did the AI produce, and which parts did you handle yourself?

[USER]
At the beginning I started by reading documentation on Javascript, and then had the AI write unit tests based off what I wanted it to do. The unit tests were very "fluffed" and had a lot of code that was unnecessary. I began to write them myself and I reduced the lines of code in a unit test by around 5x.

[ASSISTANT]
What went through your mind when you saw those AI-written tests were padded with extra code?

[USER]
I didnt think much of it but my engineering lead saw this in a code review and then told me that it is very poor and not efficient. I learned how to write it better and then told the AI to write further tests like I have, and from there it worked fine for the most part.

[ASSISTANT]
In that code review moment, what stood out to you about your leadâ€™s feedback, and how did you react right then?

[USER]
He could tell clearly that I was using AI to write my tests, and I was embarrassed. He was asking me like "What selectors did you use"? and I had no idea what this was. Being embarassed led me to write my own and redeem myself in a way lol.

[ASSISTANT]
After you rewrote them and then had the AI follow your pattern, how did the quality and speed compare to doing it all yourself?

[USER]
It was about the same because I knew what the proper syntax would look like and sometimes it would try to add something other than queryselector, and I woudl have to guide the AI to do the right thing. The scripts it wrote were fine I just had to proofread and reprompt sometimes.

[ASSISTANT]
Could you walk me through a recent time you used one of those AI site builders like Bolt to do â€œvibe codingâ€? What did it actually generate, and what parts did you step in to change or add yourself?

[USER]
Yeah so I get the concept from my boss and then I take it into bolt which has a window similar to this and you tell it with a decent amount of detail so it doesnt fill it with its own ideas. It will generate a website based off your initial prompt. Frontend and backend. From there you just use the terminal to tweak and add things that you need. You can switch from frontend like browser view to code view and edit code yourself or add new files whatever you need to do. It generated essentially the whole website I just guide it.

[ASSISTANT]
When Boltâ€™s first pass gives you a site, what tends to be off or not quite right, and how do you handle those fixes?

[USER]
You just need to add as much context to the AI as possible but yeah it takes probably 10 "revisions" or for apps "builds" to get to a completed product

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to building a site without Bolt, how does the overall timeline change for you from brief to handoff?

[USER]
It reduces the time greatly. like 5x

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re guiding Bolt through those rounds of revisions, what does that work feel like to you in the moment?

[USER]
It feels nice to be working towards a nice finished product for my boss and I know he will like it but it doesnt feel right as an aspiring software engineer

[ASSISTANT]
What about that doesnâ€™t feel right to you as someone building your skills â€” what goes through your mind in those moments when youâ€™re mostly guiding rather than writing the code yourself?

[USER]
It feels like I am cheating my way through it, but at the same time it feels like I am following latest tech trends and the future will definitely involve AI so I try not to feel so bad about it. I like C++ which is a lower level and difficult language, so doing websites with AI just feels wrong sometimes. Like my job will be replaced eventually.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
Has been fine, its been a bit annoying lately since everyone at my company is so "AI Positive" and management is trying to get people who do accounting to start vibe coding websites lol. makes me feel some type of way.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned management encouraging folks in accounting to start vibe coding websites. How does that affect your sense of your role or standing on the team?

[USER]
Makes me feel not needed and like all my knowledge up to this point is squandered because they see accounting to be able to do the old job of a software developer

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a specific conversation or meeting where this came up and how people responded?

[USER]
My boss brings up having people who are not technical at all to vibe code websites. Even my coworker who recently got into game development told my boss that and he said you are wasting your time trying to learn how to write code these days.

[ASSISTANT]
What was your gut response in that moment when your boss said learning to write code was a waste of time?

[USER]
I felt like he was not entirely correct and I still feel that way. it is useful to know how to write maintainable, modular, scalable code and know good software practices. Vibe coding can definitely lead to writing bad code especially if you dont unserstand what is going on at all behind the scenes...

[ASSISTANT]
Hearing all that, has this changed how you collaborate with teammates day to day, for example how you ask for help or how people respond in code reviews?

[USER]
Yeah my engineering lead is oldschool like know how to code and write clean efficient code and my boss is more vibe coding sided so I tend to go more in depth with my engineering lead to try and show him that I am not trying to vibe code my way thru things

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Hopefully not app development. Websites are a lost cause but I enjoy creating apps with swift in visual studio and copilot.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes building apps something you want to keep doing yourself rather than handing it over?

[USER]
It makes me feel like an engineer. The levels of abstraction in terms of software for "vibe coding" tools for app development is not far along as websites. At this point you can just vibe code a website in minutes but tech has not gotten there yet for apps so I get to build and work out bugs errors handle database integration etc.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI could take over app building and do it flawlessly, how do you think that would change your role on the team or your relationships with your teammates?

[USER]
I would have to move into product management or keep my job as an engineer but utilize AI tools

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Qa for boring software products

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
QA for boring business intelligence software is not fun. So let the AI do it. It is monotonous and not enjoyable. I am trying to become an engineer not a QA perosn.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
No beacuse I no longer work doing QA stuff so that would not be my problem

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
To have autonomy in your job SHOULD be a means to help you, but most times autonomy will end up hurting you to save whoever is at the top more $.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
I can see two ways someone might understand what you said â€” that itâ€™s about having room to decide how you do the work, or that itâ€™s about companies using tools to shrink teams while piling more on each person. Which of these fits what you mean, or is it something else?

[USER]
The latter explanation

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
