Interview 77
Username: 60a9610cae689e66af400f01
Date: 12/12/2025 18:56:28
Duration: 74.89 minutes
--------------------

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
Hello there. 

Sure, let me tell you a bit about myself and what I do for work. I am a Software Engineer for almost 4 years now. My work involves developing and maintaining software applications. Based on the topic, I think AI definitely has an impact on the work that I do today.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
I think the characteristics will involve a good work/life balance. This means that you get to work at a reasonable time that works for you (e.g. have the ability to start early and finish early or start late and finish late). There is also flexibility in terms of how you work and where you work so that means being able to work from home as well as the office (a hybrid style of working). From the job itself, I think the other characteristics would involve having a good team around you and they are able to support you when you need them to. The job itself should also be stable in terms of having a solid structure that doesn't have a high employee turnover which indicates stability. I also think it's important to think about the benefits of working, this means a strong competitive salary for the job that you are doing as well as additional employee benefits like a company bonus which motivates you to work hard in the role too.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for laying that out. Of the things you mentioned, which two or three matter most to you day to day, and why?

[USER]
I think the number one thing that matters to me the most is the flexibility of when I work and where I work. This is important because it gives me the option to adjust my working hours whenever I feel like and I can work remotely and from the office based on my own choices. Of course, I would still need to attend the office however I get to choose what days to attend which is important so that it gives me flexibility to adjust based on my schedule out of work too.

The second thing I would say is a very supportive environment where I can get the support from others whenever I need it the most. I think this is important because it allows me to feel confident in the role that I am doing and allows me to communicate openly with others in the team. I would feel more comfortable working in a place where I can get guidance on how I am doing as well as get the feedback that I need in order to improve myself.

[ASSISTANT]
Earlier you mentioned stability and pay â€” what do those mean to you in practice?

[USER]
Stability means the job is stable, the team structure doesn't change very often. There isn't a lot of employee turnover which suggests people like to stay in the company for longer. Pay is important because it's probably the biggest factor in why I am working in the company in the first place. If the pay isn't competitive then it's highly likely that I would look for a new role in a different place where the salary expectations meets my needs based on the role that I am doing.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I think AI has definitely impacted my work a lot. From a software development perspective, I can say that AI is now fully integrated into most of our development environments where we perform coding for example GitHub Copilot is now heavily used as part of the development to help us be more productive and get things done faster. It's easier to use AI to help with mundane or repetitive tasks and I think it helps get things done faster since you can easily troubleshoot problems when it comes to coding. It has also helped me to write emails faster as well so there's definitely a lot of ways that I have been using AI without realising it.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent coding task where you used Copilot? What were you trying to build or fix?

[USER]
A recent coding task where I used Copilot is writing unit tests. This was a repetitive task and I wanted some help to identify edge cases that I may have missed. Copilot was used to help me speed up the process, I simply told it to continue from my existing unit tests and it helped me to brainstorm additional tests that I did not consider.

[ASSISTANT]
In that unit test example, which parts did Copilot generate, and which parts did you write or change yourself?

[USER]
Copilot had generated the initial test scaffolding structure and edge cases. However, I did not trust it blindly and verified what Copilot had suggested. I refined it so that it only makes sense in the application context. This means that I made sure that the tests covered the right behaviour and not just what Copilot had assumed. There is something called context which you can provide to Copilot which helps it understand what kind of things it needs to work on however this isn't always accurate so I needed to check it myself as well.

[ASSISTANT]
Did Copilot make any mistakes in that session, and what did you do when you spotted them?

[USER]
One behaviour that I did notice is that it sometimes duplicated the same tests or wrote them that were not meaningful. I deleted redundant tests and kept only the ones that added value because Copilot doesn't know the business rules so it needed some guidance on filling those details.

[ASSISTANT]
When you were reviewing and pruning those tests, what went through your mind in the moment?

[USER]
Whenever I review Copilot's code, I made sure that to double check the output was correct. I also thought about our team's style and conventions. This means I had to check that it was consistent with our existing codebase.

[ASSISTANT]
How did doing those tests with Copilot change the time it took and the flow of your work compared to how you handled tests before?

[USER]
It made my time much more productive. I didn't need to spend time typing since Copilot handled most of the initial boilerplate and test suggestions. I spent the time instead with refining what the output was. Overall, it made me more focused and I didn't feel burned out during the process since I didn't need to put a lot of energy into it.

[ASSISTANT]
Has there been a time when using AI noticeably changed the outcome of a piece of work for you, for better or worse? Can you walk me through what happened?

[USER]
I think at the very beginning when AI was just introduced, I was still trying get familiar with it. At that time, AI was still using older models that weren't very good and I had doubts about it because there wasn't any options like providing it with context so I wasn't even sure if it was able to understand exactly what it was working with. The output could sometimes work and other times not work. What I mean is that it would sometimes provide suggestions and when I tried those suggestions, it wouldn't work because the AI just made it up and that doesn't actually exist if that makes sense.

[ASSISTANT]
When it gave you suggestions that didnâ€™t actually exist, what was your gut response, and how did you handle it in the moment?

[USER]
When it didn't work, I would simply Google it to see exactly if it existed. When I realised that it didn't, then I just shrugged it off as it's AI and it can get things right or wrong. I didn't give up with AI, I still used it whenever I needed to. These moments just makes me realise that AI still can get things wrong and I shouldn't just rely it on all the time but try to diversify where I get help from.

[ASSISTANT]
When you save time using AI on tasks like tests, what do you typically do with that time?

[USER]
It allows me to focus on other things like use the time for personal development and upskilling. I can also use it to help others if they are struggling with any of their tasks. It also allows me to perform other activities on the side like reading and responding to emails, messages etc. It saves me time to do other things that normally would need to be kept on hold until I had got my task done.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I don't think AI has affected my working relationships in any way. The only thing that I can thing of is that our workplace allows the use of AI. It's now integrated as part of our development environment so AI usage is encouraged. I think it helps us to get things done faster and helps us come up with more innovative solutions that we might not have known about before. Overall, it's just more productive and if we were not to use it then we would simply be at a disadvantage.

[ASSISTANT]
In code reviews, have you noticed any shifts in how teammates give feedback when AI had a hand in the code?

[USER]
Code reviews have remained the same. The only thing different is that AI is now part of the code review process, it is used to do a sense check and may ask questions or raise things if it sees "clear" mistakes or issues in the written code. This helps a real person also judge the code as well because they would see the AI comments and then allows them to make up their own judgement. Basically, AI now helps us get more insight into the written code and it's basically a much more stronger way to ensure that our code is correct and does what it needs to do.

[ASSISTANT]
Has your managerâ€™s expectations around speed or scope changed since your team started using AI?

[USER]
No, I don't think expectations around speed or scope have changed since the introduction of AI. It's still the same. AI is there just for us to get things done. Now whether it's making us more productive or not, the speed or scope hasn't changed. We haven't reached a stage where AI is dominating the field yet so the expectation is that we still work at normal speed.

[ASSISTANT]
Have there been any moments where using AI changed how you collaborate with a teammate, like during pairing or handoffs? Tell me about one.

[USER]
Yes, I have had lots of collaboration with team mates. One example is when we are struggling to understand how to get something done, it might be something simple or complex. We might look at Google to find a solution but if we aren't able to get anywhere then we are encouraged to use AI if it helps us progress and get somewhere. I think by reaching out to AI, there has been a few times where it has helped us get the answer what we were looking for as long as we provide the relevant context. For example, we were working with an unfamiliar file extension that required a specific syntax tag. We didn't know what the tag was so we used AI to troubleshoot the issue and eventually figured it out.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future. Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if it could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I think the coding aspect is still something that I enjoy doing. I wouldn't want to hand it over to an AI even if it could do it perfectly because then our roles as a software developer would definitely be at a risk. I like to use AI to help me write code from time to time as well because it gives me multiple approaches on how to tackle a problem and it's always interesting to see what ways I could have solved it.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is doing the coding yourself something you want to keep, specifically in relation to how AI is used on your team?

[USER]
Coding is something that I have always enjoyed. I just like to solving problems that require a lot of thinking and thought process behind it. It's like being an architect where you get to choose exactly how your code behaves. Plus, I think if I were to hand it over to an AI then I would definitely lose my coding skills. It's clear that if you don't practice something in the long term then you will eventually lose the skill so I think keeping myself refreshing in code just benefits me since I will be able to retain those skills instead of losing them.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI did most of the coding on your team, how do you think that would change your relationships with teammates or your role on the team?

[USER]
If AI did all of the coding then I think it would definitely change how the team works. Probably more expectations to ensure the AI is completing the work and the scope and speed will be increased. I also think non technical people will start to think that we don't do much at work and probably will think of letting some of us go since AI is doing most of the work. I would definitely think my role will be limited and I would eventually lose it since I wouldn't have a lot of responsibility left if AI took over.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I want AI to be my personal assistant. Basically I would really love it if it could handle all the boring stuff for me that I don't like doing. Maybe respond to messages, emails, schedule meetings so that I literally can simply focus on doing my actual job rather than the boring stuff that I don't like doing. I tend to think that writing emails, responding to messages does take time so if AI could handle all of that then it would definitely make me more productive and get things done since I don't need to worry about any of those.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes those communications the right fit for AI, compared to other parts of your job?

[USER]
These communications are usually just responding to people's messages and sometimes emails. It wouldn't be anything overly complex however if it were then I would simply take over from the AI. Other parts of my job might be mentoring junior developers, and I don't think AI will be able to help as much as I can because that probably requires more context around our existing application estate and how we work which the AI wouldn't really know about.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over your emails and messages, do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
Probably, because AI speaks in a very AI standard way. I think it would definitely make the human interaction feel robotic however I do hope there is a way to add "personality" to our AI assistant so that it can replicate exactly how my messages/emails are written. Perhaps, it can use my existing messages as a way to understand how it should communicate with other people (based on how I do it). In that case then nobody will ever be able to know whether it's an AI or myself!

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I still think we haven't reached the full use case of AI yet. This means we still have autonomy to work how we want to work. We have the option to use AI or not use it. But it's evident that using AI is much more productive and better in the long-term. There's simply a lot of things that you can learn with AI and you also learn to see solutions in a different way which you would not if you didn't use it. Autonomy for us is still to be able to complete tasks the way we want to do it. Unless that changes anytime soon, I would still say joining the field is still worth it and it will definitely take some time before we get to see the full use of AI.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from a typical day of what that looks like in practice â€” a moment when you decide how to tackle a task, with or without AI?

[USER]
I generally think about completing the task by myself first. I also think about what other things I need to get done today. If it's something that I feel that I want to get done quickly then I would probably think about using AI just to give me some time to get ideas and possibly find a solution. It just depends on how much my current workload is. If I feel overloaded then I am probably more likely to use it.

[ASSISTANT]
Think back to a recent task you deliberately kept AI out of. What was it, and what tipped the balance for you?

[USER]
I was working with confidential data that shouldn't be provided to an AI. I wanted to write an email with the help of AI however since the email would have confidential information this tipped me not to use AI at all. In the end, I didn't write the email with the help of AI and just used my own writing style to write it.

[ASSISTANT]
On a day with tight deadlines or strict guidelines, what room do you still have to make your own calls about how to do the work?

[USER]
We still have rooms on how to do the work. However, we do have a meeting scheduled so that everyone is clear on what the expectations are and when it is going to get completed when there are strict deadlines. However, I think these calls generally do take up some time so I sometimes do wonder if having shorter calls might be better so that we can spend the time to complete the work.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for walking me through all of that. Is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work before we wrap up?

[USER]
Sure, I can add that AI has definitely come a long way in the last few years. It seems that we are getting much more better and smarter AI models in our work now. These seem to be better at understanding the context and able to provide with more reliable results compared to what I've seen in the past. I am not sure exactly which way AI is headed next but would be interesting to see in the next few years on how it would impact our work and what kind of changes we would need to make in order to accommodate it.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. Do you feel weâ€™ve covered the important ways AI is affecting your work, or is there anything else you want to add before we finish?

[USER]
I think we've covered some good points and discussed how AI is affecting my work. From my side, I think I have mentioned all the points that I can think of. Is there anything else you want to ask?

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you very much for your answers! Looking back at this interview, how well does it summarize how experience of AI is changing and might change your work: 1 (it describes poorly how AI might change my work), 2 (it partially describes how AI might change my work), 3 (it describes well how AI might change my work), 4 (it describes very well how AI might change my work). Please only reply with the associated number.

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
When you say meaningful work, what makes it meaningful for you in practice?

[USER]
meaningful work should have purpose and impact.  I prefer work that contributes to make the company's goals more successful

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about opportunities for growth, what does that look like day to day for you?

[USER]

For me currently, growth includes the ability to learn new technologies, skills, languages, etc and not doing the same repetitive tasks year-over-year

[ASSISTANT]
When you think of a positive work environment, what stands out in your day to day?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a recent coding task where you used AI, step by step? What did you ask it to do, and what did you do yourself?

[USER]
I am working on a R&D project to introduce an development-time orchestration tool written by Microsoft called Aspire.  I have used generative AI to help think through ideas on how we could implement different parts of the tool and also have used it for troubleshooting when things failed to work after updates

[ASSISTANT]
In that troubleshooting after an update, what did you share with the AI, what did it give you back, and what did you end up changing in your code or config?

[USER]
I used Claude Code within my project, so it has direct access to the code without needing to copy/paste into a website.  When troubleshooting I usually try to give as much details as possible like urls to documentation, error messages, thoughts on what I believe might be the root cause of the issue.  

In the exact issue from my last troubleshooting session, it gave me multiple options on how to fix the error with pros and cons of each option.  I ended up selecting the preferred option it gave and it went and modified the code for me directly

[ASSISTANT]
When it offered multiple options and then changed the code itself, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
I like having multiple options when they are available, obviously that doesn't always happen.  The way claude code is setup, it asks for permissions before changing the code and I can always revert using my Git source control

[ASSISTANT]
In that session, did it make any mistakes or suggest anything you later rejected, and how did you handle that?

Interview 80
Username: 677249ee3a4f08a288a1f9fc
Date: 12/12/2025 18:53:40
Duration: 57.55 minutes

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am a software developer

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
in my view a good job is one that gives people a meaningful degree of autonomy, fair compensation and the ability to grow without being overwhelmed .

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a meaningful degree of autonomy, what does that look like for you in the day to day?

[USER]
a meaningful degree of autonomy according to me means having control over how i approach my work rather than simply executing tasks exactly as prescribed.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say fair compensation, what does fair look like to you in practice?

[USER]
it means being paid in line with the industry standards for my skills and experience with clear and transparent criteria for how pay is set. It also includes regular adjustments for inflation and maker changes and benefits that support a stable descent quality of life.

[ASSISTANT]
When you talk about the ability to grow without being overwhelmed, what does that look like for you?

[USER]
For me, growing without being overwhelmed means having opportunities to learn new skills or take on more responsibility, but at a pace thatâ€™s manageable. It looks like being given challenges that stretch me without constant pressure or unrealistic deadlines, and having support like mentorship, time to learn, or clear guidance when Iâ€™m moving into something new. Itâ€™s growth that feels steady and supported, not chaotic or exhausting.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
as a software dev, AI has started to shape my work in a few significant ways. On the positive side tools like code assistants help me move faster. They can generate boilerplate code, suggest solutions and help me catch bugs earlier which frees up time for more complex or creative problem solving. They are especially helpful when I'm exploring unfamiliar libraries or trying to understand legacy code. At the same time, AI can add new pressures like there's often an expectation to be more productive because these tools exists, or to constantly stay updated as they evolve.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used a code assistant on a specific task, step by step? What did you do, and what did it do?

[USER]
The last time I used a code assistant was when I needed to write a small data processing script. I started by typing out a rough description of what i wanted the function to do. The assistant immediately suggested a full function outline which gave me a descent starting point. I accepted part of it but changed a few details fit what I actually needed. Then I wrote a test, and the assistant filled in a couple of the assertions for me. When the tests fails, it suggested where the logic might be off which really helped me spot a small mistake faster. In the end, I still reviewed everything myself but it sped up the routine parts of the task

[ASSISTANT]
In that script example, did it make any mistakes or suggest something that didnâ€™t fit your context? What did you do when that happened?

[USER]
yes it did suggest a few things that didn't fit my context. For example, it used a data structure that wasn't appropriate for the data set I was working with. when that happened, I ignored its suggestion and rewrote that part myself. I treated its output more as s tarting point rather than something to rely on blindly.

[ASSISTANT]
When it helped you spot that small mistake, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
my first reaction was just a relief. I had been staring at the code a bit, so when it pointed out the likely issue, it felt like oh right it makes total sense kinda thing. It was a mix of appreciation that t caught something I missed and a little annoyance that i hadn't spottled it myself. Bu mostly it just felt helpful.

[ASSISTANT]
When you used it on that script, what did you do with the time you saved?

[USER]
I used the extra time to focus on testing and refining the script. Instead of getting stuck on the boilerplate code, i could double check edge cases, improve readability and make sure it actually worked with real data. It felt like I was using my time more on meaningful tasks rather than repetitive ones.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned new pressures to be more productive because these tools exist. How does that show up for you in the day to day?

[USER]
ammm day to day it shows up as this subtle expectations that I should be moving faster than before. If a task takes longer I sometimes catch myself thinking, shouldnt AI have made this quicker or wonder if others expect me to deliver more because I am using these tools. It's not always said out loud but it's always there in the back of your head and it feels kind of pressure to constantly be efficient and not fall behind.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re exploring an unfamiliar library, what parts do you let the tool draft, and what parts do you insist on doing yourself?

[USER]
when i am doing that, I usually let the tool draft boilerplate code, example usage or basic function templates. I also let it suggest common patterns or syntax I might not remember. But i insist on writing the core logic, handling the edge cases and deciding how.

[ASSISTANT]
How does using the assistant affect your confidence in the result?

[USER]
Using the assistant gives me mixed feelings about confidence. On on side, it helps catch simple mistakes so I feel a bit more reassured that I haven't overlooked something obvious. But on the other hand, I don't fully trust its suggestions, so I still double check everything myself. Overall, it boosts my confidence in small ways but doesn't replace my own judgment.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
Ai hasn't changed my relationships dramatically but it has shifted the vibe a little. There's a bit more talk about productivity and who uses which Tools and sometimes it feels like people compare themselves based on how efficient they are with the AI.  At the same time, it also related moments of collaboration sharing prompts, so i feel its a mix of mild pressure

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a specific interaction with a colleague around AI that stands out to you? What happened?

[USER]
sure. one interaction that stands out was when teammates asked me for help using a code assistant for the first time. They were struggling to get it to generate the right function and when i walked them through how to prompt it effectively and how to check its suggestions. By the end they were more confident and could use it independently. It felt good to share tips but it also reminded me that some people feel stressed about these tools first.

[ASSISTANT]
Has anything changed in how your manager talks about goals or pacing since these tools came into your team?

[USER]
yes, a little. since these AI tools became more common on the team, there's sometimes more emphasis on speed and output in meeting. and phrases like we should leverage these tools to move faster comes up. It is usually framed positively but it shifts the sense of pacing making it feel like tasks are expected to be completed more quickly than before.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
yes I'd never want to hand over the parts of my job that involve real judgment like designing systems or making trade offs or deciding what's worth building in the first place. Even if an AI could do those things perfectly, i feel as humans we have to stay accountable for them

[ASSISTANT]
Why is it important for you personally to keep those decisions, rather than letting an AI handle them?

[USER]
because those decisions are where my experience, a values and understanding of the context usually matter. They are the parts of the job that feel meaningful and they let me shape the work not just execute it. If i gave that up, i would feel more like a passenger than someone who's actively contributing for the outcome.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over those kinds of decisions, how do you think it would change your relationships with your teammates or your role on the team?

[USER]
I think it would make my role feel a lot smaller. If an AI were making the key decisions then i would probably end up just implementing whatever it decided which would make the work feel more mechanical. it could also create the distance with the team as there would be fewer discussions, fewer debates and less collaboration because the direction would already be set by the AI.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I would hand over the repetitive tedious tasks things like writing boilerplate code, dealing with routine debugging or cleaning up data formats. Those tasks don't require much creativity and they can be time consuming so i would be glad to let and AI take them off my plate.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled those repetitive tasks for you, would it change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
I think it might change things a bit. people might expect me to take on more complex work since the routine stuff is handled, which could be positive. but there's also a chance that some of the invisible efforts i used to put it like cleaning up messy data or untangling small bugs would go unnoticed now, since an AI would be doing it quietly in the background. overall, i think people would still value my contribution, but the baseline expectations might shift upwards.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve covered a lot. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would tell them that autonomy today means having space to make your own judgments choosing how to approach problems, managing your own pace, and shaping the direction of your work even with AI tools around. It's about using those tools on your terms and not letting them dictate how you think or work. Real autonomy is still being trusted for your expertise and not just your efficiency.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from the last month of what that looks like in practice? A moment where you chose your own approach and used the tools on your terms.

[USER]
sure. a recent example  was when i had to add a new feature to an internal tool. Instead of starting with the AI assistant i first sketched out the design myself like how the data should flow, what the edge cases were and which parts of the codebase I wanted to refactor first. Once I had that mapped out, I used AI assistant to only for small pieces like drafting a helper function. I ignored it's bigger architectural suggestion because they dint fir the constraints I knew about. It felt like i was steering the work and AI was just helping with the boring parts.

[ASSISTANT]
That makes sense. How do you tell, in the moment, that you are using the tools on your terms rather than the tools setting the approach?

[USER]
i usually check by asking myself that am i deciding the strategy or am i just following what the tools suggests. If i am sketching the design, choosing the logic and only letting the AI the boring parts I know i am in control. If i find myself following its suggestions without questioning them that's when i realize the tool is starting to set the approach instead of me.

[ASSISTANT]
When product requirements or compliance rules narrow your options, what helps you still feel like youâ€™re steering rather than just following along?

[USER]
even when requirements rules are strict, is still feel in control when i can decide how to meet them. choosing the implementation details, optimizing the workflow or finding creative ways to make the solution cleaner and efficient helps me steer.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for sharing all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else about how AI is affecting your work that we have not talked about yet?

[USER]
one thing that I'd add up is that AI sometimes changes how I plan my learning or growth. because some tasks can now be automated, I spend more time thinking where I want to focus my skill development like tackling more complex problems or learning new frameworks rather than just getting through routine work. It's subtle but it shifts not just what i do to day, but how i think about my long term career.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. Is there anything else about AIâ€™s impact on your work that youâ€™d like to add before we wrap up?

[USER]
no. all set

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you had to assess or block an AI tool in your tenant, step by step? What did you do first?

[USER]
we had a seemingly random AI note taker join various zoom meetings and nobody on the call took ownership (otter ai), we had to research what/where/who this service was, understand what and where the data was stored, make a decision on if this was within our policy terms and then find a way to put a stop to it randomly joining our zoom meetings if it was deemed unfit for our purpose ... we then put out comms across our organisation to advise on the 'breach' and our action taken along with our ever evolving guidelines on AI usage with personal data

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
just me but my line manager (head of IT) discussed and confirmed the policy guidelines

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
that we had a data breach / spy etc and that it was on me personally to ensure we were 'safe'

[ASSISTANT]
What concrete steps did you take to stop it from joining future Zoom meetings?

[USER]
we ensured that zoom meetings were invite only and that otter.ai was blocked by DNS/IP from our network ... the person that signed up to the service's account was deleted and any API integration was removed

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to past incidents with non-AI tools, how did handling this one feel different for you, if at all?

[USER]
it was fairly similar though with the speed that AI can perform actions it felt very urgent

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
they were in agreement as we laid out the facts clearly ... but a few employees questioned that it could be helpful to do in the future as minute takers could save employee time and effortr

[ASSISTANT]
Do you personally use any AI tools in your own workflow, like for troubleshooting, drafting comms, or documentation?

[USER]
No i feel that i would personally have to QA any AI output and therefore would be just as eashy to do it myself and keep up my sills in writing/typing/troubleshooting

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

1.  Issue Identification: Users couldn't access the main server, indicating a problem.
2.  Initial Assessment (Without AI): Checked basic things, but no obvious problems were found.
3.  AI Tool Integration: Used an AI tool that works with our monitoring systems.
4.  Data Input: Gave the AI error logs, network data, and system info.
5.  AI Analysis: The AI looked for patterns and potential causes in the data.
6.  AI-Generated Hypothesis: The AI suggested a database update was causing a conflict.
7.  Verification (With AI Guidance): The AI gave steps to check the database logs and configuration.
8.  Action and Resolution: We rolled back the update, and the server was working again.
9.  Post-Incident Analysis: The AI summarized the problem and gave suggestions for the future.

Interview 88

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am the Executive Director of a small software startup that creates AI enhanced B2B software for businesses

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
A good job provides meaningful work, autonomy, and clear opportunities for growth. It offers stability and fair compensation, but also challenges people to improve their skills. Strong communication, supportive leadership, and the ability to make an impact all play a major role in whether a job feels fulfilling and sustainable.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say meaningful work, what does that look like for you in the day to day?

[USER]
Meaningful work for me is solving real problems for businesses and seeing our products make someoneâ€™s workflow faster and more efficient. It is knowing that what I build is actually used and valued. I also find meaning in guiding my team, making strategic decisions, and watching ideas turn into features that help people.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about growth, what lets you know a role genuinely offers it?

[USER]
I know a role offers real growth when I can see a clear path to learning new skills, taking on bigger responsibilities, and making decisions that matter. Growth also shows up when the work pushes me to think in new ways and when my contributions directly shape the direction of the team or the product.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned strong communication and supportive leadership. When thatâ€™s really working, what does it look like in practice?

[USER]
When communication and leadership are really working, everyone knows what the goals are and what their part is. People share updates openly, ask questions without hesitation, and get honest feedback that helps them improve. Leadership feels present and supportive. They remove obstacles, guide decisions, and listen to concerns. The team understands the expectations, feels appreciated, and works together smoothly because nothing is unclear or confusing.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI has become central to my work. It speeds up research, planning, and problem solving, and it helps me handle large amounts of information quickly. It also supports our team by improving our software products and giving us tools that make development faster and more accurate. Because of AI, I can focus more on strategy and leadership instead of getting buried in routine tasks.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used AI on a specific work task, step by step?

[USER]
The last time I used AI was earlier today while preparing a feature outline for one of our software products. First, I described the problem we wanted to solve and the goals for the feature. Then I asked the AI to generate possible design approaches. After that, I refined the ideas with follow up prompts until I had a clear structure. I used the final output to guide my team and speed up the planning process.

[ASSISTANT]
In that feature outline example, which parts did the AI produce and which parts did you create or rewrite yourself?

[USER]
The AI produced the initial structure, the list of possible design approaches, and a few sample workflows. I created the original problem description, clarified the goals, and rewrote most of the final outline in my own words. I kept the parts that were useful, reorganized the flow, and adjusted the tone so it matched how my team actually works.

[ASSISTANT]
Did the AI make any mistakes or suggest anything off in that outline, and if so, how did you handle it?

[USER]
Yes, it did. It sometimes added features that were outside the scope or too complex for the first release. It also made a few assumptions about our user flow that were not accurate. When that happened, I removed what did not fit, corrected the details, and guided it with more context. I treat its output as a draft, not a final answer, so I edit it until it lines up with the real needs of the product.

[ASSISTANT]
When you were revising the AIâ€™s outline, what was your gut response in the moment?

[USER]
My gut response was calm and matter of fact. I have learned to expect that AI will miss pieces or overreach, so it did not frustrate me. I just thought Okay, here is a good starting point, now let me shape it into what it actually needs to be. It felt similar to editing a junior teammateâ€™s draft, useful, but still needing guidance and correction.

[ASSISTANT]
When you do this kind of planning with AI compared to before, what changes for you in the workflow or the pace of getting to a solid draft?

[USER]
Using AI changes both the workflow and the pace in a noticeable way. Before AI, getting to a solid draft took longer because I had to build everything from zero. Now I can move faster because I start with something rather than nothing. That shift saves time and mental energy. It also lets me focus more on strategy and clarity instead of spending the first hour staring at a blank page.

[ASSISTANT]
When you save that first hour, what do you usually do with the time and headspace you get back?

[USER]
I usually use that extra time and headspace to think more deeply about the product itself. Instead of grinding through early drafting, I can refine goals, test assumptions, or map out edge cases. Sometimes I review related systems or talk with my team to confirm details. It gives me room to be more thoughtful and make better decisions rather than rushing through the basics.

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond feature planning, can you tell me about another recent situation where you used AI at work and what happened?

[USER]
A recent example was drafting a proposal for a new client integration. I gave the AI the technical context, timeline, and pain points, and it produced a basic draft with sections like scope and deliverables. The structure was helpful, but the wording was too generic, so I rewrote the whole thing to match our tone and added the real technical details. The AI mainly saved me from starting with a blank page, while the final proposal was shaped by my edits.

[ASSISTANT]
What is it like for you when youâ€™re reviewing or correcting the drafts it produces?

[USER]
When I review or correct AI drafts, it feels smooth and efficient. I scan for gaps or weak points, tighten the language, and add the depth the model cannot provide. It is more like polishing a rough template than fixing real errors, and it lets me stay focused on clarity and strategy instead of getting stuck on the first version.

[ASSISTANT]
Has using AI ever led you to change a decision you were going to make, and what happened as a result?

[USER]
Yes, a few times AI has pushed me to rethink a decision. Sometimes it lays out risks or alternative angles I had not fully considered, and seeing those options clearly presented makes me slow down and reassess. When that happens, I usually compare its reasoning with my own instincts, check the facts, and then choose the stronger path. In most cases the change leads to cleaner plans or avoids unnecessary work, so the end result is usually more efficient and better thought out.

[ASSISTANT]
Is there any kind of task where you choose not to use AI, and what leads you to draw that line?

[USER]
Yes. I avoid using AI for tasks that require personal judgment, sensitive communication, or decisions that depend on context only I can see. Things like team feedback, investor updates, or anything involving subtle relationship dynamics feel wrong to delegate because tone and intent matter too much. I also skip AI when the task is so core to my role that outsourcing any part of it would weaken my understanding. The line is basically this, if relying on AI would dilute my judgment, affect trust, or distance me from something I need to stay deeply connected to, I do it myself.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
AI has mainly improved my working relationships by helping to free up time for better communication. Since I can prepare drafts, summaries, or plans faster, I show up to conversations more organized, which helps everyone move forward with less stress. It also lowers the pressure on my team because I am not handing off rushed or unclear tasks. At the same time, I am careful not to let AI replace real collaboration. I still make space for human input so people feel heard and valued. Overall it has helped us work smoother, but I stay mindful to keep the relationships personal and not overly automated.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent meeting or interaction where something created with AI shaped the discussion between you and your team? What happened in that exchange?

[USER]
Yes, surely, I recently brought an AI generated draft into a planning meeting, and it changed the whole conversation. Instead of spending time defining the basics, everyone reacted to the draft right away. The team pointed out what worked, what needed fixing, and what did not fit our product. It gave us a clear starting point and made the discussion faster and more focused. By the end, the final plan was better than the AI version, but the AI helped us get there quickly.

[USER]
you there?

[ASSISTANT]
Iâ€™m here. When you share something that started with AI, how do your teammates tend to respond, and what stands out to you about those reactions?

[USER]
They usually respond with curiosity and focus. They treat the AI draft like a rough starting point, not a finished answer. What stands out is how quickly it gets them talking. Instead of debating from scratch, they react to something concrete, which helps them clarify their own ideas. Sometimes theyâ€™re impressed by how clean the structure is, and other times they immediately point out what feels off or unrealistic. Either way, it speeds up the conversation and gets everyone aligned to collaborate faster.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

It also helps me show multiple strategic options quickly, which makes me look more prepared and thoughtful. The only real change is that Iâ€™m careful not to rely on AI when communicating sensitive ideas, because trust comes from my own judgment. Overall, it has made me more reliable and more confident in those interactions.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

Moments like that taught me to label AI drafts clearly and set expectations upfront. After that, the tension went away, and collaboration actually improved.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I would never hand over the human parts of leadership. Even if an AI could do it perfectly, I would not give up personally mentoring my team, building trust, establishing collaborative culture, or making decisions that depend on judgment, values, and intuition. Those moments of connection and responsibility define what leadership means to me, and they shape the direction of the company in a way an AI cannot replicate.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent moment of mentoring or a hard call you made where being the one in the room mattered, and what made it important that it was you?

[USER]
I recently had a teammate who was unsure about the direction of a feature and worried they were falling behind. I sat with them, talked through the decisions, and helped them focus on what really mattered instead of letting them feel overwhelmed. Being there in person mattered because I could read their stress, reassure them, and help them rebuild confidence in a way no AI could. The conversation was not just about the work, it was about supporting them as a person.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is it important to you to keep those leadership moments yourself rather than handing any part of them to an AI?

[USER]
It matters to me because real leadership is built on trust, empathy, and human judgment, and I feel like those things cannot be simply be delegated (to AI). When someone on my team is struggling or needs direction, they are not just looking for information, they are looking for understanding, accountability, and a sense that someone (human) genuinely cares about their growth. An AI can offer guidance, but it cannot form a relationship or take responsibility for the outcome. Keeping those moments genuine and intimate protects the culture I want to build and reminds my team that they matter as people.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Honestly, I would hand off all the repetitive operational work tomorrow without hesitation. Things like drafting routine emails, pulling status summaries, organizing meeting notes, formatting documents, or preparing early versions of reports all drain time without adding much creative or strategic value. AI could handle those tasks quickly and consistently, which would free time to stay focused on leadership, vision, and the decisions that actually move the company forward.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled those operational pieces, would it change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
I do not think it would change how others see my contribution. When AI handles the routine pieces, my value shows up in the strategic work, the decisions, the judgment, and the leadership that only I can provide. People would see me spending more time on direction, mentoring, problem solving, and shaping the product rather than being buried in busywork. It would highlight the parts of my role that actually define my contribution rather than dilute them.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would tell them autonomy means having real control over how you approach your work. It means being trusted to decide how to solve problems, manage your time, and shape your contributions without someone dictating every step. Autonomy today also means knowing how to use tools like AI to amplify your strengths while staying accountable for the final result. It is the freedom to think independently paired with the responsibility to deliver.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example from your work where you exercised that kind of freedom paired with responsibility, and what you did step by step?

[USER]
A recent example was deciding whether to move forward with a new feature. I sketched the concept, used AI to brainstorm options, kept the parts that matched our goals, and rewrote everything else. Then I checked technical feasibility with my lead engineer, laid out the risks, and drafted a short proposal with AI helping only with structure. I made the final decision by weighing what the business really needed against the actual work it would take to produce it. The autonomy was choosing how to navigate the decision, and the responsibility was owning whatever results came from it.

[ASSISTANT]
When you talk about autonomy there, do you mean mostly choosing the methods and pace to hit a given target, or do you mean setting the targets and priorities themselves? Which is closer to what you have in mind?

[USER]
I mean setting the targets and priorities themselves. Choosing the methods and pace matters too, but the deeper level of autonomy for me is deciding what is actually worth pursuing in the first place. Thatâ€™s where the real responsibility shows up.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re deciding what is actually worth pursuing, what signals tell you itâ€™s time to set a new target, and how, if at all, does AI influence that call?

[USER]
I usually realize itâ€™s time for a new target when customer needs a new feature, a strong opportunity shows up, or our current plan stops giving the results we want. AI doesnâ€™t decide for me, but it helps me notice trends sooner and test my ideas before I move forward.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

Interview 90

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I primarily handle dev ops for  application deployment and maintenance.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Stable employment, as well as room for growth in the field.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say stable employment, what does that look like day to day for you?

[USER]
I feel in the day to day I should feel a clear sense that my job values me and won't lay off at the first sign of trouble.  The mental benefit of feeling secure helps me work better and harder.

[ASSISTANT]
When you talk about room for growth, what does that mean in practice for you?

[USER]
Room for growth is allowing me to either move upwards, or pursue the means to increase what I earn in other meaningful and challenging ways.

[ASSISTANT]
Between stability and growth, which carries more weight for you when youâ€™re evaluating a job?

[USER]
If I'm looking to only consider one factor, stability would be the most important.  Growth in a short-lived job would have very little value.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI has definitely become a threat to people in my positions due to managerial staff not actually understanding what it is capable of.  It is constantly over-valued and over-estimated and being forced to use it tends to create more problems than it solves.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent time you were asked to use it on a specific task in your deployment or maintenance work? What was the task?

[USER]
In maintenance they were specifically asking for alerts and other routine tasks to be completely automated.  Given the clients we work with, the decisions it could make had nowhere near the level of flexibility required.  This is also adding to the fact, no one wants to code something that will invalidate their job.

[ASSISTANT]
In that example of automating alerts, what did you try to have the system do, and what did you keep under human control?

[USER]
I never pursued this and refused to implement it, due to it threatening my job position.  If I had to answer I would have specifically had it handle emergency alerts and potential solutions to resolve them without human interaction.

[ASSISTANT]
When you were asked to automate alerts like that, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
That they wanted to replace my job duties with an automated AI process.

[ASSISTANT]
How did you communicate your refusal to your manager, and what happened after that conversation?

[USER]
I was professional and framed it as a lack of knowledge on my part.  Following this, I simply provided alternate solutions that did not involve AI.  Such as, consolidating alerts to more user-friendly reference points to increase efficiency.

[ASSISTANT]
What changed in the day to day after you rolled out the consolidated, more userâ€‘friendly alerts?

[USER]
This was not something that was immediately implemented.  It was simply brought up as a potential avenue to pursue.

[ASSISTANT]
Aside from the alerts request, has AI shown up in your deployment or maintenance work in any other concrete way?

[USER]
for deployment specifically, I have heard that there might be attempts to use AI to automate newer client packages.  However, as far as I'm aware this has not been implemented yet.

[ASSISTANT]
Have you used any AI tools yourself in your workflow so far? If so, what did you try them on?

[USER]
I have not used them extensively, but I have used services like ChatGPT to write rudimentary scripts to automate tedious entry tasks or other similar duties.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking of the last script you had it draft for a tedious entry task, what was the script meant to do?

[USER]
There is a lot of rote data entry involved with the amount of clients we have.  I would usually have a script that would run and copy data from our client database to fill in orders or alerts to minimize the time spent typing the information.

[ASSISTANT]
After it drafted the script, what changes did you make before you felt okay running it on your systems?

[USER]
In general it was very accurate, I edited it for formatting at first.  I also made sure to carefully proofread the work after it was done to ensure there were no errors.  There never were any critical errors that popped up.

[ASSISTANT]
When you ran that script the first few times, what was your gut responseâ€”more at ease because it sped things up, or more on edge watching for mistakes?

[USER]
In the beginning I was mostly on edge ensuring it didn't make entry errors.

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved once the script was working reliably?

[USER]
I spent a lot more time on more complex tasks or making myself available in the event a critical alert came up.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
In general I feel it has solidified me with people on the same level, and made my relationships towards upper management more critical.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent interaction with a peer where you felt that sense of solidarityâ€”what happened and what stands out to you about it?

[USER]
This is almost entirely on us all having pretty firm agreements that coding AI that automates our jobs will destroy our careers.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a specific conversation with a manager about using AIâ€”what you said, what they said, and how it ended?

[USER]
A lot of the conversations deal with management having idealistic views of AI, assuming they can use it to solve nearly any problem.  Most of my discussions involve explaining what it is actually capable of.  In general, I feel the words are said, but not really taking to heart.  It is common to get the feeling that I simply dont have the experience to utilize it in the way they want.

[ASSISTANT]
Has this push from management changed how your contributions are recognized or evaluated at work?

[USER]
I do feel that talk of AI is at the forefront.  Due to this, if you aren't bringing it up or trying to fofer suggestions with it, you are definitely less recognized.

[ASSISTANT]
When a teammate suggests using AI on a task, how do you usually handle that conversation?

[USER]
I would caution against it, or advise implementing it in a way that makes it a very minor part of the process.

[ASSISTANT]
Has talk of using these tools changed your conversations with clients about reliability or SLAs?

[USER]
While I am not directly involved in client conversations, from what I have heard from co-workers it has created an expectation for quicker response times.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Assuming such a perfect AI existed, I wouldn't want to hand over maintenance of most systems or applications.  I feel that while humans can make errors, our judgement is what lets us make less optimal decisions that sometimes benefit the user more.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you share a concrete incident where you chose a technically suboptimal path because it was better for the user? What happened and what stands out to you about that moment?

[USER]
Multiple examples have happened in the past, such as slower delivery to ensure the full operability of the software is available. Sometimes its better to make the customer slightly displeased in the present to allow them to have the best experience possible at a later date.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI handled that maintenance work instead of you, how do you think it would change your role on the team?

[USER]
A huge portion of my job would functionally disappear, I would assume that this would mean I would be laid off or have my work responsibilities (and pay) cut accordingly.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is keeping that maintenance work in human hands important to you personally?

[USER]
While I do have some bias, as I would like to keep my job, I do feel that humans are simply more reliable and personal touch is important.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Almost any and all rote data entry that I have to do.

[ASSISTANT]
Why would you like to give up the rote data entry?

[USER]
It requires a significant amount of typing, and doesn't involve any stimulating problems or challenges.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over the data entry, do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
I don't feel it would.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
Autonomy to me is the ability to produce and implement your own solutions to problems that you will face in the field.  The opportunities where you challenge yourself are the ways you will grow, and lacking the ability to do this will keep you stagnate.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a recent example where you produced and implemented your own solutionâ€”what was the problem and what did you do?

[USER]
While I can't be too specific due to the nature of my work, I feel I have a decent broad example.  I received a fairly critical alert, and it caused a massive downtime for the client it concerned.  I was at the forefront of solving this and managed to troubleshoot and fix the underlying code causing it.  This also improved the process itself to ensure that specific problem didnt happen again.

[ASSISTANT]
In that incident, which parts were you able to decide and act on yourself, and where did you need someoneâ€™s approval before moving ahead?

[USER]
Anything touching client data I had to have approval before dealing with.

[ASSISTANT]
I can see two ways someone might hear what you said. One is that itâ€™s mainly about choosing your own methods and tools. The other is that itâ€™s about choosing which problems to work on in the first place. Which is closer to what you mean, or is it something else?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]
nothing of the sort, but excited to see the outcome

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]
data is important, if ai deletes data without s knowing, thats an issue

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
we'd feel insecure about the use of ai and the customers data

[USER]
monitoring issues to then informing us

[USER]

[USER]
no

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I'm a Software Architect

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Ensuring the job is done to completion, on time and with real dedication.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say done to completion, what tells you itâ€™s truly finished rather than just shipped?

[USER]
If the customer is happy, I am happy and the product quality is clearly delivering on its advertised value.

[ASSISTANT]
In your context, what does being on time look like, and how do you gauge whether youâ€™re on track as the work unfolds?

[USER]
Delivering something on time is to ensure that all user stories are met from our design documents and to ensure that we've communicated any potential delays as early in the process as they're delivered. Ultimately the customer and our contractual terms defines this but informally we try to ensure the customer is receiving the best kind of client service.

[ASSISTANT]
When you talk about real dedication, what does that look like in your day to day work?

[USER]
Going above and beyond to research into issues, work with colleagues and external acquaintances and just doing anything we can to make sure we keep delivering a product that leads the industry.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I typically use AI as a preliminary research tool, a way to summarize documents, and a way to mock up UI examples in a very rough and quick manner

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used it to summarize a document, step by step? What did you give it, what did it return, and what did you do next?

[USER]
I provided a technical document which outlined an integration API. I asked the AI agent to ingest the document first. This document was a first draft. I also provided a second completed API technical document as a reference and  then asked the agent to see if it can spot any potential holes in the implementation using the more completed document as a reference. I then asked it to summarize these for me

[ASSISTANT]
What kinds of gaps did it flag in the draft, and how did you check whether those were real issues?

[USER]
It flagged a couple of testing credential related issues, by referring to a more secure way in which we implemented it in the reference document. I checked they were real issues by using my own learned knowledge and by determining if they were contextually sensitive to the new API. They weren't entirely relevant, but this discovery meant I could update the API documentation to reflect this and assuage any doubts by those who read the document in the future.

[ASSISTANT]
When it surfaced those credential points, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
I was intrigued to think that this was an issue that was missed, or to know if it was really an issue in the broader context.

[ASSISTANT]
In that example, which parts did the system actually do, and which parts did you handle yourself?

[USER]
What exactly do you mean?

[ASSISTANT]
I mean in that workflow, what did the system actually produce, and what did you yourself write or decide?

[USER]
I produced the full API documentation and reference document. The system/agent provided a textual list of what I asked for in a summary

[ASSISTANT]
Were any of the systemâ€™s suggestions off base or misleading in that case, and if so, how did you handle them?

[USER]
In the early example I provided the system made a semi-valid point but in the broader business context it was a little off base. To handle this I simple added the greater context into the API documentation so that this kind of understanding isn't a worry in future.

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved by having it surface those points and summarize them?

[USER]
I worked on other pressing matters in our development stack.

[ASSISTANT]
How did doing that document review with the system compare to how you would have handled it before you had these tools?

[USER]
Without these tools I'd have circulated it to our development and functional team and asked for review input. I still did this, however by using the AI tool I was able to waste less of my own time and everyone else's time by picking up on obvious issues earlier.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about the last time you used it to mock up a UIâ€”what did you ask for, and what did it give you?

[USER]
I asked the AI agent to mock up an internal portal for our functional team members which allowed them to access a summarized webview of progress and goals across multiple integration sources such as our external and internal ticketing systems and project tooling.

[ASSISTANT]
What did it give you back for that portal, and how did you use or change what it produced?

[USER]
It gave me back some boilerplate HTML and CSS. Mainly just the design and feel of the document. I used what it produced to circulate it internally towards our team to ask if such a feature/view would be usefull.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned circulating it internally. How did your teammates react, and what stands out to you about that exchange?

[USER]
My target audience - the functional team - were rather intrigued by this but obviously our development team were more concerned with supporting a new feature. What stood out to me was that they assumed I'd spent a great deal of time on all of this, I'd in fact spent just a few hours of my own time.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about both the API review and the UI mockup, how did these tools affect your confidence in the work you were planning to ship?

[USER]
In terms of confidence the tools definitely validated and reinforced a lot of my work and thoughts and helped reduce any internal anxiety I had about moving forwards in our product pipeline.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used it for preliminary researchâ€”what you were trying to find out, what you asked, and what you did with the results?

[USER]
I wasn't able to find any decent sources on a specific algorithmic optimisation online, and as such I asked the agent to find research and doctoral level references about this, which it was able to. I used the results to learn for upcoming projects.

[ASSISTANT]
When it returned those references, how did you judge whether they were solid enough to rely on?

[USER]
I visited the sources one by one and confirmed authenticity and actually read/purchased/acquired them after assessing the relevance.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I don't really think it's affected them at all on the surface. If anything we have less busy work conversations that could be avoided by just talking to an AI agent.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you describe a recent time when you would normally have gone back and forth with a colleague, but instead you used the tool, and how that changed the interaction with that person afterwards?

[USER]
Earlier I referenced a time where I used the AI to find gaps in a technical API document before circulating this to colleagues. By doing this I avoided multiple rounds of back and forth before I eventually circulated it.

[ASSISTANT]
How do your manager or clients view you using these toolsâ€”have they commented on it or set any expectations around it?

[USER]
There aren't really any comments nor expectations set. As with any work, if we produce work or effort we have to be able to justify and back it up with reasonable data and effort. Using AI tools doesn't change this mentality.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about mentoring and learning on the job, has using these tools changed how you coach teammates or how juniors come to you with questions?

[USER]
Not necessarily. If anything I teach juniors and teammates to do their own research before becoming reliant on AI tools so that they know how to validate and assess any information AI tools produce

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Finally hitting "send" on client based communication. I want ultimate responsibility on what leaves our organisation and team in terms of information. Not necessarily me, but a human.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes having a human press send so important to you in practice?

[USER]
Ensuring we have a full trail of responsibility and ensuring there's at least someone other than AI who knows what's being communicated. That level of autonomy is just too risky.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI handled pressing send on client communications, how do you think that would change your relationships with your teammates or your role on the team?

[USER]
I think I'd be just as responsible for allowing the situation to be possible but less able to control it. The same for my colleagues.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Updating internal documentation as we ship new features, of course with approval oversight.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It's simply so time consuming and its something most code based agents should be able to handle if configured correctly in my experience

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI handled those documentation updates, would it change how others see your contribution to the team in any way?

[USER]
Absolutely not.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I'd tell them that it meant they'd have the ability to pursue tasks as they see fit and that they'd have all of the learning material available to learn at their own pace.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example from the last month where you chose how to tackle a task and set your own learning pace?

[USER]
I looked at our internal development timeline and in my own time I researched algorithmic optimisation methods for a project that was all about implementing features such as this in our prediction and forecasting functionalities.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
A combination of both

[ASSISTANT]
In your current role, what are the practical limits on thatâ€”what boundaries or standards do you need to work within when you choose methods and set your own pace?

[USER]
We obviously have client and internal deadlines to meet but nothing says we cannot start projects earlier and move at a slower pace for a longer time. Also, we have educational limits and tooling limits when it comes to finances.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
