[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I work in IT as an IT manager, I am responsible for all enterprise hardware, such as firewalls, switches, servers, storage, etc.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
One that is enjoyable to the person and fulfills them

[ASSISTANT]
When you say enjoyable, what does that look like in your day to day work?

[USER]
I find it fun to do, it is a challenge.  Challenging things make the day go by faster and leads me to feel that I accomplished something

[ASSISTANT]
When you say it fulfills you, what does that mean to you?

[USER]
As I mentioned, I feel like I accomplished something, inner pride that I completed it

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond the challenge and that sense of completion, what else matters most to you in a job?

[USER]
That I am treated with respect by my peers and leadership

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
We use it to monitor systems and accounts for unusual activity.  Does a person typically access that computer or this file in the daily worklife and if not, why are they doing so now.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a recent specific alert it raisedâ€”what it flagged and what you did next?

[USER]
I cannot give specifics, but I can discuss it if I censor some of the information.  Let's say a person all of a sudden started logging in from a different state, or country, out of the blue.   This would be a red flag and the system would challenge that person by triggering MFA.

[ASSISTANT]
In that example, what parts did the system handle on its own, and what steps did you personally take once the MFA challenge was triggered?

[USER]
Nothing at that point, it is all automated.  If the account succeeds in the MFA challenge, it's marked as atypical behavior, but valid.  If there is a failure, the account is automatically disabled and an alert is sent to us.  The person receives a message to contact IT for assistance when they attempt to access anything.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about a time when the system disabled an account but it turned out to be a legitimate login. What happened and how did you sort it out?

[USER]
That has never happened, so far.

[ASSISTANT]
When an alert does come in that an account was disabled after failed challenges, what goes through your mind in that moment, and what do you do first?

[USER]
We have someone contact the person via phone call, ask what happened, get any details that may be helpful in tracking down the source.    They have the password changed and continue on

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to before you had this system, how has the workflow around account anomalies changed for you and your team?

[USER]
Before we didn't necessarily know when something was occurring, we had no visibility

[ASSISTANT]
What stood out to you when you first started getting that visibilityâ€”what was your gut response to seeing those alerts?

[USER]
How unaware we were previously.  Luckily we had almost no cloud presence so the risk was minimal

[ASSISTANT]
Since putting this in place, how has it changed what you spend your time on during a typical day?

[USER]
It hasn't changed anything from that perspective.

[USER]
hello?

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for the nudge. Besides monitoring logins and account behavior, are there other ways AI shows up in your hardware or network responsibilities?

[USER]
I use it for writing scripts, very helpful in that regard.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about the last script you asked it to help with. What did you need the script to do?

[USER]
I had it write a script to look for all enabled accounts in a specific OU and to report back any of those accounts that were not a member of a group.

[ASSISTANT]
In that script example, what did it produce on the first try, and what changes did you make before you were comfortable running it in your environment?

[USER]
The first iteration was entirely too complex and didn't work.  I let it debug a few times before I told it to make the script as simple as possible.  That one worked on the first try.

[ASSISTANT]
When you were iterating on that script and telling it to simplify, what went through your mind during that back and forth?

[USER]
I was wanting it to provide a good output and not the troublesome code it was giving me.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I have not seen a change there.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you think of a moment where AI touched a handoff with a colleague or a managerâ€”maybe around an alert, a script, or a policy discussionâ€”and tell me how that interaction went?

[USER]
The events I mentioned earlier would be one.  Once an alert is raised, we reach out to our Help Desk team to contact the person.

[ASSISTANT]
What typically stands out to you about coordinating with the Help Desk during those alerts?

[USER]
Nothing, it's as simple as a Teams message to the group.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I will always want to be aware and involved with any security events.  Not because it cannot handle it but because I want that information so I can stay informed about the company's safety.

[ASSISTANT]
What parts of a security event do you feel you personally need to see or decide in order to stay informed about the companyâ€™s safety?

[USER]
All of that information, the who, what, where, and why it occurred

[ASSISTANT]
What changes for you if you only received a brief summary of an incident instead of digging into the details yourself?

[USER]
I won't have the complete picture

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled the triage and investigation end to end and only pinged you when it was done, how do you think that would change your role on the team or your interactions with others?

[USER]
I would no longer be the point person who is contacted by any leadership that wants the information.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Any reports requested.  Active users, people who are over licensed, accounts not using email, etc.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
When you say you want to feel secure, what does that look like day to day for you?

[USER]
Just knowing I'm able to do my job without being scrutinised by anyone and I can get on with my work.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
We had a fairly big project going on, and we were under some time restraints which is normally the case at work. My boss could see I was struggling with stress, and they pulled me aside and assured me it was all going to be okay, and that we distributed the work load differently and I was able to concentrate more on the important things for the project.

[ASSISTANT]
Among the things you mentioned, which matters most to you and why?

[USER]
Having a support system at work. Knowing your colleagues aren't going to react in a negative way by making a mistake.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
We use AI specifically that we have developed ourselves. When we don't have big work on, we use it for summarising and sorting emails strictly.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used it to summarize emailsâ€”what you did and what it did?

[USER]
We use it daily for emails and to summarise, we get over 100 emails over night that we have the AI automatically sort for us, and it will make a note of it, for us to check the morning after. So, we don't have to do anything, the AI is automatically set up for it to do this. When we need it for something else, we will then programme it ready.

[ASSISTANT]
When you check the summaries the next morning, what exactly do you look for, and what kinds of things make you override or adjust what it produced?

[USER]
We have it set up so it will be able to detect keywords, and then simplify the emails and put them down to a couple sentences. With the amount of testing and work that has gone into this specific model, we do not need to make changes for this anymore, we've been working on it for years, and we've perfected it for this specific task.

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond the email sorting, can you tell me about a time you programmed it for another task and how that played out?

[USER]
In the past we have let it aid in code, so when we have a big project on, we will give it tasks, it tends to help with code error, but we are slowing implementing it, so it can assist with actually writing code. But for something that we do on a regular basis, it is programmed to detect error in the code, notify us of the specific code that is in question, it will offer a solution and then we will fix it ourselves.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about the last time it flagged an error in your codeâ€”what was the issue it pointed to, and what steps did you take next?

[USER]
It was to do early on in a project, we were coding some work for logistics in the company and it spotted an error with how the charts were showing estimated delivery times. It was a very small and odd error, a few of us in the team weren't even sure as to why it was coming up as incorrect, but we eventually realised what had happened, the AI offered it's solution and we followed through by implementing it.

[ASSISTANT]
In that logistics incident, which parts did it handle and which parts did you and your teammates handle?

[USER]
It was just checking the code we provide for the AI to go over. Our team do all of the coding, in this scenario specifically.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Confusion, was my initial thought, as we don't tend to get a lot of errors, especially not for straight forward code, and something we do on the regular, but it was indeed strange, but that's what the AI is programmed to do, and we are thankful for that.

[ASSISTANT]
When it proposes a fix like that, how do you decide whether to implement it as is or dig deeper before making changes?

[USER]
Well, as we could see the code wasn't working as intended, so we knew something was amiss, and it was a logical fix. We tested it, and it worked. It's quite simple when it comes to fixes like that. It's a lot of trial and error, but for this, there was only 1 thing that it could have been.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It gives me more time, sorting the tasks of my team, and allows me to focus more on the project earlier than usual. It's more about time saving.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It's more of a relief, knowing I don't have to do that mundane task, which was not good for productivity.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It hasn't changed my role much at all, I still do everything else, reading and going through emails was just part of my job that had to be done, until we programmed this AI to aid in that.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
We don't use AI for any sort of social activities in the office, but it has allowed our team to spend more time planning our actions for projects and other things, because of the time save that it is bringing us.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
We will never allow AI to interact with stakeholders, or higher up bosses. We keep those strictly personal, and it allows us to stay in contact and keep that closeness.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes those conversations with stakeholders and senior leaders something you want to do yourself rather than have a system handle them?

[USER]
When you can put a face to a name, it looks like you're showing interest and putting effort into the job, and not just putting them onto an AI.

[ASSISTANT]
If a system handled those meetings for you, how do you think it would change your relationships with those people or your place in the team?

[USER]
It just shows a lack of professionalism to me. We want the people involved to feel like they are being respected and given the time of day. If we're directing them to an AI, and it's automated, it won't feel the same.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you think of a time when meeting someone in person or directly changed the outcome of a project or a decision? What stands out about that moment?

[USER]
Well, we've only ever dealt with people in person and we ensure we get it over the line.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily hand over to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I've already gladly put the email summarising over to the AI, the coding is something that is not part of my job but I do still help out, as I am the senior engineer in my team, but slowly the AI is being programmed to be able to perform to a very high standard and that is next to be a permanent feature.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It will be another time saver, as I have other jobs to do other than help out with code, the more I can put onto the AI, the more time it gives me to ensure the quality of the work is as good as it can be.

[ASSISTANT]
If more of the coding shifted to the system, do you think it would change how others view your contribution to the team? Why or why not?

[USER]
It's not part of my job anyway, so it was just something I help out with, if there's a problem, so no, I don't think it would. They understand my time is needed elsewhere.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would make sure they knew it isn't about doing what you want, it's about having trust in people and the space to use your own judgement. It allows me to choose how I come at a problem, I get to set my priorities, and then I can decide what is the best way to deliver the best I possibly can from not only me but my team. We don't need someone constantly looking at the little things. I am able to set the bigger goals, but for each day, my team have the freedom to do what they think is best, and take lead of your own situation.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
The other week we had to turn around a product usage insight fast. I set the key questions we needed to answer and the order of priorities, then everyone tackled it their own way, one person coding in Python, another pulling data in SQL, another sketching visuals. It was pretty obvious it was working as I was left alone and I trust my team to come to me for any little issue.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
The most important thing for me is making sure everyone is on the same page for our end goal, the last thing you want it is people confused as to what we're aiming to achieve as a whole. We set a time that we will check in with each other to discuss any issues that have arose, to ensure it doesn't get too deep and then a real problem. Lastly, I would say we have people share their drafts or anything they find, no matter how raw it is.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
last month, during a check in on a dashboard project, 1 member of the team realised their data source was missing key fields. Because we caught it early, we didnâ€™t waste time building on incomplete data. I helped them adjust the query and reprioritised a couple of tasks, and by the next check in we were back on track. It was quick and easy to sort out.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Providing deliverables timely, within budget, with high quality.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
My job is to create systems and policies that protect the companies' data and systems from attacks, infiltration, and other malicious activities. This can be from an internal or external attacker.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I use AI in many facets of my role. Primarily for assistance in coding, scripting, and querying. I also use it to help with Standard Operating Procedures and best practices. I also use it for formatting and grammar checks when sending messages.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used it for coding or scriptingâ€”what were you building or fixing?

[USER]
I used it for writing a script today that would automatically compile multiple spreadsheets of data into one, then it would add specific charts, and add formatting. This would also be automatically delivered to stakeholders.

[ASSISTANT]
In that script, which parts did the AI generate, and which parts did you write or change yourself?

[USER]
It created the majority of the script including commenting. I had to revise a few steps to add specific attributes for Azure Key Vault.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
There were a few errors in the initial script. I tested this in a sandboxed environment and provided feedback to the AI engine.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I thought this was common as often it takes time for the engine to fully understand the use-case you are working toward.

[USER]
It is quite simple. The output is usually pretty close. I just have to make a few modifications.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I could have done it without AI but it would have taken me 2-3 hours to get it perfect. With AI this took less than 45 minutes to complete.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I moved on to other tasks. I was able to have 1:1s with my subordinates which helped free them up more for next week.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
For that SOP, which parts did it draft, and where did you step in to shape or revise it?

[USER]
It drafted the entire process. I stepped in to revise it with company terminology, formatting, and the current SMEs of the EDR/XDR.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I have not seen any positive nor negative affect on my work relationships.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It is often not noticed or considered as long as the output is favorable and accomplishes the task.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Data privacy, integrity, availability, and confidentiality

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I cannot recall a specific situation.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Automation of Incident management

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Most of the time it is a repetitive task with many false positives. Handing this over would create more time for creativity.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
No. I would still be notified and use human judgement to make the call whether it is a serious threat or not.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
The ability to create your own schedule, take time off as needed, and create a work/life balance. I would also tell them they need to have self-determination and self-disciple. Some cannot handle that level of freedom within their job.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I tend to it if serious along with other teammates. If I or any other teammate is on vacation, I tell them sign completely out of all communication platforms (email, MS Teams, etc.) Since we prioritize well qualified individuals and pay them accordingly, I feel comfortable for anyone on my team to be able to handle the incident.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

I decided how to structure the code, which approach to take for tricky parts, and when to ask teammates for input. I wasnâ€™t just following instructions, I made choices about the best way to get the work done and owned the results.

[ASSISTANT]
When an AI offers a solution on a project like that, how do you decide whether to follow it or stick with your own approach?

[USER]
I look at whether the AIâ€™s suggestion actually fits the problem and the bigger picture.

[USER]
I look at whether the AIâ€™s suggestion actually fits the problem and the bigger picture.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
Hello. I'm a principal software engineer, I lead a department of 30 engineers within the pensions industry building the next generation of administrative tooling

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Fulfillment and clear objectives, being able to succeed at the role and feel good about it

[ASSISTANT]
When you say fulfillment, what does that look like for you in a typical week? What tells you youâ€™ve hit that feeling?

[USER]
Good question. I suppose starting the week with an unmet objective and ending the week with a resolutionin place, completing the goal to the satisfaction of a stakeholder. That could be individual contributor (IC) work, or leadership

[ASSISTANT]
What helps make an objective feel clear and achievable for you?

[USER]
Understanding and marking deliverable milestones towards the end objective

[ASSISTANT]
Is there anything else that matters most in a good job for you?

[USER]
Pay, of course. Being able to sustain my lifestyle as a bare minimum of the job is important

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
Sure. Code generation has become trendy and is seen as a force multiplier within software engineering. It allows people with no history or training to create /something/, whereas existing skilled engineers can create /more/ and faster.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent task where you used it in your own work? What was the task, and how did you bring the tool into it?

[USER]
My typical usage is for script creation. If i have a manual process, or a process that I'm not 100% confident with that can be scripted, AI is very good at iterating on that process tro find an automated solution.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking of the last script you built this way, what did the AI generate first, and what parts did you end up changing yourself?

[USER]
The "skeleton" of a script is generally my first approach. I'll outline the requirements in clear instructions, note any constraints or considerations, and then "fill in the blanks" so to speak.

[ASSISTANT]
In that last case, which parts did the tool actually write, and which parts did you write yourself?

[USER]
A good example is a script which processed the contents of a download from the UK government. Every 90 days we have to rotate some crypto material (certificates, keys etc). This can manually take ~5 minutes or so, however a script could automate the steps and have it take 10 seconds.

I prompted the AI tool with the individual requirements (combining a leaf certificate with the chain, extracting the JWT private signing key etc) which took a few iterations to get correct. This formed the skeleton.

Once that was done, I considered how we as a business may interact with this script. I began to parameterise various components of it, allowing value substitution where useful.

[ASSISTANT]
In that example, did the tool make any mistakes or misunderstand anything in those early iterations, and how did you handle that?

[USER]
Yes. When not being explicitly clear, ie implications are made or assumptions are needed, guesswork comes into play for the AI output. That has to be manually caught, then fixed either through clarification or manual interventionm

[ASSISTANT]
When you spotted that guesswork in the output, what went through your mind in the moment?

[USER]
I tried to apply how I designed the prompt to the output to spot the error. That helps me understand what I may need to clarify in a follow-up prompt, but also learn how to better phrase prompts in the future

[ASSISTANT]
When you were reviewing and correcting that script, what stood out to you about that experience?

[USER]
It was quick and mostly accurate. It would have taken me a few hours to create it, with AI it took seconds.

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved on that script?

[USER]
Picked up other tasks elsewhere in the business

[ASSISTANT]
Did using the tool leave you feeling more confident in the result, or less, and what led you to that judgment?

[USER]
Neither

[ASSISTANT]
How does doing this kind of scripting with the tool compare to how you handled similar work before you had it?

[USER]
It's a time save. If I'm not manually doing it then I still need to understand the output to validate it before it gets used against secure or sensitive materials.

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond scripting, where else has it changed your day to day, either in your own work or in how you lead the team?

[USER]
it being AI?

[ASSISTANT]
Yes, I mean the AI tools like the one you used for scripting. Outside of scripting, has it changed how you lead the team in any way?

[USER]
No, it has no input on the human element of my role

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
As far as I'm aware it hasnt. It's a tool, in the same way a hammer hasn't impacted my working relationships

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Creative problem solving. It's the reason I love my career, handing that over to AI would make it feel pointless.

[ASSISTANT]
What is it about the process of creative problem solving that you most want to keep in your own hands?

[USER]
Going from completely confused to delivering a solution. It's a great element of job satisfaction that would turn my job into a chore if it was given to AI.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI handled that kind of problem solving, how do you think it would change your role on the team or how others see your contribution?

[USER]
It would make me into a principal prompt engineer (tongue in cheek joke). I wouldn't be a leader of problem solving with technology, just a guy who used to solve the problems but now delegates that to an LLM

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Hmm, good question. I suppose I have several tasks that are repetitive related to the continuity/maintenance of services built in the past. I'm a subject matter expert, therefore I'm involved in the upkeep of these services. If I could transplant that knowledge into an AI and automate the crud work, that would free me to be more impactful elsewhere.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes those upkeep tasks feel like good candidates for an AI to take over?

[USER]
They're repetitive, repeatable and validatable stepped procedures. Think: download an item, run the script called X.ps1, check the output, ensure the file Y.pem is structured in Z way.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI handled those upkeep tasks, would it change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
No

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
Being able to decide what you're working on and how it's achieved. You would still be accountable for the delivered work, but being able to choose your own approach or solution would be full autonomy.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from recently where you had that level of choiceâ€”what was the situation, and what choices did you make about what to work on and how to do it?

[USER]
The scenarios we've discussed today have been within those parameters

[ASSISTANT]
How do you tell, at the start of a piece of work, that you actually have that freedom youâ€™re describing? What are the signs you look for?

[USER]
I don't have a set of tools dictated at me to use, just the problem statement and typically a deadline

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re handed just a problem statement and a deadline, whatâ€™s the very first thing you do to set your own direction?

[USER]
Analyze and understand the problem, check affected areas if it's something with an existing system and then begin to formulate an approach. I don't involve AI in this process and never will

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work?

[USER]
No, thank you!

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
When you say interesting, what does that look like for you in day-to-day work? What kinds of problems or situations keep you engaged?

[USER]
My day to day role can include responding to incidents generated by automated monitoring, such as disk space, high cpu, high memory etc. We respond to those by checking the systems manually and resolving the issue. We also deal with requests from end users which is when some particular application isn't working, or we may have to install software. We also periodically patch/update the systems and we also have to install new virtual machines at the request of the customer. Most of this work can be interesting although some of it can also be repetitive.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I prefer to work from home on a full time basis. I have been allowed this flexibility as I am a senior professional. The company policy is for individuals to work from the office at least 2 days per week but they are reviewing this to increase this to three days per week.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

This is because people trust the output of AI but AI isn't always 100% accurate. [ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

For disk space issues, it would need to know what logs should and shouldn't be rotated. The AI would need to be fully trained as person would be.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Maybe AI could do the more mundane tasks, but I would still want to be able to troubleshoot issues. I guess my future role might involve supervising AI's mistakes or double checking AI's work for mistakes.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is troubleshooting the part youâ€™d want to keep in your own hands? What makes that important for you compared to letting an AI handle it?

[USER]
I think that AI can help with troubleshooting, by presenting fixes, but does it have the ability to know which thing will fix a problem if there are 3 or more options? I would always want to have the hands on ability to resolve issues.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I would maybe give up the more mundane tasks, like monitoring CPU and Memory and trying to restart services to free that up.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
They are frequent and boring. Freeing up disk space is also a mundane task, but the AI would need to know what files can be rotated.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, if a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I think a lot of tasks in my field can already be automated, but they aren't at the moment because we haven't got the specific tools to hand in our company. Were we to have them a lot of tasks that could resolve incidents could be automated. Going forward, I'm not sure what the future of my role would be if AI became advanced enough to make decisions about all of the issues that come into us on a day to day basis. I think we have a while to go before AI is capable enough to replace senior engineers - but they can definitely automate a lot more of our job, providing accuracy can be guaranteed.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example of what this looks like in practice â€” a recent situation where you decided how to approach an issue, and how you knew it should be you rather than a tool making the call?

[USER]
We currently have a CIFS mount issue where a job is running slowly. We can't isolate what is causing the issue, but AI has not provided me with an answer. Further troubleshooting such as doing a tcpdump and dtrace on the interface and executable needs to be done manually. AI could potentially do this in the future, but at the moment I had to talk to Red Hat to get that information.

[ASSISTANT]
I can see two ways someone might hear what you just said. One is that itâ€™s about choosing the approach and sequence of steps yourself. The other is that itâ€™s about having the final say and carrying the responsibility for the outcome. Which of those fits better what you mean, or is it something else?

[USER]
I think it is more about choosing the approach to resolve the issue, but it is also about communicating with the customer. The customer describes a problem, but we don't have all of the information so have to go back and forth with the customer to try to gather more information. Could AI do this effectively? Maybe it could. At the moment I am at an impasse with this issue as I have gone back to the customer and asked for information and he hasn't got back to me.

[ASSISTANT]
In that CIFS case, what exactly did you ask the customer for, and how did you decide those were the next best pieces of information to request?

[USER]
I asked him for more details on how his job is slow and how long it has been slow. Whether this was the same in test as it was in production. He hasn't been specific about what job is running slowly. He says the job runs on his PC fast but on the server slowly. This could be some sort of mount point issue. I am still following this case up at the moment.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work right now or might affect it soon?

[USER]
Do you think that AI is guaranteed to be accurate enough for businesses to trust AI to carry out Systems Administration tasks as well as a person with 30 years experience?

[ASSISTANT]
Short answer: no, not guaranteed. Trust in these tools comes from tight scoping, guardrails, and verifiability, not from a blanket promise of accuracy.

In practice, businesses tend to trust AI for narrow, well-instrumented automations with low blast radius and clear rollback, such as:
- Detecting known patterns and proposing fixes tied to vetted runbooks
- Executing remediation behind approvals or in staged environments
- Handling routine maintenance with rate limits, audit trails, and health checks

Whatâ€™s still hard to trust without human oversight are environment-specific diagnoses, ambiguous symptoms, or anything requiring trade-offs across performance, risk, and customer context. Getting to 30-year-expert reliability would require strong observability, policy constraints, sandboxed testing, explicit reasoning you can verify, and automatic rollback if KPIs degrade.

Is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how this is affecting your work right now?

[USER]
At the moment this isn't affecting my work as we haven't really utilised AI to a great extent, but I can see this changing as AI becomes more trustworthy across industry.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. Before we finish, is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work now or could affect it soon?

[USER]
I wonder how AI can talk to the customer and offer a personal touch that humans can. I think that part is currently missing. The chatbots that banks use are often impersonal and not very useful.

[ASSISTANT]
That point about the personal touch comes through clearly. Is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about AIâ€™s impact on your work, or does this cover it for now?

[USER]
I think that covers everything from my side.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for your time and insights. Just to confirm, thereâ€™s nothing else you want to add about AIâ€™s impact on your work?

Thank you very much for your answers! Looking back at this interview, how well does it summarize how experience of AI is changing and might change your work: 1 (it describes poorly how AI might change my work), 2 (it partially describes how AI might change my work), 3 (it describes well how AI might change my work), 4 (it describes very well how AI might change my work). Please only reply with the associated number.

[USER]
I think it describes (3) how it might change my work but isn't at the moment. I feel that over the next few years we will see further developments in AI that will lead to advances in it's use in the workplace.#

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for the rating and for sharing your perspective. I appreciate your time and insights today. A7C9D2QF x7y8

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It was nothing major. Mostly cosmetic - adjusting the tone a bit.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
yeah I think it saves me time. But more importantly it reduces my cognitive load and hence fatigue. I never keep track of what I do with the time saved. I guess I spend it on things that AI can't do, like talking to my team, checking on with clients, etc.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
At first it felt like Magic. I couldn't believe AI can actually do that. I'm old enough to remember AI based on expert systems. LLMs are light years ahead of that. But after a while, I just got used to this magic. I guess I've taken it for granted.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Not sure. I guess it improves them since I now spend a bit more time talking to my team.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]
hello??

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
When you hear those complaints about debugging AIâ€™s code, how do you respond as a manager?

[USER]
I said it wasn't mandatory to use AI. It was only a tool. If they didn't feel like the tool was useful, don't use it. Also, it's probably a good idea to limit the scope of the AI's work. Ask it to write a single function or debug a function. Don't ask it to generate an entire project.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
For my own interest, obviously I don't want to lose my job to AI. But if one day we got ASI and it could do my job perfectly, I guess it's going to take over no matter what.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Maybe the human interaction. I enjoy talking to people.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
In that case I probably would be out of a job.

[USER]
they convey information beyond verbal communication. There's facial expression, body language, tone, etc. AI can't capture that. not yet.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
mostly the admin task. email, memo, performance plan, etc

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am a senior data manager for a health related study at a university in the UK. thank you for having me

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Flexibility in terms of working from home and going to the office, having varied tasks, the ability to progress, having a solid team, working with people who are competent at what they do but also who are good people. Also working in meaningful for for society

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about flexibility, what does that look like in practice for you, say in a recent week?

[USER]
For example, last week I was not feeling too motivated to go in and the weather was not great, so I chose to stay home and work. Other weeks if I felt like it I would go in every day, or go in half days in the office or other at home. I think that is important

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned meaningful for society. Can you tell me about a time recently when your work felt meaningful, and what about it gave you that sense?

[USER]
In one of our interviews the participant said that the interview did really well for them and that they felt heard and they had not felt like that in years. Through this study we are able to directly impact the life of people, through data that drives policy but also sometimes in direct experiences like this one, where we had a connection and the participant was moved and felt helped by what we were doing

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a solid team, can you tell me about a moment that showed you your team has that quality?

[USER]
We had a period of ups and downs in the team, where we were shortstaffed because of illness and maternity leave, which obviously is normal. Those who were still working motivated each other and helped each other out so we could cover and still manage to accomplish what we needed to. And I think that is important because it shows that genuinely I am working with good people but that they are also very competent

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
As a senior data manager I use AI on a day to day basis to complement a lot of the tasks that I do, such as scripts for data cleaning, database building

[ASSISTANT]
In the case of writing scripts for data cleaning or building a database, can you walk me through one recent task and say which parts you did yourself and which parts the AI handled?

[USER]
I mean for example I was working on multiple sql scripts that would help me migrate tables from REDCap databases into a microsoft access environment. I would say that I did it all, but whenever I was unsure of a query or wanted a suggestion, AI would complement what I was doing, as in I would prompt it and then it would help me, but I am experienced in SQL and in both MS Access and REDCap so that is why I feel that for me  I was doing almost all of it and only using AI as a complement tool

[ASSISTANT]
In that SQL migration case, did it ever give you something that didnâ€™t work, and what did you do next?

[USER]
Yeah absolutely, many many times actually. I kept prompting it over and over, rephrasing the question, or even copy pastying what the error was to see if that would make a difference

[ASSISTANT]
When it kept giving you things that didnâ€™t work, what went through your mind in those moments?

[USER]
I guess I was a bit frustrated, but at the same time I wondered whether I had not been clear enough, or if there was anything I could add to make it actually work

[ASSISTANT]
When it does give you a usable query, how do you check it before you run it on your data?

[USER]
I have a test environment, both in REDCap and a separate MS Access instance so I would always run queries on test environments first

[ASSISTANT]
When it does help, what difference does it make to your time or the way you organize the task?

[USER]
It helps tremendously in terms of time because it would probably take me much longer to figure it out without it. And it helps organize because I am essentially having a conversation about what I am doing, which helps me organize things but also learn about what I am doing

[ASSISTANT]
How does using AI affect your confidence in the final result?

[USER]
I don't think it has a direct impact, I would be confident with AI or not. I choose to use it because we should be embracing technology and using it to complement what we do. But whether I use it or not is independent of my confidence. Confidence comes with experience and from learning. Confidence comes from putting effort into things.

[ASSISTANT]
When you save that time, what do you usually put it toward?

[USER]
Other tasks I might have, say admin, or other tickets, or data cleaning

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
Pretty neutral to be honest, AI is something that I used on an individual level to complement my work, I have not really used it in collaborations or in ways that it would affect my working relationships if that makes sense. Its completely independent, until I am in a project where I am producing something with someone and use some AI, but at this point in time since I am working on databases and data and use AI to complement, its separate to my working relationships

[ASSISTANT]
Have you talked with your colleagues or your manager about using it, and if so what were those conversations like?

[USER]
Absolutely, even with my manager. I think with my colleagues its more of a joke as we all use it but not to do everything again its more of a tool on the side. With our manager we actually talked about generating images and how our institution embraces it and we even have paid accounts so, conversations are happening for sure!

[ASSISTANT]
Has using it changed what your manager or teammates expect from you in terms of speed or the kinds of tasks you take on?

[USER]
Not at all, because at this point of time it is up to us whether we use it or not. They don't know what is AI and what isn't. We don't go into detail, as long as things are done and its about quality that is all that matters

[ASSISTANT]
Have you had any moments where using it sparked a misunderstanding or where you had to explain your process to someone?

[USER]
There was one time where I used to complement/help me write some of the code for ICC analysis, and I guess with AI we went one specific way, but we had not considered another factor so the person just wondered whether we could include that. But again, by prompting AI and also understand the needs of the researcher a little better and having a back and forth, we were able to amend the script and get it to do what it needed to do.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
The researcher didn't know that AI was used to complement the code and shape it, so honestly it was the same

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Well its all about integrity with our participants, but also a sense that this is a human study, we are human and we should be in charge, not the computers. Sure, AI and computers can complement us, but we should be leading it as professionals but also as people

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I think it would create some tension in the sense that people would not trust it no matter how perfect it is because LLMs and AI are still programmed

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Probably more admin-tasks that have no sensitive data, for example running vlookups on spreadsheets or when people ask you to generate a dataset from anynymous variables, I think that would be good, again humans need to QC it and I dictate when its done but yeah that would save time

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
They are boring, repetitive, and it would allow me to focus on other more important tasks

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Not at all, because some times those tasks are already given to say people doing placements or more junior, so if anything they would see that I am more focused and involved in bigger, more important things

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I am working on a new data dictionary but obviously its a massive undertaking since we are in the middle of a data collection phase and the study is decades old. [ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
There are several things we would need to consider
a) Your manager and your team. If all of these are good 85% of your job is great
b) Mentorship. Especially from those who are junior or intermediate levels. It makes a difference.
c) Being paid fairly. Wage theft is just wrong, and underpaying people to appease capitalism is very much wrong
d) Depending on the company, leadership needs to have a sane head on their shoulders

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Tells me what I need to improve upon, doesn't do my work for me, but tells me what I need to know, encourages me, etc.

[ASSISTANT]
When leadership has a sane head on their shoulders, what stands out to you in how they make decisions that affect your team?

[USER]
Well I am moving teams sooooo, it would be fulfilling the best interests of the rank-and-file, not their own pockets.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
For sure. So 3-4 reorgs in a month, first it was contractor reductions, second it was denying backfills causing entire release trains to trade devs around, third it was now to have AI-dedicated teams, and now it's consolidation of team management to lower managers and eliminating other management positions

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Since it's the holiday season, it burnt the hell out of me out.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
A slog, real slow. can't think. Just weather the storm until my team transition.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

I changed some details and pasted it in, took the outputs and tested them against a development copy of a database. [ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
In that setup, what does the chatbot handle and what parts do you or your team handle after it creates the ticket?

[USER]
It handles the creation of the ticket and asking the person submitting the ticket clarifying questions to try to get more information so that it is easier for us to troubleshoot.

[ASSISTANT]
When you first started using it, what stood out to you about the quality of the information it collected on those tickets?

[USER]
What stood out is that we got more information about the problem that helped us troubleshoot a lot more.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through one recent ticket where those extra details changed what you did first?

[USER]
one of the tickets said that the monitor wasn't working because of the extra details that said that their was graphical anomalies on the screen first before going black we first checked the graphics card instead of focusing on the monitor

[ASSISTANT]
Has the chatbot ever gathered info that turned out to be off or misleading, and if so, what did you do next?

[USER]
No, it hasn't happened because it mainly just asks simple questions to the person to get more details.

[ASSISTANT]
In that moment when the extra details pointed you to the graphics card first, what went through your mind?

[USER]
That it would be easy to just change out the card and see if that fixed it so it wouldn't take a lot of time.

[ASSISTANT]
When it saved you time on a ticket like that, what did you end up doing with that time?

[USER]
I ended up being able to answer more support tickets and finish my work faster.

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to before the chatbot, how does your workflow on a typical day feel different, if at all?

[USER]
It feels different because we don't have to go find the person who submitted the ticket and ask what the problem with the system is because before they would basically just say it wasn't working.

[ASSISTANT]
Besides the ticket chatbot, has anything else using AI touched your work?

[USER]
No, there isn't really anything else that involves AI in my work right now.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It hasn't because we don't really use AI to interact with each other.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]
I think that it is inevitable since work places will want to implement AI technologies to bring down costs.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I don't think it would change my role on the team it would more so just change the tasks that I focus on.

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am currently a software engineer

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Resolving bugs in a quick and timely manner, assisting customer support, meeting sprint goals

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks. Thinking more generally, beyond those specific tasks, what makes a job good in your eyes?

[USER]
Being knowledge about the product and being about to mentor or assist with a wide variety of questions

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about a really good week at work, what stands out about it for you?

[USER]
Resolving a massive client issue, finishing a difficult ticket or clearing out my queue and being able to come in the next day to pick up tasks always feels good

[ASSISTANT]
What is it about those moments that makes them satisfying for you?

[USER]
It's the satisfaction of knowing that I've finished something difficult, or have a clean slate to pick my next adventure

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
It's constantly being thrown down my throat. It's not necessarily improving my work ethic. It helps for certain things like writing documentation or quick SQL scripts but my main job requires me to think rather than code. So when I attempt to use AI there is a lot of back and forth with it that may end take longer than me actually attempting to conceptualize something alone.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used it to write a quick SQL script? What was the task and how did it go?

[USER]
I asked it take look at the format of two tables that I needed to join to filter a specific type of row out. It was able to quickly provide a script to me within 10 seconds of me sending my prompt

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the script once you got it?

[USER]
I ran it in the DB, it was not a CRUD action. Just a query

[ASSISTANT]
Did the query give you what you needed, and how did you check that the results were right?

[USER]
It did give me what I needed. I asked AI to write the script because I was being lazy but I knew roughly what I wanted

[ASSISTANT]
When you use it for documentation, what parts do you let it draft, and what do you usually add or change yourself?

[USER]
I let it write the entire documentation but correct it as I check over the documents. It is a collaborative experience.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent time you tried using it on one of those thinking-heavy tasks and ended up in that back and forth? What were you trying to figure out, and what happened step by step?

[USER]
I asked it a question about an error that I was seeing in the UI for our application. I provided it with the error and the class that it more than likely originated from. It then began to hallucinate methods and properties that did not exist to explain the issue to me.

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do next to get to the bottom of the issue after you saw it inventing methods?

[USER]
I tried to correct it by stating that it was making up things. But it continued to hallucinate throughout the process. 20 minutes later, I manually debugged the issue myself

[ASSISTANT]
When it kept making things up, what went through your mind, and how did you react in the moment?

[USER]
I got angry and I'm ashamed to admit, I cursed at it in the chat. I'm company is spending millions on this software because "everyone else is" but in my day-to-day it does not help much.

[ASSISTANT]
On the days when it helps with docs or quick queries, what do you do with the time it frees up?

[USER]
I'm able to focus on more tasks, do more debugging, more coding, or answer questions of the juniors on my team.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
It's made the juniors less likely to reach out for help, and has kind of reduced collaboration

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent moment when a junior used it instead of reaching out to you? What happened step by step?

[USER]
A junior we hired recently wrote a new feature to filter record in the UI - something simple that can be mocked up honestly with the built in tools in visual studio. They wrote it all with AI and it came out as jumbled code. Unnecessary, variables, overly complicated conditional statements and lots of them. Needless to say I rejected the PR and sat with them to work on the task

[ASSISTANT]
In that code review with the junior, what stood out to you about the conversation itself?

[USER]
The junior did not know the basics of coding, names or concepts in software engineering.

[ASSISTANT]
How did realizing that change how you approached mentoring them or setting expectations for their next attempt?

[USER]
I realized that I will need to reach out more to them in order to help along. They require more oversight

[ASSISTANT]
Has it changed what your manager expects from you in terms of speed or volume of work?

[USER]
My manager understands my frustration because they also have tried using it. It can be helpful for certain things but they find themself in the same situation as me

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I ideally would love to hand over large portions of my job to AI but right now it's just not ready for cognitive work. Just busy work that requires repetition or writing.

[ASSISTANT]
Even if an AI could truly handle it flawlessly, is there any part of your work you would still want to keep for yourself? Which part comes to mind and why?

[USER]
I like the debugging aspect of my job. I would like to keep that.

[ASSISTANT]
What is it about debugging that you want to keep â€” what makes that part meaningful or enjoyable for you?

[USER]
It's like hunting, tracking your prey. You know what it looks like, where it lives. You just need to catch a glimpse of it

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent bug hunt that sticks in your mind â€” what the trail looked like and the moment you finally â€œcaughtâ€ it?

[USER]
We had an intermediate issue where a client would see records of IDs different to the person that they were running an API call for. Our API calls are all SOAP action, so the client sends a list of parameters to query. What the client was doing was sending an update initially to the records and querying afterwords. They wrote this in their internal tools. I had an idea of this because it was the only way that this could occur logically. I was able to catch it on a call with their devs.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I'd love to give the ticket creation part of my job to AI yesterday

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It's monotonous, and boring.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled ticket creation, would it change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
No, because no one wants to do that aspect either

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
In order to have autonomy, you need to understand how to work through problems. It's not able having the solution. You need to be able to be thrown into a situation where you are clueless and be able to work your way through it, logically.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example of a time when you were thrown into something you didnâ€™t understand and worked your way through it step by step? What did that look like in practice?

[USER]
I did not know how to build jmeter automated tests. i was given a project to build a proof of concept. I had the project manager provide a list of must haves and stretch goals. I set expectations that It would take time to learn how to build tests. I started with small ones getting used to the process, then started to interlink our systems in tests and progressed slowly until I was able to build something that met requirements.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
They break the problem down and work through it in pieces without direction

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
owning the outcome, because at the end of the day you choose whether or not to accept input from others.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Nothing that comes to mind

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
Hi! I work as a business analyst, which means I help teams understand problems, use data, and decide what to do next. I mostly translate between technical people and non-technical people so everyoneâ€™s on the same page.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
A good job should pay enough to live comfortably and make you feel valued. It should also give stability and not leave you constantly stressed or burned out.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a job makes you feel valued, what does that look like in your day-to-day experience?

[USER]
It means my opinions are listened to and my work is acknowledged, not ignored. Simple things like feedback, trust, and basic respect make a big difference.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about stability, what signs tell you a job has it?

[USER]
Clear expectations, regular pay, and not constantly worrying about being let go are big signs. Long-term plans and honest communication also help a lot.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI helps me work faster by summarizing information, checking ideas, and handling repetitive tasks. It saves time so I can focus more on thinking and decision-making.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used it to summarize something at work, step by step? What did it do and what did you do?

[USER]
I pasted a long document into the tool and asked it to pull out the key points and actions. Then I checked the summary against the original, fixed anything missing or wrong, and shared the cleaned-up version.

[ASSISTANT]
In that example, what kinds of points did it miss or get wrong when you compared the summary to the original?

[USER]
It sometimes missed small but important details, like dates or exceptions buried in the text. Occasionally it also oversimplified things that needed more context.

[ASSISTANT]
When you spotted those missed details or oversimplifications, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
I realized it was useful but not perfect. I knew I still had to read things myself and think carefully.

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved on that summary task?

[USER]
I used the extra time to think through the problem more deeply and prepare better recommendations. It also gave me breathing room so I was less rushed.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about a recent time you used it to check an idea. What did you ask it to do, and how did you use what it gave you?

[USER]
I explained my idea and asked if it made sense and what might be missing. I used the feedback to tweak my thinking not to replace it.

[ASSISTANT]
When you review and correct what it produced, how does that part of the work feel to you?

[USER]
It feels like proofreading someone elseâ€™s rough work. It is quicker than starting from scratch but still needs attention.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about a task you used to do without AI, how is it different now from start to finish?

[USER]
It starts faster because I am not staring at a blank page anymore. I still finish by reviewing and shaping the final result myself.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned you shared the cleaned-up version. Who saw it, and what was that interaction like?

[USER]
I shared it with my team and a few stakeholders. The discussion was smoother because the main points were already clear.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about a repetitive task you now let it handle. What did it do, and what did you do around it?

[USER]
I use it to draft first versions of routine emails or notes. I review them quickly make small changes and then send them.

[ASSISTANT]
Has there been a time when what it produced was so off that you set it aside and started over? What happened next?

[USER]
Yes there were times when it completely missed the point or sounded wrong. I stopped using it and just did the task myself from the beginning.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
It has made collaboration easier because information is clearer and quicker to share. It has not replaced conversations but it helps people come prepared.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a specific meeting where people came in with AI-prepared material? What stood out to you about how that changed the conversation?

[USER]
People were more focused because the basics were already written down. The meeting spent more time on decisions instead of explanations.

[ASSISTANT]
Did AI change anything about how your manager or clients judge the quality or speed of your work?

[USER]
Yes there is more expectation that work is done faster now. Quality still matters but speed is noticed more than before.

[ASSISTANT]
Has it changed anything about how you and your colleagues divide up project work?

[USER]
Yes some tasks are done faster so people take on more thinking work instead of admin. It has shifted effort toward review and decision making rather than drafting.

[ASSISTANT]
Has using AI changed anything about who gets credit for work, or how people recognize each otherâ€™s contributions?

[USER]
It can sometimes blur who did what because the tool helped with early drafts. Clear communication still matters so people know who actually shaped the final work.

[ASSISTANT]
Have there been any tensions or awkward moments with colleagues because of how someone used an AI tool? What happened?

[USER]
Yes some people felt others relied on it too much and did not understand the work fully. It caused small trust issues until roles and expectations were clarified.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I would not hand over final decisions that affect people or money. I want a human to stay responsible for judgment and accountability.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is keeping those final decisions in your hands important to you?

[USER]
Because those choices have real consequences for people. I believe humans should stay responsible for decisions that matter.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over those final calls, how do you think it would change your relationships with your teammates or your role on the team?

[USER]
I would feel less trusted and less responsible for the outcome. It would make my role feel smaller and more mechanical.

[ASSISTANT]
Before a decision goes out, what is the last check youâ€™d always want to do yourself rather than have an AI do it?

[USER]
I would always check if it makes sense and feels fair. I want to be sure it will not harm people or cause problems later.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I would happily give it routine admin work like formatting documents and writing first drafts. That kind of work is necessary but does not need deep thinking.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes those admin tasks the ones youâ€™re most ready to hand off?

[USER]
They take time but do not need much judgment. Letting AI do them frees me up to focus on work that actually needs thinking.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled those admin pieces, do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
Yes I think people would see me as more focused on ideas and decisions. It would highlight the value of my thinking rather than busy work.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would say autonomy means you have the freedom to decide how you do your work and use your judgment. It means you are trusted to think and not just follow instructions blindly

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from your work where you felt you had that freedom to decide how to do it, and what you did with that freedom in practice?

[USER]
I was given a problem to solve but not told how to solve it. I chose the approach the tools and the questions to ask and delivered the result my way

[ASSISTANT]
What told you that freedom was real in that situation, not just on paper?

[USER]
My manager trusted my choices and did not step in or micromanage. The work was accepted based on results not on whether I followed a strict process.

[ASSISTANT]
If someone new asked how to build that kind of freedom while using AI tools, what concrete steps would you suggest they take in their first few months?

[USER]
I would tell them to learn the basics well so they understand the work before using AI. They should use AI as support and always explain their thinking clearly so people trust them.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for walking me through all of that. Is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t covered?

[USER]
Overall it feels like a helpful assistant not a replacement. It works best when people stay thoughtful and do not switch their brains off.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
AI makes work faster but also raises expectations. It is useful as long as people stay responsible for the final outcome

[ASSISTANT]
Is there anything else you want to add, or does this capture the main ways AI is affecting your work?

[USER]
This captures the main ways AI affects my work. It helps with speed but still needs human judgment.

[ASSISTANT]

In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Something that allows you to make a positive impact on the world, allows a good work life balance, provides challenge and reasonable compensation

[ASSISTANT]
When you say positive impact, what does that look like in your day to day work?

[USER]
Ultimately the goal of our science is to improve treatments for people with illnesses but there is quite a gap between the work i do day to day and that outcome

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about challenge, what kinds of challenges feel meaningful to you rather than draining?

[USER]
Challenges where I have to think creatively about a problem to get the results needed or collaborate with other to solve problems rather just challenges caused by unreasonable time pressures or administrative delays

[ASSISTANT]
When you say good work life balance, what does that look like for you in a typical week?

[USER]
Being able to work 9-5 (or less), flexibility about when I can do my work to allow for appointments and other life admin, being left with the energy for hobbies and activities outside of work

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I use AI to some extent on a daily basis to help with coding problems. There is also a broader push in the field to include AI in many more experiments

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used it for a coding problem? What was the task and how did you use it?

[USER]
The last time I used it for a coding problem was to help me clean some data in Python where I knew roughly what to do but a fairly complex regex was required so it was much faster to get chatgpt to solve this for me

[ASSISTANT]
In that regex task, what did you handle yourself and what parts did the tool generate for you?

[USER]
I provided the AI with some example values that I wanted to clean and my desired output, it gave me the code to use which I then implemented

[ASSISTANT]
Did the code it suggested work on the first run, or did you have to tweak or iterate on it?

[USER]
I had to iterate on it as there were exceptions that were not originally captured

[ASSISTANT]
When you hit those exceptions, what went through your mind, and how did you handle them?

[USER]
I wasn't particularly surprised, I just then provided chatgpt with some examples of the exceptions that were causing issues and asked it to update the code so that it worked for those as well

[ASSISTANT]
In that data cleaning task, how did using it affect your confidence in the final dataset you produced?

[USER]
I made sure to double check the dataset myself for errors but I was as confident in the final dataset as if I had coded it myself as I don't find regex easy to do

[ASSISTANT]
How did doing that data cleaning with it compare to how you would have done it before without it?

[USER]
It was likely a lot faster than if I had to do it myself which probably would have been more of a multi step process and involve looking up code snippets in other places

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved on that data cleaning task?

[USER]
I was able to spend that time on getting other tasks done

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned a broader push to include AI in more experiments. Can you tell me about a concrete example where that affected the design or expectations for one of your projects?

[USER]
We have not yet incorporated AI into any of our projects

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Occasionally I will ask for help with drafting an email, rephrasing some text or getting it to explain some obscure language#

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I don't think it has had any effect on them yet

[ASSISTANT]
Has it come up in conversations with colleagues or your manager, and if so what were those conversations like?

[USER]
My colleagues generally feel like AI is "over-hyped" and that our organisation is pushing it without a strong plan or guidance to go along with it

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a moment when that push showed up in a meeting or project discussion? What happened?

[USER]
It often has shown up in wider institute seminars where we are shown some examples of things that AI can do and encouraged to use it without the potential limitations really being discusssed

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
If the AI could do it perfectly then no I guess not. But I feel like there are some aspects of my job that would not be possible for an AI to deal with

[ASSISTANT]
Which parts do you think wouldnâ€™t be possible for an AI to handle, and what makes those different from the rest of your work?

[USER]
There are things that occur that are very unexpected (e.g. a shipment accidentally going to the wrong continent) or that require negotiation with colleagues to figure out a non-standard way of working

[ASSISTANT]
When those surprises land on your plate, what do you draw on to navigate them â€” what skills or instincts do you find yourself using?

[USER]
I think generally you need to rely on the fact that most people want to help solve the problem - you need to communicate calmly and start working through options

[ASSISTANT]
In those negotiation or detour situations, if an AI tried to take the lead, what would concern you most?

[USER]
That because it can be a situation that hasn't happened before, they wouldn't have the previous experience to be able to iterate from

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Boring coding things like data cleaning where there isn't any creativity required to get the output, it's just quite mundane

[ASSISTANT]
What makes that kind of data cleaning feel like the right thing to hand off â€” what is it about it that youâ€™d be glad to not do anymore?

[USER]
It isn't something intellectually challenging, it doesn't really require much problem solving but it can take up a huge amount of time without really making much progress

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled that data cleaning, would it change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
I don't think so, no

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I would want to review at least a subset of the output to understand what had been done. I'd also like the AI to outline the steps taken. Potentially I'd also use a test dataset first

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, if a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
To be able to make decisions around what you do on a day to day basis and to be given the opportunity to shape projects on a broader scale as well

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I am able to choose in what order I want to work on what during the day. I have also been able to push for one of our projects to use a specific technology that I think would work best

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I need to have a manager that is willing to trust her employees and give them that freedom

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
She will ask for my opinion on decisions, will not overly micro-manage or hover over my work and is happy as long as the work ultimately gets done
