Interview 117
Username: 5bead56b5324b10001c2551c
Date: 12/12/2025 18:14:28
Duration: 70.85 minutes
--------------------

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am a software test engineer

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
If we are talking i terms of a workplace environment and job roles/tasks then I would have to say  something that gives you a sense of purpose would be pretty high up on my list.  The ability to carry out tasks autonomously without having someone micromanage everything you do and how you do it. Good work colleagues are also worth it.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say a sense of purpose, what makes a job feel that way for you?

[USER]
I suppose it feels like you are actually providing something that people will use and actually benefit from using like in my case, I test healthcare systems so I know that the systems I actively work on directly go towards patient care.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re able to work autonomously, what does that look like in your day to day testing work? Can you tell me about a time that happened?

[USER]
So we work using agile which means we have dedicated meetings each day for daily standups and we have some sessions mid week for refinement of items and sprint planning for future sprints. Outside of this I am free to pick up any task that is available on the sprint board and work on it until its complete, obviously there are estimates for how long a task will take and you generally work towards that but you can be flexible if something goes wrong or in the odd case something goes right and you do it quickly. Previously in my job I used to be assigned tasks by someone else which was not very good because i would often get assigned boring menial tasks that did not challenge me. Now I get to pick and choose (within reason) which tasks I work on and my colleagues will also pick and choose which work they work on. Eventually you have to work on boring tasks however compared to before when I wasnt able to work autonomously it is a significant amount less.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned good work colleagues matter. What makes someone a good colleague in your team?

[USER]
Someone who you can send a message to at any point during the day and they will be happy to respond and even take time out of their day to talk to you or help assist you. Obviously it works both ways you have to be open and available to help them in return but together you can make a good "partnership"  or good team. You dont necessarily have to be friends but Its always nice to have someone there that you can bounce ideas off of or even transfer knowledge. Say you have to pickup a task they have done before, instead of getting lost in the weeds you can just simply ask them for advice and they will more than likely help you out, possiby even give you a head start.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
At the moment I would say we are in the early adoption phase. Most development teams have access to coding tools our organisation currently uses M365 Business copilot or whatever its called (but you can also use other tools as you see fit aslong as you dont share secure/private data), so it is able to help programmers within visual studio using copilot and it is also helpful for people in non technical roles with document generation or analysis and what not. Personally I find that I get alot of use out of AI tools mostly in regards to helping me understand, debug and sometimes write code. Ive also used it for tasks such as creating test scenarios or verification of my work things like that. At this point there isnt a day that goes by where I dont use AI tools.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last time you used an AI tool to debug something in your tests? What did you do first, and then what did the tool do?

[USER]
So I created some gherkin scenarios based on some user stories we had in order to test an API PUT request. I had created corresponding step definitions but i was encountering errors with some of the code. First off, I expained abit of the background about what I was trying to do, what I had currently created and where I was stuck. I then also provided the error message I was provided by the console and pointed it towards the problematic function. The tool then did its thing and was able to spot a problem with the code however because it was missing context its original "fix" was misguided. So I realised that I needed to provide more context which lead to me copying the entire gherkin scenario and then also providing the functions leading up to the error step at this point it was able to understand the problem better and help me come up with some potential solutions which did infact work quite well. The way I generally work with AI tools is to carry out all the steps I outlined above but also to then ask it questions about why this might be the correct solution and if there are any alternatives or drawbacks to it. More often than not it will come up with some things I might not have thought about as alternative solutions or it will give a good reason as to why this solution is the right choice for the scenario.

[ASSISTANT]
In that debugging example, which parts did you do yourself and which parts did the tool effectively handle?

[USER]
I provided snippets of code and a short outline of what I was trying to achieve and just left it to figure out some solutions.

[ASSISTANT]
When its first fix was off because it lacked context, how did you decide what extra information to feed it next?

[USER]
I firstly tried to implement the provided fix and then there are two routes really, either I understand where its gone wrong from here and I change it to fix the problem I was having and then I report back to the assistant that its fix was actually incorrect and brought up another error to which i was able to fix by doing a specific action. At this point we might have a back and forth where it might say good job or we might come up with a better solution together. Or I just give it the new error that I received and let it figure out what I should try to do next.

[ASSISTANT]
When you saw that the first fix didnâ€™t fit the situation, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
Well as Ive done some programming for over 5 years professionally I didnt think too much of it, my initial thought usually is that I didnt provide enough context for it to give me the correct answer or I didnt do a good job explaining what it was that I had already done and what I was trying to achieve

[ASSISTANT]
When the tool suggests a fix that looks plausible, how do you decide whether to trust it before you run it?

[USER]
I can understand the code that its providing me so Im aware of what it will do.

[ASSISTANT]
Has the tool ever given you a suggestion that turned out to be clearly wrong in your testing work? How did you handle it when that happened?

[USER]
Yes it has previously but that was due to me either missing some context or just making a stupid mistake. For instance I had a problem where I was trying to make a PUT request in python and for the life of me I couldnt figure out why it wasnt working. I used an ai tool to help me debug what would be going wrong and i went down quite a long rabbit hole where i spent maybe 2 hours testing various different fixes the tool suggested. In the end it was as simple as I was using ".post" instead of ".put" but neither I or the assistant noticed the very obvious error, it was only after I took a short walk that I noticed it when I sat down

[ASSISTANT]
When you realised it was .post instead of .put, what was your gut response in that moment?

[USER]
"What a waste of time oh well atleast it works now"

[ASSISTANT]
After that two-hour rabbit hole, did you change how you use the tool or set any guardrails for yourself?

[USER]
I remember not so much creating a guardrail for myself but reminding myself not to be so reliant on the tools, and to make sure that I actually put a fresh set of eyes on it to see if i can spot the problem some times before or after asking for help.

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to doing similar debugging without these tools, how has your pace or workflow changed during a typical sprint?

[USER]
It has definetly sped up the debugging process. Previously debugging would revolve around getting an error you dont know or understand and having to search the internet or documentation for a good while until you find something that explains the error or you find someone that has also encountered the same error as you and knows how to fix it Then once fixed you would usually run into another problem and the cycle repeats itself until you fix all instances of an error which could take multiple hours. Now you can simply ask an AI tool, why is this not working and within seconds it can do all the searching that could have taken you hours and give you useful information or even a direct fix for your issue. Its sped up the workflow for everyone I work with

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used a tool to create test scenarios? What did it produce, and what did you end up changing before you used them?

[USER]
So out BA's were testing writing user story scenarios in Gherkin which we could then "use" however as they are new to it they werent exactly capable of being copy and pasted into feature files ready for use. So I gave it the user story detail and then provided the gherkin scenarios and asked it to convert them into gherkin scenarios that would be good for automation. For the most part i was provided with useful scenarios but there were formatting and wording changes I needed to make in order for them to line up with pre-existing test steps/step definitions. I dont think there was even one that I could just "use" as is without editing. But what it did do for me was provide me a good starting point and provided me with some output that achieved everything I wanted it to I just needed to make it match the style we use inhouse

[ASSISTANT]
When these tools speed things up for you, what do you usually do with the time youâ€™ve freed up?

[USER]
Usually just more work I suppose. Its isped up the time it takes to do things so if i complete a user story 3 hours faster than i should have Ill either spend some time on some personal development or just simply go straight into starting my next user story.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
i suppose im asking my colleagues for advice or help alot less than i previously would have because its alot easier to just ask an AI assistant. Theres also the added fact that you can ask it anything no matter how stupid a question it might be and you get no judgement in the response. There are still some times where I will ask my colleageue directly when I know its something they have done before and have knowledge on because sometimes takling to someone can be helpful in building up abit of confidence for a task you arent that confident in. There are no real negatives that I can think of.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent moment when you chose to ask the tool instead of pinging a teammate? What happened after?

[USER]
There havent been many instances of that recently however If i see that my colleague is in a meeting ill just ask the assistant because its always available, rather than waiting for god knows how long until they finish their meeting. Usually I can get past my obstacle but if I need some confirmation from a colleague i can just ask them after implementing a solution.

[ASSISTANT]
Has using these tools changed how you and your teammates do code or test review and share knowledge with each other?

[USER]
I cant say that it has affected that really. We still do knowledge sharing sessions whenever someone has something they want to share with others, whether thats something they learnt on their own or something they learnt with the assistance of AI. Our test reviews currently are done manually and we dont use AI tools just yet for those.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I suppose things relating to data safety as we work with patient data and there are lots of rules around data safety which usually require human approval/intervention.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is that part important for you to keep in your own hands?

[USER]
I mean data safety is the utmost important thing for our organisation. Handing it all over to an AI  that makes its own rules and judgements would be very risky.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI handled those data safety decisions, how do you think it would change your role on the team or the way you interact with others?

[USER]
personally i dont think it would change alot for me. It would however make things quicker and easier to do in general because we wouldnt have to rely on a human to approve things relating to using or accessing specific data which currently is a road blocker for alot of teams and tasks.

[ASSISTANT]
What do you think a person adds in those decisions that a tool might miss?

[USER]
I couldnt tell you. Thats beyond my responsibilities and not something ive had to worry about so im not entirely sure whats so special about their approval either.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I mean hey if it can program all my tests for me why not. I f i could just be there to verify it was doing what we wanted then sure go for it. However it would then make my job probably obselete which would then in turn bring me lots of personal problems like not having a job or stable income.

[ASSISTANT]
What would make handing over the test programming worth it for you, given your concern about your role and income?

[USER]
If there was a guarantee that even with handing over the test programming there were jobs that were created off the back of it that I could transition into.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled most of the test programming, how do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
Well my role would most likely change but I couldnt tell you what my roles would be. Perhaps I would just be in charge or converting BA user stories into prompts for an assistant to create all the scenarios/tests for

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
So to have autonomy in my job today means im being trusted to communicate proactively/effectively, manage my time well and take responsibility for the outcomes of my work. But at the same time I am being given the freedom to, pick the tasks I work on, choose how to work on those tasks and manage my own schedule.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example of a recent day where you did exactly that, from choosing a task through taking responsibility for the outcome? What happened step by step?

[USER]
Most days are exactly that, there are only some mandatory meetings I need to attend which occur at the same time every week. We have a sprint board that tracks work, I simply need to go on there and find a task that is open for testing and neither of my colleagues have started working on and put my name on the task. That task then becomes my responsibility. I am responsible for working on the task, providing updates on the task during our daily standups and managing it until completion when I ultimately have to sign off the item using my own name to say that it is complete. So I am taking repsonsibility for claiming that a piece of work has been tested sufficiently and is ready to be closed off, and in the future if there is a problem with that piece of work I will most likely have to answer for it (although I dont think its entirely negative however it does look poorly upon me should I not do a good job).

[ASSISTANT]
When AI suggests a different way to approach a task youâ€™ve picked up, how do you decide whether to follow its approach or stick with your own plan?

[USER]
If I already know what to do in order to complete the task I will most likely do it the way I know how or if the suggestion from the assistant would end up taking me more time to implement or be overly complex for what it needs to achieve.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about a recent time when you did change course based on the toolâ€™s suggestion. What stands out to you about that moment?

[USER]
Nothing particularly stands out im quite flexible in my thinking so if it genuinly seems like a better idea then ill just do it, im not precious about it having to be something that "I" thought of.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t covered?

[USER]
Nothing further to cover from me.

Interview 118
Username: 6631b5852e5e748863ca2c4c
Date: 12/12/2025 18:14:22

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I work as a Segment Producer / Researcher for a media production company.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
I think something that has tangible meaning. I have worked many accounting jobs that have little meaning, but this role can have an impact.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say tangible meaning, what does that look like in your day-to-day work?

[USER]
We produce shows that warn people of potentially adverse outcomes. I would say you can compare it to Ralph Nader's work, but more media.

[ASSISTANT]
Besides having an impact, what else matters most to you in a good job?

[USER]
The pay matters. Having a tolerable supervisor also matters

[ASSISTANT]
When you think of a tolerable supervisor, what qualities or behaviors make that true for you?

[USER]
I like supervisors who don't fly off the handle, or lose it, or display any type of chest-beating bravado.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I have used generative AI in my research and for brainstorming attempts.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used it for research or brainstormingâ€”what exactly were you trying to do?

[USER]
I was interested in legal verdicts and an insight into the most prominent attorneys and verdicts in various areas of the law.

[ASSISTANT]
In that example, what did you ask the tool, and what did it give you back?

[USER]
I asked for specific attorneys and listings of verdicts in specific areas of the law, such a product liability law.

[ASSISTANT]
What did it return to you, and how did you end up using or checking that information in your work?

[USER]
I was not impressed with the attorney listings. Most of the information was wrong. The response listed many individuals who were in prominent roles but in different industries outside of law. The insights into verdicts were slightly better;  however,  many international cases were presented in the response

[ASSISTANT]
When you realized a lot of it was wrong or out of scope, what did you do next to handle thatâ€”can you walk me through your steps?

[USER]
I did not refine my prompts much. The general sense of incorrect data was enough for me to pause.

[ASSISTANT]
What went through your mind when you saw those mismatches and international cases showing upâ€”what was your gut response?

[USER]
I did not think the data was trustworthy. I also was fascinated by how you can be fooled by responses. I also considered previous non-law queries from the past. I wondered how gullible I may have been in those past non-law queries, too.

[ASSISTANT]
How do you normally research attorneys and verdicts without using these tools, and how did this experience compare to your usual process?

[USER]
I use fairly expensive databases. I have also researched and used many other sources, both free and paid services. Many new AI-assisted legal-specific AI tools are being touted. I have also researched legal AI tools for automating workflows and conducting research.

[ASSISTANT]
Tell me about one recent time you tried a legalâ€‘specific AI toolâ€”what was the task, and how did you use it?

[USER]
I saw an ad for some side work with an attorney. He told me about a workflow AI tool that could streamline his law practice. I studied the tool in depth. I noticed he had some preconceptions that were incorrect regarding costs.

[ASSISTANT]
What parts of his practice did the tool claim it would streamline, and what steps did it say it would handle?

[USER]
He had a divorce practice. There was significant paperwork transmission. The tool addressed such paper pushing and the form-filling process. The tool also had integrations with many standard legal practice case-pleading software products.

[ASSISTANT]
When you dug into that tool, what did you actually test or observe, and what did you conclude about where it would work well versus where it would stumble?

[USER]
At the price point the attorney mentioned, there were advantages. However, the attorney underestimated the API-access pricing. He envisioned using the API access to create a full-process solution. However, the actual cost was prohibitive.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I have been inspired by AI and also automation in general. The potential for productivity gains is clear. I am wary about bad information, and I don't see clear solutions to fact-checking.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a specific interaction with a colleague, manager, or client where AI came upâ€”what was said, and how did that exchange go?

[USER]
I have seen where AI is touted in one area and admonished in other areas. One supervisor touted the use of AI in video creation. However, he complained about using it for research purposes. I think most top management types are unclear about what AI  is and what it can do.

[ASSISTANT]
When you heard that mix of praise and complaints from your supervisor, how did that shape what you chose to use these tools for in your day-to-day work?

[USER]
I don't tell my boss that I use AI and automation tools. He may blame quality issues on the AI. More importantly, he may request a reduction in pay if I simply press a few buttons and have AI do all the work. On a side note, there is a genuine fear in the legal industry that extensive AI use may bring on requests for legal hourly rate reductions from clients.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a specific time you chose not to mention using a toolâ€”what was the situation, and how did you navigate that with your boss or client?

[USER]
I use my research to keep potential productions in the pipeline. When our pipeline becomes less full, my boss gets emotional and panicked. He often requests a more simplified approach. He does not realize that AI can shave 40% off the completion times. So, I hide my AI and automation use from him.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future, is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if it could do it perfectly?

[USER]
My use of automation reduced my stress levels tremendously. I don't think humans should dwell in stress. It also allowed me to be more human by freeing up time to consider potential show topics in a more uniform and less rushed way. So, I think it is best to preserve the layered thinking for humans. However, it is AI and automation that create the extra time to be a human.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is that layered thinking important for you to keep in your own hands?

[USER]
There may be 20 variables in play when making a decision. I don't really see the current interface with AI being able to replicate that type of decision grid.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI did that layered thinking for you, how do you think it would change your relationships with your teammates or your role on the team?

[USER]
I think such a scenario might put me out of a job, or I would be paid a reduced wage to simply perform AI babysitting. That is why I lie to my supervisor. If he knew that AI saves me 20 minutes every hour, he would want that money. He would ask how long it takes me with the use of AI, and he would want to pay me for only that time.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I have to compile contact information. I have toyed with the idea of automating this process. However, it's more complex than it appears on the surface. There were huge shifts during the pandemic, and that required a more human focus. However, I would gladly give that task to AI, and I may write the code soon to automate the process. Some lookup aspects are already automated. On a side note, there are interesting benchmarks surrounding the percentage of a task that can be automated --- the 80-20 split referenced in some papers and books on the subject.

[ASSISTANT]
Why would you like to hand off the contactâ€‘compiling work to a tool?

[USER]
It can do a better job with fewer errors. The trade-off is the time it takes you to streamline the code creation, and testing, and fixing glitches. So, a general feel of how long your employment will continue impacts your tool selections.

[ASSISTANT]
If a tool handled the contactâ€‘compiling for you, how do you think it would change how others see your contribution on the team?

[USER]
They would not notice. It is a minute and small part of the overall process  The bottom line is they would want to pay me less!! I am very wary of that fact.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I think AI and automation. I think relying on your own skills and not delegating everything to generative AI is important, too. Applying my automation programming was an astounding experience for me. I have lots of programming experience from high-frequency stock trading. I applied that to text analysis. It turned a tedious, stressful job into something fun. Most importantly, it put me in control. It enabled me to increase my wage secretly. It gave me great autonomy. The automation made me feel like an independent contractor, with independence and options.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example of a day when your automation changed the way you worked, and what stands out to you about that moment?

[USER]
I was going to quit my job after 2 weeks. Given the production line quality of the job, there was enormous stress when I could not find specific instances that matched the required criteria. I tried to apply automation as a last-ditch effort, and I realized it could work well. It was one of the best experiences I have ever had as an employee.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say it put you in control like an independent contractor, what could you decide or do differently in a typical day that you couldnâ€™t before?

[USER]
I could maneuver. I could make quick adjustments to meet time constraints. I had more options to meet my work obligations. The automation shaved 40% off my workload and completion times. However, my stress levels went down by 90%!!

[ASSISTANT]
I hear two possible meanings in what youâ€™ve said. Do you mean having the freedom to choose your own tools and pacing to hit goals, or do you mean having the final say on the content and standards of the workâ€”or is it something else altogether?

[USER]
I mean maneuvering. I have to analyze a document that is 1000s of pages with minimal interface options. The tools I use enable me to work with greater control. I have control over the document and the pages.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through one specific script or workflow you built that let you â€œmaneuverâ€ inside those thousandâ€‘page documents, and what you actually did with it on a real piece of work?

[USER]
I am able to expand upon the interfaces available to me. I can act upon criteria requests that are imposed on me. I have greater sorting and filtering capabilities. I can adjust to different time zones and time constraints. One specific insight is my ability to pick out specific case types and similar information that is not possible through the interface of the database.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for sharing all of this. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to add about how AI has affected your work that we havenâ€™t talked about yet?

[USER]
No.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you very much for your answers! Looking back at this interview, how well does it summarize how experience of AI is changing and might change your work: 1 (it describes poorly how AI might change my work), 2 (it partially describes how AI might change my work), 3 (it describes well how AI might change my work), 4 (it describes very well how AI might change my work). [USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I am an IT Operations Manager

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€“ in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Clear hours, well paid, good benefits

[ASSISTANT]
When you say clear hours, what does that look like for you day to day?

[USER]
I prefer a solid 9-5.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Perks mostly. holiday pay, pension maybe, sick leave

[ASSISTANT]
When you say well paid, what tells you the pay is at the right level for you?

[USER]
When all my bills are paid, and I'm able to save some every month

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
It impacts it though not as much as many think. I use AI to help with things like scripting, and batch files where a single syntax error can make it all fall apart. I might use it sometimes for some research, though I have to be very careful that it doesn't make things up. I've also used it to help me come up with a better way to say something when I'm making an email and I need it to sound a certain way

[ASSISTANT]
In that scripting example, which parts did the AI handle and which parts did you do yourself?

[USER]
I usually feed the AI what I want the script to do, and what I have for the script already. Then have it finish it off or make it better

[ASSISTANT]
When the AI finishes or improves a script, does it ever get things wrong, and if so how do you handle that?

[USER]
It hasn't yet. I usually get scripts far more wrong than the AI does

[ASSISTANT]
When you get a script from the AI, how do you test or review it before you run it in your environment?

[USER]
Honestly, I don't.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Nothing really.  I have yet to find any incidents of an AI model making a script that does 'bad'. Usually the scripts have mostly been written by me but aren't working, so I can glance over the AI generated script and see what I did wrong

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned being careful with research because it can make things up. Can you tell me about a time that happened and how you spotted it?

[USER]
I was researching some equipment purchases, new switches for an office. I was looking into cloud managed switches. The AI (ChatGPT) fed me some names and one I knew had gone out of business two years before.

[ASSISTANT]
When you realized the model listed a company that had shut down, how did that change the way you use it for research going forward?

[USER]
It just meant I had to make sure to double check most things. It was still a bit faster than doing it all on my own, but I did spend a decent amount of time making sure things were accurate

[ASSISTANT]
When the AI helps you spot what went wrong in your script, what stands out to you about that moment?

[USER]
That I'm bad at scripting and it's why I'm not a programmer

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It's almost always the following format: I write the email fully myself.  with all the needed information. But it tends to come across as a bit stiff and cold. I will usually copy the email into the AI I'm using and ask it to make it warmer and more personable.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It always reads a bit trite to my ears, but I know I'm cynical and ignore that sort of stuff often

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
It hasn't really. It's just another tool to me

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Occasionally. Most of them were fine. There's a few outliers in both ways. Some who put AI on a pedestal, and those who hate AI with passion. Most are like me, just another tool that is useful in certain areas to fill in places of weakness

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Not that I've been aware of

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Network Optimization

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I'd always want a backup config that *I* took so I could roll back if needed.

[USER]
That the autonomy in IT is still there. Honestly, most people are sort of still intimidated by tech, and are generally happy to have us fix their issues. As long as you can be somewhat personable, and you narrow down to a few skills and excel at those, you can go far.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
that it all gets done,  triage the easy things that affects users day to day, then move into longer term things

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI actually greatly helps me work.  I've been able to use AI to get things done quicker and take some of the load off.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I had AI help me automate some onboarding emails that we send out.  We used to do these manually but AI helped me automate this so less human interaction is needed.

[ASSISTANT]
In that onboarding email automation example, which parts did you design and which parts did the AI generate?

[USER]
I just designed the basic template for the email, AI helped to show me how I can automate that by inputting the names and addresses I need as well as sending that.

[ASSISTANT]
When you first set that up, did anything go wrong or come out odd, and if so, how did you handle it?

[USER]
Yes.  At first I ran into an issue with the script that AI provided me.  It was having issues actually sending the email.  I took a look at it and figured out the issue so I was able to get that fixed.   I can also credit part of the fix to AI, as it helped me with that new script.

[ASSISTANT]
When you hit that sending issue, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
I really just wanted to get it resolved right away.  I was a bit frustrated but I was determined to fix it.

[ASSISTANT]
How did doing the onboarding emails this way compare to your process before you brought AI into it?

[USER]
It has saved a lot of time.  Sometimes we have to send out 50+ emails out to new users.  This can take a lot of time doing it manually.   Now it is very fast and something I don't dread doing.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I just use this time to work on other projects.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Another task would be Airtable integration.  We just started using Airtable instead of Excel and I asked AI to help me with that.

[ASSISTANT]
In that Airtable case, what did you ask it to help with, and which parts did you end up doing yourself versus what it produced for you?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I think humans can solve these issues quicker.  I also think you need that human element to help understand what's going on and be empathetic towards them.

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent support interaction where being there in person or live made a clear difference in how it turned out? What stands out to you about that moment?

[USER]
A recent time that being in person made a difference was when I was helping an executive at my work.  Some executives can be hard to work with because they are very busy and want fast results.   Based on my previous experience with them, I remembered that they aren't the best at reguarly restarting their computer.   Luckily the issue they were having was just some stuck updates so a simple restart was able to fix their issue.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Granting software access.   This is something my company still doesn't manually for the most part.   I really hope AI can take this over soon.

[ASSISTANT]
Why would you like to hand over granting software accessâ€”what makes that the right task to give up?

[USER]
It's something that can be automated very easily.  Our process is that the user requests the software, then it goes through any approval needed and then the access is granted.  I don't really see a need for a human in all of this.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled granting software access, do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
No I don't think it would.   I don't think the average user understand the process for software access.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would tell them that autonomy is actually a very important part of this job.  You need to be able to kind of be your own boss and know what you need to do next.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from a recent day where you â€œwere your own bossâ€ â€” what decisions you made without checking in, and how you decided what to tackle first?

[USER]
Really that's kind of my job everyday but an example would be when you first sign on for the day.   The average tech worker has a ton of tickets, calls, and emails to go through.  It's your job to figure out which ones are the most important and what to work on first.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re sorting those tickets, calls, and emails, what cues do you rely on to judge urgency and importance in the moment?

[USER]
If they currently cannot do their job at all because of the tech issue, then this would be an urgent task.   If it's something like their screen isn't as bright as they'd like, this is something that can wait.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about everything youâ€™ve said, has using AI changed what â€œbeing your own bossâ€ looks like in your role, and if so, how?

[USER]
Yes I think AI has given me more freedom.  With the AI knowledge, that can help me with the basic tasks so I can work on more urgent tasks.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a specific day when AI took some basic tasks off your plate and how you used that spaceâ€”what you did first, then next?

[USER]
Sure.  Going back to the onboarding emails, a few weeks ago we had a ton of emails that needed to go out.  Luckily AI's helped with that gave me more time.  With this time I was able to get a head start on the next weeks onboardings.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t covered?

[USER]
I'd just like to say I think AI has been very positive in my job and I'm thankful for it.  I'm very curious to see where it goes in the future and I really hope it doesn't steal my job lol.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
That's it.  Thanks

Interview 122
Username: 6777feb0d25d8a20d7e7e790
Date: 12/12/2025 18:12:10
Duration: 32.88 minutes

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I work in software development.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
A good job has scheduling freedom, regular hours, and high pay.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say scheduling freedom, what does that look like for you day to day?

[USER]
Being able to easily reschedule around sudden events easily or flexible hours which aren't restricted to a single shift.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say regular hours, what does that mean to you in practice?

[USER]
Reliable weekly full time hours and/or consistent available which allow for confidence in the work and prevent confusion.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say high pay, what does that mean to you in practice?

[USER]
Enough to live comfortably and have money left over for myself. An amount that prevents me from being concerned about my finances.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
Ai is often used in software to speed up production and handle repetitive time consuming tasks. However, more and more people are using it to replace their own work, in other words to get away with lazyness, and more and more companies are using it to replace employees at the cost of product quality.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent task where you used AI in your own work, and walk me through what you did and what the AI did?

[USER]
I converted a list of values into a table by telling an AI to reformat the information. Unfortunately, I have a hard time trusting results so I still had to manually check the whole thing . It still did save time in the end though, which is part of the problem.

[ASSISTANT]
When you reviewed the table, did you notice any specific errors or patterns you were watching for, and how did you handle them?

[USER]
I didn't find any errors that time, but that doesn't mean there won't be any next time. Usually the errors involve faulty lines or missing information. Hallucinations are also extremely common, but not in that particular task.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re deciding whether to use it on a task like that, what goes through your mind?

[USER]
Its almost always a question of efficiency. Can I do this faster or cheaper using AI than a traditional method. Or if I'm told to by the higher ups.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time it hallucinated or left out information on a work task, and what you did in response?

[USER]
The most common hallucination event is when performing a tasks that spans two different version updates. AI gets very easily confused about which features have been removed or added. In other words, it has a hard time maintaining the concept of permanency or internal consistency. The only thing I can do in response is manually review it ever time.

[ASSISTANT]
When you realize you have to manually review it every time, what stands out to you about that experience?

[USER]
It's annoying to check for hallucinations because it's a tedious process that is sometimes hard to verify. I wish AI could maintain better internal memory.

[ASSISTANT]
When it does save you time, what do you typically do with that reclaimed time?

[USER]
Additional work productivity.

[ASSISTANT]
How does doing a task with AI compare to how you handled the same kind of task before you started using it?

[USER]
When I perform tasks myself I usually have to spend time learning and adjusting before I can perform the task as a satisfactory level of quality or speed, but the AI will generally perform the same way from the first time. That can be a good thing or a bad thing.

[ASSISTANT]
In a recent project, where did you draw the line between what you let the AI generate and what you kept for yourself?

[USER]
Almost any time we have a task that involved the AI gathering information for itself, such as collecting search results or performing a web search, I throw out the entire thing and do it myself. Performing tasks with internal data or premade data tables is generally reliable but external data is almost always unreliable or contains hallucinations. You can check this by attempting to use the Google Search AI summary. 99% of the time it is completely and utterly false information.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
Ai has caused significant problems with socialization both in and out of the office. People won't write their own texts, emails, or reports anymore and will instead have AI do it. Harming their literacy and communication skills.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent interaction where you suspected a message was AIâ€‘written and it changed how the exchange went? What happened?

[USER]
Almost all in office emails and memos, and reports. There is no official policy on the subject yet so there's not really anything that can be done about it, and if I confront the individual they simply deny it or change the wording later.

[ASSISTANT]
How has this shift affected trust or coordination on your team?

[USER]
People were always the most unreliable part of an organization, but it's hard to trust people have proper understanding and competency if they can't even exchange communications on their own.

[ASSISTANT]
What conversations, if any, have you had with your manager about how and when to use these tools?

[USER]
None, because they do it to, which often leads to vague or unclear instructions.

[ASSISTANT]
When you get vague or unclear instructions that you suspect were AIâ€‘generated, how do you respond to move the work forward?

[USER]
I simply perform my tasks anyway and let the company deal with the repercussions, which is usually performing extra work later at cost.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Managing employee accounts, personal data, account access, passwords, security etc. It is so unbelievably easy to manipulate and trick AI. It is the opposite of safe and secure.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes you want to keep that responsibility yourself?

[USER]
To maintain the confidentiality, integrity, and security of information.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a time you saw an AI get manipulated in a way that would worry you if it had access to accounts or sensitive systems?

[USER]
Any time you talks to AI, as long as you carefully phrase things, you can get them to say or do mostly anything.

[ASSISTANT]
If someone proposed using an AI for parts of account or access management, what would you need to see or test to even consider giving it limited responsibilities?

[USER]
I wouldn't even consider it to begin with until the far future where I've seen proof it's secure, or the concept of AI has changed completely. Currently the way AI works, there's no way to remove or partition off data in a reliable way.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Not sure, maybe collecting daily reports so I could have it all in one place easily at the start of the shift, if I could trust it was providing an accurate change log.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes that reportâ€‘gathering worth offloadingâ€”what would you gain if an assistant handled it reliably?

[USER]
It would save a lot of time. It's an extensive amount of work to shift through and organize daily progress reports, especially when working with a code base.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled that report gathering, do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
Not really, that's not the primary role I perform.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
The ability to choose my work format, for example whether I work from home or in office, as well as the ability to perform my job in a way decided by me without direct supervision beyond regular check ins, updates, and task assignments. In other words, a good employee with a high degree of trust.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example from your job where you had that kind of autonomy, and walk me through what you did and how it played out?

[USER]
I was given a month to create a white paper report on a solution to a proposed software solution. Basically what the company could do to serve a client's needs, and present it for review.

[ASSISTANT]
In that white paper project, what were the key decisions you made on your own without asking for signâ€‘off, and what happened as a result?

[USER]
I presenting the software solution, how we could design it, and how it would perform the requested role. It was basically a product design document presented for review by the board.

[ASSISTANT]
In that project, how did you set your own process and checkpoints, and what told you that you were free to proceed in your own way?

[USER]
I designed the entire document from the ground up with no overview aside from the deadline.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for walking me through that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work that we havenâ€™t covered?

[USER]
Not really. I'm worried about people's job security especially in the creative arts where people can dump out literally infinite slop to replace artists work.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you very much for your answers! Looking back at this interview, how well does it summarize how experience of AI is changing and might change your work: 1 (it describes poorly how AI might change my work), 2 (it partially describes how AI might change my work), 3 (it describes well how AI might change my work), 4 (it describes very well how AI might change my work). [ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I'm a UI/UX engineer, but I also teach on the side.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
A good job allows flexibility, has good time off, good coworkers, and allows you to work at your own pace.

[ASSISTANT]
Of the things you mentioned, which one matters most to you right now, and why?

[USER]
Being able to work at my own pace.

[ASSISTANT]
What does working at your own pace look like for you in practice, day to day, in your engineering and teaching roles?

[USER]
It means I can work at night if I want to or during the day. It means I don't have set hours, just deadlines.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I use AI everyday, mostly to improve my communications, including emails.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last email you drafted with AI, step by step, from your first prompt to sending it?

[USER]
I copy and pasted the email into ChatGPT then I asked for a small response and it gave me one. I edited it to my liking and used it.

[ASSISTANT]
In that email, what changes did you make to the AIâ€™s draft before you sent it, and what led you to make those edits?

[USER]
I changed some words around and fixed the spelling. AI often makes errors, so it needs to be constantly edited.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example of an error it made in that draft and how you caught it?

[USER]
Yes, it hallucinated a fact about a company I was emailing. I had to correct it.

[ASSISTANT]
What went through your mind when you spotted that mistake?

[USER]
"AI sucks" because it is mostly inaccurate. It still has use cases, but it is nowhere near as good of a tool as the techbros are hyping it up to be.

[ASSISTANT]
When you use it for messages now, how do you check the information before you hit send?

[USER]
I read through the entire message that AI gives me.

[ASSISTANT]
How has using it changed the time you spend on email compared to before?

[USER]
It allows me to spend less time on email, but also it just makes my communication sound more professional.

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond email, where else do you use it in your engineering or teaching work?

[USER]
It helps me grade student assignments. It also helps me code and find bugs in the code.

[ASSISTANT]
Take the grading first. Can you tell me about the last assignment you graded with help from AI, and exactly how you used it in that process?

[USER]
Yes, I graded essays. I would copy and paste parts of the essay into ChatGPT and just ask for it's opinion on what the grade should be based on the assignment prompt.

[ASSISTANT]
When it suggested a grade, how did you decide whether to accept it or change it?

[USER]
I used my own judgement and adjusted the grade up.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
AI makes my communication better in general, so I think it improves my working relationships.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a specific interaction where the clearer wording changed how the conversation went? What happened?

[USER]
Yes, I recently had a student email me that was having a hard time. I made sure the communication was kind, as well as professional. I think it really made a difference.

[ASSISTANT]
What did the student say in response, and how did it shape what happened next?

[USER]
The student was grateful for my support and it shaped the positive outcome.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Yes, anything art related or anything related to a final product. Human creativity cannot be replaced in my opinion and AI requires constant oversight. Nobody should be using anything AI outputs without reviewing it carefully first.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is keeping the art and final product in your own hands important to you?

[USER]
Humans need to be valued higher than computers or there's no point to our existence.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI handled the art or the final product, how do you think that would change your role with your team or with your students?

[USER]
I think it would do a poor job with both and that would lead to major issues. I don't think it would change my role because I don't think it's capable of replacing what I do.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
summarizing things, like papers, books, emails, etc.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It's really good at summarizing long amounts of text.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled the summarizing, do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team or your class?

[USER]
No, I think summarizing just helps me be better at my jobs directly.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
Autonomy means having the final say, the final approval. It means being able to change anything related to final communication, final product. It means AI is a tool to be used, an assistant to make you (the human) better at your job.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a recent example where you exercised that final say on a project or message, what you changed, and why it mattered to you to change it?

[USER]
Yes, I recently finished a small coding project. AI helped a lot, mostly with debugging. However, I had the final say on the overall design, the overall end project that I presented. I did change quite a bit that AI had suggested because it just wasn't what my human judgement said was correct. It mattered to me to change it because it made the end product much more me.

[ASSISTANT]
For someone new to your field, what habits would you recommend so they keep that final say when they use AI on a project?

[USER]
Always review all AI output very carefully. If you think something isn't right, change it. Use other resources, including other people, to make sure your end product is human-centered.

[ASSISTANT]
I can see two ways someone might hear what you said. One is choosing the goals and the plan. The other is the final wording and design details. Which is closer to what you mean, or is it something else?

[USER]
Final wording and design details. Goals and plan is good to have obviously, but it's the end product that matters most.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am an IT manager for a textile manufacturing company

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
I think a good job means completing something in a way which means the tasks is fully completed and doesn't have to be revisited or corrected in the future

[ASSISTANT]
Besides getting something right the first time, what else matters to you when you think about a good job?

[USER]
I mean more a sense of once the job is complete, it is done to such a standard that you almost don't have to think about it anymore. Or that you do not have to go back to rework on it, or have someone else have to finish it for you. It should also show some kind of progress, after finishing a job well, there should be a feeling like you have "moved forwards"

[ASSISTANT]
When you say moved forwards, what does that look like in your role?

[USER]
So for me that could mean something like refreshing out computer hardware. If that is our job, once we have completed it, we can see the progress we have me

[ASSISTANT]
When a job is done well in your world, what do you notice in your day or from others that tells you it hit that standard?

[USER]
There is a feeling of satisfaction, definitely. Seeing others act grateful for the work you've done or give you approval can be very fulfilling and encouraging for me

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
The main impact of AI so far has been giving me more free time in the day to do more important managerial work. It feels like having an extra member of staff that I can give simple work to

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used it at work and what specific task you handed over to it?

[USER]
Most recently I have been using it to scan our systems monitoring logs so that I don't have to do it myself in detail. It finds things like errors or odd activity and turns it into a summary for me to read, essentially

[ASSISTANT]
In that example with the monitoring logs, what parts did it handle and what parts did you still do yourself?

[USER]
I decided the data points that I wanted to monitor and set up the overall process initally and I also still personally review the summary and go into further depth if I think it is needed. The AI collects all of the data points and looks for anything unsual. It the turns that information into a fairly simple summary for me to rea

[USER]
read

[ASSISTANT]
Has it ever flagged something that turned out to be noise, or missed something important? What happened in that instance?

[USER]
Yes there has been examples of both although they are quite rare. It has flagged for irregularities  occasionally during data syncs that may take a bit longer than usual but I was able adjust the thresholds for detection and it seems to be working so far. The biggest miss so far was during a system backup in which it was reported as a "partial success" and the AI didn't detect that it was an error. We had to manually backup certain files after we noticed the gap, we then updated our prompt to try and avoid this in the future

[ASSISTANT]
When you discovered that backup miss, what went through your mind and how did you react in the moment?

[USER]
I felt quite surpised that it had missed it and it also made me think about how much more cautious I should be when using the AI in the future. It was a fairly minor issue that didn't take long to correct, but if it had missed something else it could've had much worse consequences

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about this past week, what did you do with the time you didnâ€™t spend on detailed log review?

[USER]
Mainly planning for 2026 and working more closely with my team members. As a company we have been planning infrastructure upgrades for some time now, so having extra hours to properly focus and plan out the next year has been realy helpful. Especially when it comes to working with other departments

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond the log summaries, are there other parts of your job where you use it?

[USER]
I often use it for things like drafting emails or communication posts. It saves me a lot of time writing things from scratch every day. I also use it to review documents or contracts to highlight key things, again saving time. I have been using it more for planning recently too. I will give it rough ideas for projects and it is able to organize things in a way which makes them much easier to think through

[ASSISTANT]
When you use it to draft emails or posts, what do you usually keep as-is and what do you tend to rewrite yourself?

[USER]
Usually I will change the tone or certain words as AI always seems to have a particular way of writing. Even if it doesn't change the information, it makes it seem more human and less perfect. I also usually add some personal details that the AI won't know unless I give it specific instructions. I nearly always keep the same email structure as I think it does a superb job of that. I also don't tend to overly edit summaries as I think it is hard for me to improve them

[ASSISTANT]
When you hand these tasks over to it, do you feel more confident in the end result or less, and what makes you feel that way?

[USER]
I feel much more confident most of them time. I was skeptical initally but AI has been very consistent at giving me high quality responses, it is hard to deny how effective it is when used correctly. I am  still happy to work without it, but I definitely feel more secure when using it

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I think overall it has slightly improved them as I have more time and am less rushed than I was before. I feel more calm and relaxed so it can be very helpful to boost morale slightly. It has been very helpful when talking with other departments too as I can work at a faster pace and explain things to them in a clearer and more organized way when I use AI to help me

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent interaction with another department where using it changed how the conversation went? What stands out to you about that moment?

[USER]
I was recently in contact with finance as they were having issues with their software and they had sent me a fairly long message explaining the problems they were having. Before I would have briefly skim read the message and most likely said I will come to see what was wrong at some unplanned part of the day when I was free. But I put the message into AI, asked it summarize the issues and concerns  and then make a response with some simple suggestions where it was appropriate. What stood out was how fast and easy the process was. Everything was so much faster and more efficient than if I had to do it all myself

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if it could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I wouldn't want the AI to be making final decision on big projects. As much as it can be helpful, I still think people should stay in charge of things like this. I would also not want AI to be involved in dealing with team members. If people are having issues or problems, I wouldn't want them to have to interact with an AI to fix them

[ASSISTANT]
What is important to you about keeping the final call on big projects?

[USER]
I think it is important that people are responsible overall. If AI makes the final call on a big project and it goes wrong, nobody can really learn or account for the mistakes being made

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI made the final call on a big project, how do you think that would change how your teammates see you or how you see your responsibilities?

[USER]
It would make me seem less responsible and trust worthy as a manager. If I was willing to let AI make choices like that, I would basically be making myself useless

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I think it is important that these things are handled with empathy and understanding. I know that AI can in theory deal with emotional issues, but I think it is more appropriate for humans to interact with each other than rely on an AI

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Any type of log scanning, email drafting or document preparation. AI has shown it is very good at these tasks, so if I never had to do them again I would be happy

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
They are things that AI is very good at and that can be done efficiently. It can take workers a long time to complete this kind of work

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over those tasks entirely, would it change how others see your contribution at work, or how you see what you bring to the team?

[USER]
I don't think so as this type of work is more about saving time than anything else

[USER]
I would say it is about having control over how you spend your time and how you choose to complete your work and solve problems

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I pretty much do that every day being that I am the infrastructure architect, and the lead engineer. Normally, I have a deadline and as long as I make that deadline, no one bothers me. I don't have anyone telling me how to do it, that's actually my job.

[ASSISTANT]
In that last problem you led, can you walk me through one trade-off you had to weigh and how you decided which way to go?

[USER]
We are moving everything from our race floor into the cloud, but we do have some programs that require on site storage since our enterprise storage was all going to cloud I just needed a very inexpensive solution to keep on the floor. The choice we had to make prior to that is do we force everybody into the cloud or do we keep something on prem, and then back it up to the cloud. We have a department that creates a tremendous amount of very large files, images, etc. having them come into the office and upload to the cloud would've taken too long so we just have them drop it onto the on premise storage that we create a solution for. Then it backs up, so we still have it in the cloud, but it's done at night when the customer is not affected.

[ASSISTANT]
For someone new coming into your field, what would you tell them to doâ€”or avoidâ€”so they can earn that level of trust today, especially with AI in the mix?

[USER]
raised floor

[USER]
Not realy I think. we covered alot

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
Hello, I'm a data engineer and automation specialist

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
I think it matters a lot whether you like what you do and whether your role allows you to work on what you like. Also, of extremely importance is the environment and management which should make you feel appreciated and work with calm without being excessively pressured

[ASSISTANT]
When you say working on what you like, what kinds of problems or projects give you energy? Can you share an example?

[USER]
I like working on something end to end, especially if it is a solution that I proposed or thought of. For example last year I came up with an idea to automate some internal activities we have to do every time there is a holiday event. I proposed it, developed it, tuned it and improved it. And everybody loves it

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about feeling appreciated and being able to work with calm, what does that look like day to day for you?

[USER]
I'm happy when someone in the team appreciates what I'm doing and recognises my effort and good work, like for example mentioning something that I did well during our daily stand-up. Also, I like to work in an environment that gives me the time and resources needed to do my job in the best possible way. Quality is better than quantity in my opinion

[ASSISTANT]
If you had to pick the single most important ingredient that makes a job good for you, what would it be, and why?

[USER]
Strong company values which make an environment relaxed and pleasant

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
I have recently started a new adventure as I'm learning how to develop Copilots

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through the last Copilot you worked on, step by step?

[USER]
I've just started and I'm working on my first Copilot agent. It will be a Copilot agent to help our team automating some internal activities. The first use case is to generate a release plan and posting it to a Teams channel, the agent will first gather some required information from the user

[ASSISTANT]
In that workflow, which parts will the agent handle and which parts do you expect to do yourself?

[USER]
That should be, if it works as expected, all handled by the agent. Of course than the user will interact with the release plan and make changes to it

[ASSISTANT]
What information does it need to collect to draft the release plan, and where will it pull that information from?

[USER]
For now it will just need some basic information such as which product the release is for and what version number it is so it knows how to name the plan and the tasks properly. In the future I might enhance it to also schedule tasks, assign them to people, populate calendars etc, but for now this is not needed

[ASSISTANT]
Before starting this project, how did you and your team create and share a release plan without an agentâ€”what were the steps?

[USER]
It was all manual, in Teams a new channel was manually created, then add a tab to it, choose Planner app, create a new plan and add manually all the release tasks

[ASSISTANT]
Since this is your first agent, what has it been like to design it so farâ€”what stands out to you about the experience?

[USER]
It's not very easy  because I'm missing the experience, which I'm hoping to build up as I proceed, but as it is quite a simple use case I'm proceeding pretty well so far. What I don't know very well for now are the best practices

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re unsure about best practices, what do you do to figure things outâ€”where are you looking for guidance, and what has helped most so far?

[USER]
I'm googling and using ChatGpt, however I'm not always find the best information, as many times what applies to others doesn't apply to your use case

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent moment when the guidance you found didnâ€™t fit your situation, and what you did next to get it working?

[USER]
Part of the automation required to call an API to pin the newly created plan to a Teams tab. Microsoft changed the way this API endpoint works, with very little official documentation on what values to provide to it. Information on the internet  and on ChatGpt was so confusing as everybody was saying a different thing, information was outdated, etc., only one version of the information was right, which I just found today after a few days of frustration.

[ASSISTANT]
When you finally found the version that worked today, what went through your mind?

[USER]
I was so happy, I kind of already gave up and accepted a compromise as I previously found a solution that didn't do what I wanted but it was close enough. This morning I found a recent post and I decided to give it the last go. That worked, I'm happy I tried

[ASSISTANT]
Once this agent is in place, how do you expect your release days to feel different compared to the fully manual way you described?

[USER]
It won't be a game changer as it will just saves a few minutes of manual work, but it's the first of probably a long list, so no matter how helpful it is, the important thing is to have it published so that we can start using it for other things as well

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
It didn't affect any relationships, for now it is just helping optimising processes

[ASSISTANT]
What conversations have you had with your teammates or managers about introducing this agent?

[USER]
I know we are planning to have a customer facing virtual agent in a year or so, so as I'm already familiar with the Power Platform family it seemed like a good idea to expand my knowledge on Copilot, so I took the opportunity and volunteered for the future project, informing them that it would be beneficial for me to start gaining some knowledge on some easier internal agents.

[ASSISTANT]
What response did you get from your manager and teammates when you volunteered to take this on?

[USER]
They seemed pleased with me volunteering

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I believe that somebody should keep an eye on what AI would and could do in the future, so I would want to have a supervisory role on AI solutions. Also, I wouldn't handle our customer's data over to AI

[ASSISTANT]
What makes that supervisory role important for you to keep?

[USER]
A sense of control, I want to be able to switch off the solution, or to make changes to it, or checking if it's doing what's been built for

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI were doing the oversight itself, how do you think that would change your role on the team?

[USER]
I would not allow that to happen I think

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned not handing customer data over. What concerns are top of mind for you there?

[USER]
Customers pay us to protect their data, I want to have control over what it is happening to it. An AI system could use or misuse data or interpret it wrongly.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
For example in today's example, I would have liked that a reliable AI system produced the correct code for me to use in that API action, while ChatGPT failed to do that, it just gave me a lot of different versions of it, all wrong, making me waste a lot of time time. At the end the right solution I found it myself on a specific post on the internet.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
First of all, making sure that is up to date with all the latest versions of software, APIs and components

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I don't think they would see me differently, as anyway I'm the one who needs to know how to use that code, how to generate the logic, how to design your workflow in the way that it works for us.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
To me it means to be able to choose how to do your job, having the freedom to propose alternative solutions or ways of working and having someone open to listen to your creative ideas and happy to support you to pursue them

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I explained how the new technologies could benefit the team, giving them real examples and showing them real POCs. They always liked those ideas so didn't need special approvals, just requiring the licences needed.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I'm a bit of both, I like to choose the tools and methods and also like to propose ideas and new areas to build, I don't think one excludes the other

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I handled the criteria and AI handled the rest, according to the specs provided

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

The director was well pleased and also able to provide up to date information to the board meeting, which in turns pleased all the other senior executives

[ASSISTANT]
Has using AI changed what your manager or colleagues expect from you in terms of speed, quality, or availability?

[USER]
not really. The environment I work is very fast-paced anyway. What has changed is my ability to perform more tasks for different people

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
managing very sensitive data. that's something I don't feel confident about sharing with AI. It's also not allowed by company policy yet

[ASSISTANT]
Why is handling those sensitive datasets something you want to keep in your own hands?

[USER]
because they are kept in stick confidential manner and I occasionally need to delegate tasks to colleagues that involve sharing the location to such data. That's allowed, but the company forbid me from sharing that dataset with AI, as a data britch would be of cathastrofic consequences

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI were to handle those sensitive datasets instead of you, what do you think would change in your relationships with teammates or in your role on the team?

[USER]
nothing would change if the company change its policy - that's out of my hands

[ASSISTANT]
What would need to be true about an AI system for you to feel comfortable involving it with highly sensitive material?

[USER]
i am already confident about this. this is not an issue of confidence - well, not on my part. It's about the confidence or willingness of the board of trustees. this is decided at their level

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
most of it lol. AI is capable of extraordinary things at a speed I can only dream about. I wouldn't have any issue giving AI more tasks, but at the moment that's not a necessity

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have â€œautonomyâ€ in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I'd tell them that autonomy is something you need to work hard to gain. Autonomy goes together with experience, hard work, skills and understanding.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from your own job of what that looks like in practice?

[USER]
I manage many projects

[ASSISTANT]
