[USER]
I PM all the technical projecyt of the company, so what you are asking is my daily bread. I set up, draft and delegate tasks for every single data related project in the company, managing 25 individuals. I also manage and approve the execusion of each tasks and ove the project along, dealing with issues on the way as well. I do at least 90% of my work in complete autonomy

[ASSISTANT]
When you are deciding whether to make a call yourself or bring someone else in, what tells you it is yours to decide?

[USER]
can you rephrase that

[ASSISTANT]
How do you tell a decision is one you can make on your own versus one you should escalate or check with someone else?

[USER]
the fact I am at the top of my department. my line manager has no technical or/and data related skills whatsoever, so those are mine and my decisions alone. Sometimes are the wrong ones, but I am paid to make those tough calls

[ASSISTANT]
Think back to a recent project milestone. What was a specific call you made on your own, and what stands out to you about how you reached it?

[USER]
A recent project milestones was the introduction of AI :)) What made it stands out was that I could quite easily demonstrate the huge benefit introducing AI would bring to my department and the company as a whole. It was a long and convoluted analysis, but I eventually produced a very detailed report that highlighted the individual benefits and the ROI for the whole company as well

[ASSISTANT]
With AI in the mix, what tells you a newcomer is ready to be trusted to run with a task on their own?

[USER]
a new comer will need to shadow a more experience person for at least 3 months before they are left in charge of important tasks

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI has changed your work or how it might change it going forward?

[USER]
AI has changed they way I work in a way I myself didn't anticipate. What I am a bit worried about is the easy with which newcomers wish to rely on it, not paying too much attention to their own personal development and skill building first. I fear that this is going to get worst going forward, but likely I won't be part of it, as I would be likely retired.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I think so

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I work in Fiber Optics

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, thinking generally rather than about your own role?

[USER]
Being honest and caring about what you're giving or providing to customers. Ambitious and wanting better for the employees and the company itself

[ASSISTANT]
When you say being honest and caring, what does that look like in a day-to-day interaction with a customer?

[USER]
The customer should feel like you care about them and what you are doing for them. They should be able to trust you

[ASSISTANT]
When you talk about being ambitious and wanting better for employees and the company, what does that look like in practice where you work?

[USER]
Not being stagnant. Giving your employees something to look forward to and to work towards something that gives them meaning

[ASSISTANT]
Of the things youâ€™ve mentioned, which one feels most important to you right now, and why?

[USER]
Ambition. This is what fuels the workers and gives them a reason to want to work hard and diligently for you outside of a paycheck

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI impacts my work in a positive way. It helps us stay organized with our customers and support as well. Cleans up our schedule, makes other parts of our work easier to deal with

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a recent time when it helped you stay organized with a customer, step by step? What did you do and what did it do?

[USER]
It pretty much helps us everyday with customers. We get a pretty long list of customers who need tech support. AI helps us manage them by giving us whats a priority, whats not a priority, how far away the customer is so we can group them together, etc.

[ASSISTANT]
When it suggests priorities and groups customers, what do you do with those suggestions, and what decisions are still on you?

[USER]
I will prioritze them by who is a priority and needs to be seen ASAP versus the other customers. So basically whoever is getting prioritized, I will see them sooner than the others

[ASSISTANT]
Has it ever suggested a priority or grouping that you disagreed with? What happened in that instance?

[USER]
Not really, the AI does a good job now understanding critical issues versus ones that arent so important.

[ASSISTANT]
When you look at its list at the start of the day, what goes through your mind?

[USER]
Nowadays, I normally just focus on the list and can expect the people who need to be priotized on the top.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking back to before you had it, how does your day feel different now when you handle that queue and routing?

[USER]
It makes my work mornings a lot easier by allowing me to quickly go through the list, so I can prepare my equipment for the customers

[ASSISTANT]
Before you head out to the first site, what checks do you still do yourself on the list or the tickets?

[USER]
The list contains the customers phone number, name, and address. I will check the list to make sure that the customers on my list are also on the quickest route to their location

[ASSISTANT]
Have you ever noticed it giving incorrect or outdated info on a ticket, and if so, what did you do next?

[USER]
There have been times where their physical address hasnt been correct. The AI will give us coordinates on where their location is, and it hasnt been completely spot on at times

[ASSISTANT]
When you realized the coordinates were off, what did you do next?

[USER]
I manually checked the coordinates via Google earth. I also refer to the techs who works on the more technical side of AI, and they will try to correct its behavior

[ASSISTANT]
When you first noticed the location was wrong, what went through your mind?

[USER]
I start to realize that AI is not perfect and that I need to be more diligent and manually check their information that they are giving me

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
In reference to my relationship with colleagues? No real affect, outside of it gives us something to discuss

[ASSISTANT]
Has it changed anything in how your manager sets expectations for pace, response times, or what â€œa good dayâ€ looks like for your team?

[USER]
Yes. Since we have started using AI more, leadership does believe that we should be getting more installs or repairs done during the day since we have more time to focus on it.

[ASSISTANT]
What was your gut response when leadership raised the targets?

[USER]
It made me want to blame AI for giving leadership an excuse to give us more work to do.

[ASSISTANT]
After that reaction, did you bring it up with your manager or your team, or did it change how you went about your day?

[USER]
I didnt bring it up, but it did change how my work day goes, since now I have to spend more time putting equipment in my vehicle and having to carry more equipment around

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if it could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I wouldnt want AI to be doing the installs or repairs, atleast the physical part

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Because this is what keeps us employed. If the AI are doing physical repairs and installs, there is no need for technicians anymore

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
It would completely change my role because I would likely be let go, and will no longer be their colleague

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Customer and over phone support.

[ASSISTANT]
Why would you like to give up customer and phone support?

[USER]
Our clients can be very difficult to deal with and not very understanding as to why their internet is down or not working properly. Dealing with rude customers is very common in this business and it becomes overwhelming

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled the customer and phone support, do you think it would change how others see your contribution to the team?

[USER]
Not likely, since it would also be effecting them as well since we all have to do it

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would tell them that autonomy can be a great idea and contributor to what you are doing by doing the more easier and repetitive task so that you can focus more on the imporant aspects of work. But don't completely trust it, check manually and make sure its working correctly for you.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a concrete example of when it took a repetitive task off your plate and let you focus on something more important, and walk me through what each of you did?

[USER]
It helps with screening calls and preparing/organizing our schedule, list of clients, etc. It allowed me to focus more on the customers and their issues

[ASSISTANT]
In that callâ€‘screening and scheduling example, what choices did you still make yourself, and what was already set by the system?

[USER]
Sometimes I will filter the schedule out by where the customers are located, is it along the way, which ones are furtherst away from me.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say do not completely trust it, what is your rule of thumb for when to double check versus when to just go with what it suggests?

[USER]
Our AI has been having some issues with locating the exact location of some of our customers. This is important to us since a lot of our customers live in the mountains and are very hard to track down just by using their physical address.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am an IT Director for a group of small startup companies.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Work-life balance is crucial. Knowing that your work is appreciated also helps people feel their efforts are worth it. Competitive compensation packages are important as well.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say workâ€‘life balance, what does that look like for you on a typical day or week?

[USER]
I would say that a company can expect an employee to work hard during work hours, and even put in extra effort. However, expecting employees to work extra hours on a consistent basis is unreasonable. High-stress jobs where you're thinking about work while you're with your family are not ideal.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about knowing your work is appreciated, what lets you know that in practice? What tells you itâ€™s landing the way it should?

[USER]
Recognition from my manager and senior management, whether that be publicly in front of others, or even just calling or emailing me individually to congratulate me on a job well done.

[ASSISTANT]
When you talk about competitive compensation packages, what elements matter most to you?

[USER]
Salary, retirement benefits, medical coverage.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
Before we go further, I'd like to ask, is this study specifically only for people who live in the UK? The study didn't specifically exclude US participants, but it seems you might only be interested in UK workers.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for checking. Your perspective is welcome regardless of where youâ€™re based, and US experiences are very much of interest here.

Can you tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
OK, thanks. I use AI for a variety of tasks. I use it to summarize meeting notes for later recall. I can also use it to catch me up on what happens in meetings if I join late. I've used it to summarize long documents to give me the highlights. I use it to generate code, giving me small scripts to run, saving time when I have repetitive tasks to do.

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about the small scripts you mentioned, can you walk me through the last time you used AI to generate one and tell me which parts it did and which parts you handled yourself?

[USER]
Someone asked me if I could automate moving data from an Excel spreadsheet. It required a long list of conditional parameters that would have taken me a long time to parse through and generate on my own. Instead, I used AI (I think I used Claude specifically for this one) to generate the code and it worked flawlessly. The AI generated all the code. I only copy and pasted it to execute it and created a button in the workbook for easy execution.

[ASSISTANT]
When you ran that script the first time and saw it work, what went through your mind?

[USER]
I was somewhat surprised at how well it was able to parse and interpret my prompt. Part of me was proud of myself for creating such a well articulated prompt that the AI could interpret everything correctly. Another part of me was impressed at how accurate the AI was and how well-commented the code it generated was.

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to how you would have done that task without AI, how did the process and your pace differ this time?

[USER]
Without AI, I would have created the code one step at a time, tested that step, then move to the next step. It would have probably taken me hours. With AI, the code was generated in minutes. It took me longer to write the prompt than it did for AI to spit back the code to me.

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved on that task?

[USER]
I moved on to the next task in my queue. It made me more productive, essentially.

[ASSISTANT]
Have there been times when the code or outputs from AI missed the mark for you? If so, what did you do next?

[USER]
Yes. Sometimes, there would be just a small error in the code that I could just manually fix myself. Other times, I would go back and refine the prompt and have the AI regenerate the code.

[ASSISTANT]
When you use AI to summarize meeting notes, what do you feed it and what do you personally review or tweak before you rely on the summary?

[USER]
We use Microsoft Teams, so we just enable recording and Copilot generates the meeting notes for us automatically. I typically skim through the meeting notes to make sure I don't see any major problems, but as a general rule I trust that the notes are accurate and file them.

[ASSISTANT]
When you join a meeting late and use the AI to catch you up, how does that change how you participate for the rest of the meeting?

[USER]
In the past, I would feel a bit awkward speaking up because I wouldn't be sure if a particular topic was already discussed before I joined. With the AI giving me a catch-up briefing, I am more confident that I'm not asking redundant questions or making redundant comments.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I wouldn't say it's affected my working relationships at all.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you think of a recent interaction with a colleague, manager, or client where AI played any role at all, even a small one, and tell me what happened?

[USER]
AI is often the subject of discussion with colleagues. As an example, just yesterday, a colleague asked about creating a chatbot with ChatGPT specific for our online store, and making it accessible from the company's Shopify site. He wasn't sure how to integrate ChatGPT with Shopify. I suggested he ask ChatGPT how to do that. We had a little bit of a laugh at the circular concept of asking ChatGPT how to use ChatGPT.

[ASSISTANT]
Have expectations from your managers or clients around speed or deliverables changed because these tools are available, or has it stayed about the same?

[USER]
For the most part, they've stayed the same. However, I can sense expectations are starting to rise. I often hear comments from upper management saying things like "Can't we just ask AI for this or that?"

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I can't think of anything off the top of my head. I will say that I enjoy solving complex challenges, and wouldn't want to hand over total control to AI. I would be interested in using AI to help come up with solutions, but for selfish reasons, I would want to remain involved in that process, as I find it personally enjoyable.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say you want to stay involved in solving complex challenges, what part of that process do you most want to keep in your own hands?

[USER]
The formulation of the idea and the implementation process, turning the idea into a real solution.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is keeping the idea formulation and the handsâ€‘on implementation important to you?

[USER]
It's what I enjoy doing. It's the most interesting and fun part of my job.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over the idea shaping and the handsâ€‘on build, how do you think that would change your role on the team or the way others relate to you?

[USER]
If AI could do that job better than me, I would completely understand why the company would remove that from my responsibilities. I imagine that would result in a loss of prestige in the company in the eyes of my subordinates as well as upper management. I think I would think a little less of myself as well.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Dealing with irate customers. Overall, customer support is not something I enjoy.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes you want to hand off customer support, especially the angry cases, to an AI?

[USER]
People can become irrational and emotional when they have complaints about our department and services. They make unreasonable demands and become very aggressive and confrontational. This in turn makes me irate. I think AI can remain calm since it has no inherent emotions and is better suited to that work than I am.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled most of those customer support interactions, how do you think that would change your dayâ€‘toâ€‘day and your relationships with colleagues or clients?

[USER]
I think I would be in a better mood overall, not having the stress of having to do that work. I would also have more time to devote to more productive work, which would increase job satisfaction.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I would say increased autonomy comes with experience and seniority. In an entry-level position, autonomy would be the ability to have questions answered, have suggestions heard by superiors, and given serious consideration instead of being dismissed. As experience is gained, more autonomy should be expected as to the best way to accomplish tasks. Depending on the job, the ability to work where and when you want might be reasonable to expect. Autonomy is a broad concept, and it's highly dependent on the type of job and the seniority you have.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me a recent example where you felt you had that kind of freedom at work, and walk me through what happened and how you handled it?

[USER]
In my current position as IT Director, I am giving broad flexibility in my work. Recently, there were changes requested in our ERP. They wanted the changes implemented in time for the start of the new fiscal year. They did not give me a project schedule. Instead, they allowed me to create the schedule, adjusting tasks and the critical path around my other projects. They allowed me to prioritize my work based on my own evaluations of what brings most value to the business.

[ASSISTANT]
In that ERP project, where did you feel you could make the calls entirely on your own, and where were there clear boundaries you needed to work within?

[USER]
The only constraint given to me was the deadline. It needs to be completed in time for the start of the new fiscal year. All other milestones were up to me to determine and set.

[ASSISTANT]
On that ERP project, did any AI tools play a role in how you planned or executed the work, and if so, how did they shape the choices you made?

[USER]
I did not use AI to create the schedule. However, AI was used to assist with coding changes in some modules, and to create documentation.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work?

[USER]
I have nothing further to add. Thanks.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you very much for your answers! [ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I am a software engineer

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
The core characteristics are knowledge of software/technology, technical skills, problem solving skills, creativity, and logical processing

[ASSISTANT]
Of the qualities you mentioned, which feel most important to you, and why?

[USER]
I think the most important is problem solving, as it highlights your ability to solve challenging problems coming up with new solutions

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent time at work when problem solving really stood out for youâ€”what was the situation, and what made your approach work?

[USER]
A recent time when problem solving really stood out to me was when I was tasked to move to a new project I had no experience with and needed to create a new feature/functionality. I had to learn how the software worked, how to implement a new feature, and how that functionality would work within the software architecture

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI is a fantastic support tool I use to help generate code, write tests, and debug issues

[ASSISTANT]
Think of a recent time you used it to generate code. What did it handle, and what parts did you handle yourself?

[USER]
A recent time I used AI to generate code was to create a helper function to translate information I had within the software product and needed to convert to a new format for processing with Gitlab API

[ASSISTANT]
In that helper function case, what did the AI produce, and what did you change before you felt comfortable using it in the codebase?

[USER]
The AI helped produce a byte string that could be utilized as part of a gitlab issue description, which was translated from our code files. I tested it out and modified the generic case to our specific use case

[ASSISTANT]
When you first ran that helper, what didnâ€™t work as expected, and how did you spot it?

[USER]
The helper function wasn't specifically targetted at the type of file and format we were using, so I had to adjust it to ensure the file contents were read and parsed correctly

[ASSISTANT]
When you realized it wasnâ€™t targeting your file type and format, what went through your mind, and how did you decide what to try first?

[USER]
I first needed to identify the cause for why the function was failing, which I used an iterative problem solving process starting with a very simple input and slightly making it more complex to find the issue

[ASSISTANT]
As you went through that iterative process from simple to more complex inputs, what emotions came up for you, or what stands out to you about that moment?

[USER]
I became exciting and confident as I slowly diagnosed the issue and started to work through and solve the problem

[ASSISTANT]
When you used it for that helper, did it change the time it took you to get to a working solution compared to doing it without AI, and what did you do with any time you saved?

[USER]
It was roughly equivalent to the time it would have taken me to research the appropriate functions I needed to implement and put together the functionality myself. It made it easier on the front end not doing research, and just spending time on the backened tweaking the functionality to make it fit

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned using it to write tests. Can you tell me about a recent time you did that and walk me through what it produced and what you kept or changed?

[USER]
I use AI to help generate template tests for unit tests to save me time generating test formats for different cases that follow a similar repeated pattern

[ASSISTANT]
When you use it to generate those template tests, how do you check that they really cover the tricky edge cases before you commit them?

[USER]
I make sure to run our code coverage scripts to make sure we hit our 80% coverage threshold for unit tests

[ASSISTANT]
You also mentioned using it to debug issues. Can you tell me about a recent bug where you brought AI into the loop, and what it suggested versus what you actually tried?

[USER]
When I get stumped while debugging an issue, i use ai to help offer suggestions or potentially help diagnose the issue

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through a concrete example of a bug where you used itâ€”what was the symptom, and what did you try first before asking for suggestions?

[USER]
A concrete example of a bug where I used AI to help debug was when there was a dependency issue with the package I was including, and used AI to help me figure out the correct dependency pattern and packages to provide the functionality I wanted to use in the file

[ASSISTANT]
When it suggested the dependency pattern, what was your gut response, and how did you decide whether to trust it or verify it?

[USER]
I felt like it was right, and tested it out to verify whether it worked or not

[ASSISTANT]
Thinking about your day-to-day now, has using it changed how you organize your workflow or the way you approach new tasks compared to before, and can you give me a concrete example?

[USER]
For my day to day work flow, I use AI when I need to generate a routine block of code quickly, rather than trying to find the functions myself, espcially when using packages I am not super used to and have a good understanding of all functionality and features

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
A concrete example is using the Gitlab API, which has helped me generate functionality through functions I didn't know existed. AI hasn't really affected my working relationships much, as I primarily use it for personal use at work

[ASSISTANT]
Have you ever put AI-assisted code into a merge request and had a teammate review it? If so, what was that interaction like?

[USER]
I have used AI assisted code in merge requests, but I always vet and tweak the product, and never just copy, paste, and blindly commit it. I make sure to alter the logic to make it more efficient. The AI code did not affect the teammate MR

[ASSISTANT]
Have you and your team or manager talked about when and how to use it at work, like any norms or boundaries you try to follow?

[USER]
We have roughly talked about appropriate use of AI at work, the type of information that it can be used for to help with privacy and security, but nothing more

[ASSISTANT]
Has using it changed how you collaborate or share knowledge with teammates, for example in code reviews or explaining design decisions?

[USER]
It has not changed how I collaborate or share knowledge with teammates, as I only use it for personal development

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I would never fully hand over coding, design, or implementation responsibilities to AI, as it is something I enjoy having  the leading part in

[ASSISTANT]
What is it about taking the lead on coding, design, and implementation that you want to keepâ€”what does it give you in your work?

[USER]
It is fun to engage in problem solving related to coding, as it provides a rush of joy when you overcome a hard problem to create a working solution

[ASSISTANT]
If those pieces were handed off, how do you think it would change your role on the team or the way others see your contribution?

[USER]
I would take more of a role in the design of the software, handing off the implementation responsibilities to AI

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I would happily give AI my responsibilities related to updating documentation, which is mundane and boring

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over the documentation updates, how would you want to review or control its output so it matches the system accurately?

[USER]
I would review final drafts of the documentation to ensure it is clear and informative, and presented in a reasonable way for human consumption

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close this part, if a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
Autonomy in the role of a software developer means remote work, ability to schedule work time flexibly around your own schedule, and having control of how to approach and complete your work

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example of what that looks like in practice, maybe a day when you set your own schedule and chose your own approach to a task?

[USER]
I work 100% remotely from home, work from 6am to 2pm every day, but can take breaks if I like, work odd hours, or even work 4 days a week so long as I meet my 40 hour workweek.

[ASSISTANT]
Beyond setting your schedule, what choices about tools, libraries, or the way you tackle a feature do you make on your own, and where do you typically need a sign-off?

[USER]
I have autonomy within my role to make choices about what tools and libraries we utilize given my best judgement and what is needed to complete the task. So long as I provide evidence and support for my decisions, my supervisor trusts my judgement to choose what is best

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a time you made a call on a tool or library and had to explain or defend that choiceâ€”what was the situation, and how did that conversation go?

[USER]
A time I made a call on a library was switching from the go gitlab xanzy library to the go gitlan-org package because xanzy became deprecated and out of date, so it made sense to rewrite our software to utilize the modern package, even though it took some time and redesign with the new library functionality

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Nothing else to cover that was not discussed

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
understanding what you're doing because if you don't you will be very lost and struggle with whatever it is you've been tasked with

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent task where that clarity clicked for you, and what made it click?

[USER]
With pipelines pushing and pulling from repositries I came from a software dev apprenticeship so had no knowledge of this whatsoever then I done some theory with my training and then a project with my work regarding this and doing it like 3/4 times made it click for me.

[ASSISTANT]
When feedback works well for you, what does it look like in practice?

[USER]
With pipelines aswell you have to make sure the files that you're pushing are up to date and is synced in the sharepoint so if other people are working on it you don't overwrite their edits or commits by pushing or commiting a file from your local computer i done this and couldn't figure out what was wrong then asked my colleauge who is more experienced and they pointed out that I made that mistake next time I done it I made sure to push from the correct location.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
It helps a lot ecspecially in my line of work working with api's, pipelines, data mapping, logic flows, integrationsand many more alonge those line this is AI's field so it gives very insightful advice and help and also shows me how to do things in ways I wouldn't consider without.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you walk me through one recent task where you used it, step by step? What were you building, and how did you bring it into the process?

[USER]
I was doing a liquid transformation json to json and for some reason only some of the json data was coming through. So I put the schema my input data and the output data I was currently getting and the output data I expected into chatgpt prompt and asked it to help me see what was wrong with the liquid map. It then showed me how to properly call what i needed in array because that's where the data I needed that wasn't being populated was stored. I then used it's advice and it still didn't work because the AI added some unneccesary curly brackets which it told me after I told it it's first advice didn't work. When that was removed though the correct fields were being brought through and I was elated.

[ASSISTANT]
In that liquid mapping example, which parts did you write yourself, and which parts did you take straight from the AI?

[USER]
I wrote everything by myself apart from the part where there was data that needed to be extracted from the arrays.

[ASSISTANT]
When it didnâ€™t work after you first followed its advice, what went through your mind in that moment?

[USER]
I was thinking the AI has scammed me it's unreliable and I was upset because even my manager and my boss couldn't manage to solve the issue so I thought what am I going to do this a very tricky predicament.

[ASSISTANT]
Once you had the corrected mapping, how did you check it before moving it into your live workflow?

[USER]
By testing it via a liquid playground website then by testing via postman.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
Could you elaborate pleae I don't understand that question.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I would've just played around with it for ages hopefully not that long, google check places like stack overflow or reddit and hopefully get to a solution. Now Ai is so easily accessible and helps a lot so I would use AI instead now.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re working on pipelines or API integrations, what kinds of tasks do you tend to ask AI to help with?

[USER]
Depends these are area's that I don't really get stuck in or If I do my colleauges are a lot older and more experienced so I'd ask them for help in these areas.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
If it's something more broad and simple not that technical I'd ask AI but if it's very niche and I know my colleauges have some sort of experience with like C sharp programming I have a colleauge who has knowledge of this for 40 years so i'll ask him about that instead of AI. But with liquid mapping he hasn't got a clue about it and neither do I so I'll ask AI bout it.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I always test whatever it sends me regardless so nothing changed with that you get a lot of error with formatting and code wise the brackets did make me wary but I was always excited to use AI but still cautios because at the end of the day it's still quite limited.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I'd say it has you know because before it I was asking my colleauges for more help but with AI now it's more accessible convinient when I'm working from home so yeah made me kinda more independent but I feel like exposure to a lot of different projects has played a role in that too.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

Besides drafting HDL, are there other parts of your FPGA work where you use it, like testbenches, constraints, documentation, or debugging?

[USER]
I did use it for testbenching since I needed to generate the simuli for the my top module.

[ASSISTANT]
For that testbench, what exactly did it generate for you, and what did you end up changing or adding yourself?

[USER]
It gave me various testcases so that I could see things on the waveform. I changed some of the stimuli to cover corner cases.

[ASSISTANT]
What was your gut response when you looked at the waveform outputs from the AIâ€‘generated tests?

[USER]
It seemed correct, but could have used more test cases

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
It has not affected any of my working relationships.

[ASSISTANT]
Have you talked with your manager or teammates about you using it, or has it come up in code reviews or design reviews?

[USER]
My manager and teammates actually encourage me to use AI because it saves the company money and time,.

[ASSISTANT]
When your manager and teammates encourage you to use it, does that change what they expect from you on timelines or the kinds of tasks they give you?

[USER]
They give me a shorter timeline.

[ASSISTANT]
When the timeline gets shorter because youâ€™re using it, what goes through your mind and how do you adjust your approach to the work?

[USER]
It makes me more likely to use AI because it will give me more time to debug.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Not really. I do think that AI would be extremely helpful with workflow and figuring out all of the logic.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes you comfortable with the idea of handing over even the core parts of your workâ€”what gives you that confidence?

[USER]
I know that I can't be replaced because HDL is something that has to be done by humans in the end, especially programming it onto the FPGA chip itself.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled more of the logic work, how do you think that would change your role on the team, if at all?

[USER]
It would make figuring out different projects a lot easier.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over more of the logic work, how do you think that would change how others see your contribution on the team?

[USER]
It would make them view me as more efficient

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Writing testbenches and constraints for the FPGA

[ASSISTANT]
Why would you like to give up writing testbenches and constraints?

[USER]
It is too tedious

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled testbenches and constraints for you, would that change how others see your contribution on the team?

[USER]
No, I don't think so.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
Make sure you have all of the knowledge necessary for the job. Only then can you use tools like AI to support your work to save yourself time.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example of a time when having the right knowledge let you use AI well, and what you did in that situation?

[USER]
For one of my projects, my manager told me to use AI. With the digital logic knowledge I had, I was able to understand the mistakes that AI generated and made it much easier to fix.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say â€œhave all the knowledge necessary,â€ what specific areas would you tell a new FPGA engineer to master before leaning on AI?

[USER]
Basics of digital logic, HDLs like Verilog

[ASSISTANT]
On a fresh FPGA task, how do you decide what to let AI draft and where you keep tight control yourself?

[USER]
If it is a simple system, then I will let AI draft the body of the RTL. If it is complex, I will try to write it myself.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for walking me through all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work?

[USER]
No

Looking back at this interview, how well does it summarize how experience of AI is changing and might change your work: 1 (it describes poorly how AI might change my work), 2 (it partially describes how AI might change my work), 3 (it describes well how AI might change my work), 4 (it describes very well how AI might change my work). Interview 140
Username: marco
Date: 12/12/2025 17:31:54
Duration: 15.41 minutes

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I'm a nurse who works in the ER1

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
enough money!

[ASSISTANT]
Besides pay, what else matters to you in a good job?

[USER]
respect

[ASSISTANT]
Day to day, what makes it feel like a good day at work for you?

[USER]
working as a team within a safe and respectful work environment wehre I get to care for patients effectively

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
it's fairly new in the hospital, but we use it for scheduling, documenting notes, and triage

[ASSISTANT]
Could you walk me through the last time you used it for triage? What happened step by step?

[USER]
Wait, triage? We don't use AI for that at our hospital.
Are you asking about something else, or...? I'm a bit confused what you mean.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for pointing that out, and Iâ€™m sorry for the mix-up. Could you tell me about the last time you used it for documenting notes, from start to finish?

[USER]
Sure. So this was Wednesday evening shift. I had a patient post-op from gallbladder surgery who needed wound care and pain medication.
After I finished with her, I went to the mobile cart in the hallway and opened the AI charting system. I spoke into it - told it the patient's name and room number, described the wound site, said it was clean with no signs of infection, listed the pain score she'd reported, and the medication I'd administered.
It typed everything up in the proper format. I read through it, saw it looked accurate, and hit submit.
That's basically it.

[ASSISTANT]
In that example, which parts did you do yourself, and which parts did the system handle?

[USER]
I did the actual patient care - the wound check, giving the medication, talking to the patient.
Then I spoke the information into the system.
The system transcribed what I said and formatted it into the proper documentation structure - you know, with the right headings and clinical language.
I reviewed it and submitted it.
So basically: I do the care and provide the information, it does the writing and formatting.

[ASSISTANT]
Has the system ever gotten something wrong or left something out in your notes? If so, what did you do in that moment?

[USER]
Yeah, it has. Once it completely left out that a patient had fallen earlier in the shift - I'd mentioned it but it didn't show up in the note.
I had to go back and add that manually. That one worried me a bit because falls are a big deal legally.

[ASSISTANT]
When you noticed the fall was missing, what went through your mind and how did you react in that moment?

[USER]
I panicked for a second, honestly. Falls are serious - if something happened later and there was no record of it, that could be really bad for me.
I immediately added it in and made sure it was documented properly. Double-checked the whole note after that.
Made me trust the system a bit less, to be honest.

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to how you documented before this system, how has your process changed, if at all?

[USER]
Before, I'd type everything myself at the computer. Took longer - probably 10-15 minutes per patient sometimes.
Now it's quicker, maybe 5 minutes? But I still have to review everything carefully, especially after that fall incident.
I guess I'm more... vigilant now? Like I don't just trust what it generates.

[ASSISTANT]
When you save those extra minutes, what do you usually end up doing with that time during a shift?

[USER]
There's always more work to do. Another patient needs something, or there's medication rounds to finish, or someone's call button is going off.
It's not like I get to leave early or take a break. The time just gets absorbed into everything else.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used it for scheduling? What did you do, step by step?

[USER]
Scheduling? We don't use the AI for that. It's just for documentation.
Our scheduling is done by the charge nurse or manager - it's not automated.

[ASSISTANT]
When youâ€™re reviewing or correcting what it generated, does that feel like using your clinical judgment or more like tedious cleanup work?

[USER]
Depends on the situation, I guess.
When I'm checking vitals are correct or medication doses - that's definitely clinical judgment. That's important stuff I need to verify.
But when I'm just fixing formatting issues or adding back something obvious it missed... yeah, that feels more like busywork.

[ASSISTANT]
Has using it changed how much time you spend with patients or what happens in the room, even in small ways?

[USER]
Not really, I don't think. I still do the same assessments and care.
Though... I suppose sometimes I'm thinking about what I need to remember to tell the system afterwards? Like making mental notes of specific details.
But I'm not sure if that's different from before when I had to remember for typing it up myself.

[ASSISTANT]
How has AI affected your working relationships?

[USER]
I'm not sure what you mean by that. My relationships with colleagues?
It hasn't really changed anything there. We still work together the same way.

[ASSISTANT]
Has your manager or charge nurse given any feedback about using the system, like expectations for how you use it or how they review those notes?

[USER]
Not really specific feedback, no. They just expect us to use it and make sure the documentation is accurate.
I think they can see the notes like they always could, but I haven't heard anything particular about how we're supposed to use the AI part.

[ASSISTANT]
What have you been hearing from your coworkers about using itâ€”any stories, gripes, or tips that stand out?

[USER]
Most people think it's fine, I guess. Saves time.
One of the other nurses said it completely garbled a patient's allergy information once - put the wrong allergen in. That scared her.
And there's some grumbling about having to constantly correct little things. But nothing major really.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
Making decisions about patient care. Like what medications to give or when to call a doctor.
That needs a human.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is keeping those care decisions with you important?

[USER]
Because... you can't just follow rules, you know? Every patient is different. Sometimes the textbook answer isn't the right one for that particular person in that moment.
And if something goes wrong, someone needs to be accountable. That should be a person, not a machine.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over those care decisions, how do you think it would change your role on the team or your interactions with physicians and families?

[USER]
I haven't really thought about that.
I guess... I'd feel less like a nurse and more like someone just following orders? Even more than we already do with doctors' orders.
And families ask me questions all the time. If a computer was making the calls, I don't know what I'd tell them.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
Honestly? All the charting and documentation. If it could do that perfectly without me having to check it, I'd be thrilled.
That's the part of the job that takes time away from actually being with patients.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI handled all the charting without you checking it, how do you think that would change how others see your contribution on the unit?

[USER]
I suppose... the documentation is evidence of what we do, right? If the AI is doing all of that automatically, then what's visible is my hands-on care, not the... I don't know, the thinking and judgment that goes into documenting things properly?

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I guess I'd say... you have autonomy in how you interact with patients, how you prioritize your tasks, that sort of thing. But there's a lot you don't control - staffing levels, hospital policies, what doctors order.
With the AI stuff, I'm not sure. You still make the important decisions, but more of your work is... shaped by these systems?
I don't know if I've really figured out how I feel about it yet, to be honest.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say more of your work is shaped by these systems, can you give me an example of what that looks like in practice?

[USER]
Well, like... the system structures how I document things. It has certain formats it uses, certain language.
So I find myself thinking in those terms now when I'm with patients - like, what information does the system need? What will it be looking for?
I'm not sure if that's shaping my work or just changing how I report on my work. Does that make sense?

[ASSISTANT]
That makes sense. Thinking about a recent patient, did the systemâ€™s structure change anything you asked or did in the room, or did it mainly change how you wrote it up afterward?

[USER]
Mostly just how I wrote it up, I think.
Though... actually, now that you ask, there was one time I went back to ask a patient an extra question because I realized the system would need that detail for the assessment.
But I'm not sure if that's bad? Maybe I should've asked it anyway?
I don't know. It's hard to separate out what I'd do normally versus what the system prompts me to do.

[ASSISTANT]
If that young nurse asked how to keep their clinical judgment front and center when the system nudges them toward certain boxes and phrases, what would you tell them to actually do on a busy shift?

[USER]
That's tough. I'm not sure I've figured that out myself yet.
I guess... don't let the system rush you? Take the time to actually think about what's important about the patient, not just what fits in the boxes?
But honestly, on a busy shift when you're running behind, it's hard to do that. You just want to get the documentation done.
I don't know if I have a good answer for them.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you recall a moment when you chose to ignore or override what the system produced, and what led you to make that call?

[USER]
I think we have passed the itnerview time

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for letting me know. Before we wrap up, is there anything else youâ€™d like to add about how AI is affecting your work?

[USER]
no!

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you very much for your answers! Looking back at this interview, how well does it summarize how experience of AI is changing and might change your work: 1 (it describes poorly how AI might change my work), 2 (it partially describes how AI might change my work), 3 (it describes well how AI might change my work), 4 (it describes very well how AI might change my work). Please only reply with the associated number.

[USER]
4

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I work on the internal infrastructure team at a medium-sized software development company as a Senior Engineering Manager.

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
A supportive environment that allows you to grow skills. Freedom in working hours and location as long as the work gets done. Supportive leadership. Mistakes are not punished but seen as a learning opportunity. Job security and stability.

[ASSISTANT]
Of the things you mentioned, which two matter most to you right now, and why?

[USER]
Job security and freedom in working hours / location.

[ASSISTANT]
When you think about job security in your context, what are the concrete signs that tell you that you have it or that itâ€™s shaky?

[USER]
At the moment we are seeing a number of changes across the business which makes me think we may well be impacted negatively. My role means I see things that others in the business might not.

[ASSISTANT]
When freedom in hours and location is working well for you, what does that look like in your day to day?

[USER]
On a normal day I will work from home, and I can start anytime between 7am-10am, finishing from 4pm onwards. We're not obssesive about people working set hours as long as the required work is done and is high quality.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
At the moment our AI use - at least in my team - is informal. People are free to use it in the ways that best work for them, or not at all, but our current processes don't incorporate AI as a mandatory element. We do provide AI resources (CoPilot) for employees though.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used CoPilot or another AI tool at work, and what specific task you used it for?

[USER]
I used it this morning to write a skeleton Powershell script that I could build specifics onto.

[ASSISTANT]
In that PowerShell example, what parts did CoPilot generate and what parts did you add or change yourself?

[USER]
CoPilot created a basic skeleton of a script to iterate through some objects, incorporate some checks, and write to a log file. The specifics of the objects, checks, and what would be logged was added by me.

[ASSISTANT]
When CoPilot produced that skeleton, how did you review or test it, and did you run into any mistakes?

[USER]
The intention was always that the code would not be in a runnable state on creation. I sight-checked to make sure the fundamentals were there, then as I was adding to it, the checks were done at that point. I ensured that the script was making no changes and running in 'what-if' mode before the first test run.

[ASSISTANT]
When you were working from that skeleton and filling in the specifics, what went through your mind about using CoPilot in that way?

[USER]
Nothing specific. It's not an unusual occurence. CoPilot is a tool like any other.

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to writing that script from scratch, how did using CoPilot change your time or workflow, if at all?

[USER]
It was certainly quicker. I find AI to be a very useful tool as long as your expectations are realistic.

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved on that script?

[USER]
Specifically today, I squeezed in a check-in with one of my team.

[ASSISTANT]
Has using AI changed any of your working relationships, either within your team or with peers and leaders?

[USER]
I would say not.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
With the state of things at the moment, I would never deploy anything AI-created without human review first. I would also not hand any personnel descisions over.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes human review essential for anything AI-created in your domain?

[USER]
I'm not sure I understand the question

[ASSISTANT]
Got it. When you think about releasing code, what risks come to mind if no person reviews what the AI produced?

[USER]
The risk of catastrophic bugs leading to loss of data or reputational damage. To be clear, I wouldn't allow unreviewed human-written code to be deployed either for the same reason.

[ASSISTANT]
Why are personnel decisions something you want to keep in human hands rather than give to an AI?

[USER]
I don't believe that's where AI's strengths are.

[ASSISTANT]
What parts of personnel decisions, in your experience, really depend on human judgment or context?

[USER]
Anything that impacts a human requires human judgement, in my opinion.

[ASSISTANT]
If AI took over parts of personnel decisions, how do you think that would change your relationships with your team or your role?

[USER]
I think it would devalue my role. If I can't have an impact on the well-being and progress of my team, my role as a manager is almost moot.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I genuinely can't think of anything I would be comforable handing over to AI 100%.

[ASSISTANT]
Is there a task youâ€™d be comfortable letting AI do most of, as long as you still review and make the final call?

[USER]
Yep. Scheduling meetings and organising the team rota are two that come to mind.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes scheduling and the team rota good candidates to hand over mostly to AI?

[USER]
It's algorithmic work and the consequences of errors are quite mild.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
The ability to decide how do you the work that's given to you.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example from your job where you had that ability, and what choices you made about how to do the work?

[USER]
That's true for most of my role. The PowerShell script I mentioned earlier was a choice I made from many possible options. It's impossible for me to list them all.

[ASSISTANT]
When you donâ€™t have that ability to decide how to do the work, what tends to be going on in the project or organization?

[USER]
The are certain elements that are dictated by company policy that we can't deviate from, such as performance reviews. That's the case all the time, rather than when specific things are happening.

[ASSISTANT]
If someone junior asked you how to recognize, in a concrete way, that they have that ability on a task, what would you tell them to look for?

[USER]
sorry I'm not sure what you mean?

[ASSISTANT]
No problem. Thinking about a recent assignment, what signals from your manager or the brief told you how much freedom you had in how to do it?

[USER]
That's hard to answer as that's always been the way we've worked. There will always be an end result, but how we get there is left to us - obviously we have to work with available tools and resources, but other than that we are autonomous.

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I don't think so. I'll call back to what I said earlier - AI is a very useful tool when used correctly, with the right expectations.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about the last time you used AI on a specific task in your role? What was the task?

[USER]
We normally organize a tabletop exercise annually in the information security department. Prepping the document for this type of exercise normally takes about 2 weeks for me to complete; however, with the use of AI, I was able to prompt an AI tool to give me a draft of a scenario we planned to run. Also,o giving AI more details about the type of organization, an idea of what the IT department looks like, and our infrastructure.

After the first draft document, it was easy for me to edit and get this document ready within a week

[ASSISTANT]
In that tabletop exercise prep, which parts did the document come from the AI and which parts did you write or replace yourself?

[USER]
The template and structure of the exercise in terms of moderator scripts, the type of questions to be asked during this simulation, and what and when injects should be used were from AI

All I did was to fine-tune the scenario to suit our organization's needs, structure, and also replace some of the text in a way that is not too AI-scripted

[ASSISTANT]
Did the AI include anything off-base or make mistakes in that draft, and how did you handle it when you spotted them?

[USER]
Nothing off base in the case, however, there were some nuances AI made; however, I feel because I didn't give it as much prompt as needed, which I am happy with, because I dont want to be too specific about our environment for privacy reasons

[ASSISTANT]
What did you do with the time you saved by getting the document ready in a week instead of two?

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
Sofware Engineer

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks. In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job â€” in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
Interesting work, with appropriate challenge to be interesting, appropriate time for the work and a function you can recognise of being of benefit to society

[ASSISTANT]
When you say appropriate challenge, what does that look like day to day for you?

[USER]
Just things which are not too easy to be boring, or too challenging to be impossible

[ASSISTANT]
When you say appropriate time for the work, how do you tell that a project is paced right? What do you look for?

[USER]
deadlines that are meetable without sacrificing quality or over-working

[ASSISTANT]
When you say being of benefit to society, what tells you your work is having that kind of impact?

[USER]
That entirely depends the job, and the appropriate feedback you have. There's no simple answer

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
It massively harms it, C-Suite people dictate it must be used, when it simply doesn't achieve anything, a few people use it without realising it's going wrong, it's just a disaster which pulls time out of getting things done as you correct mistakes.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a specific time when AI was used on a task in your team and what happened, step by step?

[USER]
Team member used AI to write some code - in the review process lots of time was taken up understanding and recommending corrections to be more readable, more understandable, some obvious bugs were found, after being addressed to some extent, it then passed through testing where more bugs were found.  Eventually the AI input was thrown away and work was done in the traditional way quickly and efficiently.

[ASSISTANT]
In that example, who did the initial drafting and who was responsible for the review and signâ€‘off?

[USER]
The team member responsible for the work did the initial drafting, review and sign-off of course is an entire team activity.

[ASSISTANT]
When you were reviewing that AIâ€‘written code, what kinds of mistakes stood out, and how did you decide whether to fix them piece by piece or scrap and rewrite?

[USER]
The main stand out was the appallingly bad structure making it difficult to confirm it was even working correctly, there was work done to improve this, but it was only after actual functional testing that it was confirmed that the concept was broken enough to be worth rewriting

[ASSISTANT]
When you reached the point of deciding to rewrite, what went through your mind?

[USER]
I was happy for a solution

[ASSISTANT]
Compared to doing it the traditional way from the start, how did this approach affect the timeline and your day to day that week?

[USER]
It massively slowed it up, the rewrite took little time - of course there was knowledge from the previous attempt so can't say it would've taken the same amount of time definitively, but certainly the struggles with the low quality took time from both the developer, and more importantly the more experienced developers who certainly would've done it very quickl.

[ASSISTANT]
Spending that extra time untangling and testing the AIâ€™s code, what did that work feel like for you?

[USER]
It's not really a "feel" activity.  It's a job that needs doing .

[ASSISTANT]
Has using AI changed how you work with teammates or managers in any way?

[USER]
Only the ones who choose to waste their time with it.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
I think that's a nonsense question, my job is thinking about stuff and working out what needs to be done, the implementation and review of stuff is intrinsic to that, there is no part that could be handed over to a tool.   It's a question like "Are there any nails you would like to not hit with a hammer even if a hammer could hit them perfectly?" - the tool is irrelevant to the question.

[ASSISTANT]
What makes the implementation and review inseparable from the thinking part for you?

[USER]
because it's how you think

[ASSISTANT]
Can you tell me about a recent moment where building or reviewing the code changed your understanding of the problem and led you to adjust the approach?

[USER]
Not in the sort of detail that makes sense for this format - too much context would be needed of the nature of problems - whenever you're building something you realise things which could be built differently or do differently or the user actually needed something else.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
See my hammer comment above, it's a tool I can't "give my job to AI" any more than I could give the hammering of nails to a hammer.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
In my job Autonomy is freedom to work how and where you like to achieve the requirements of the job - So the outputs are specific, but how you get to them is down to you.

[ASSISTANT]
Can you give me an example of what that looks like in practice, maybe from a recent project where you chose your own path to the output?

[USER]
Not really - I mean it's pretty obvious - "you need to create a widget that does X" - how you research what X is, how you decide to implement it, how you test etc.  are all part of what you do, rather than just being told "implement it like this."

[ASSISTANT]
I can imagine two readings of what you just said. One is that itâ€™s mainly about choosing your own methods and tools, and the other is that itâ€™s also about setting the sequence and pace of the work. Which is closer to what you mean, or is it something else altogether?

[USER]
Both

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for walking me through all of that. Is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work before we wrap up?

[USER]
nah, I'm good

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
Hey! I'm glad to be able to speak to you too. I'm a software engineer.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
It gives you fair pay, a sense of stability, and some chance to grow. It should also have a healthy work environment where people treat each other with respect. You wake up in the morning and not dreading going into work.

[ASSISTANT]
Thatâ€™s helpful. When you think about growth, what kinds of opportunities or experiences make you feel like youâ€™re genuinely progressing?

[USER]
When you are appreciated for your work and it becomes noticed, and you get opportunities from that, be it more responsibility, or just harder tasks.

[ASSISTANT]
Got it. When you picture a healthy work environment, whatâ€™s something concrete that tells you itâ€™s thereâ€”maybe a recent moment or practice that stands out?

[USER]
When you have people at work who can ask for help without hesitating or worrying they will be judged. So, when someone on my team is unsure, they know I will always be there to help them, I'm not going to think any less of them.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
At the moment, we use it for all kinds of things, just recently we have started to implement an AI that we built ourselves, to guide us in coding errors. We also use it for things like summarising and polishing up emails/docs.

[ASSISTANT]
In that recent example of the tool you built to guide coding errors, can you walk me through one specific time you used it? What parts did the tool handle, and what parts did you do yourself?

[USER]
It wasn't too long ago actually, we had a project going on, and we came across some bug that none of us had seen before, we asked the AI and it was able to break it down for me, which then allowed us to properly address it.

[ASSISTANT]
In that moment, who did the drafting and who did the reviewing? For example, did the AI propose the diagnosis and a code change that you then vetted, or did you write a fix and have the AI critique it?

[USER]
The AI pointed out the error, offered a couple of potential solutions, but once they had pin pointed the issue at hand, we knew what was needed.

[ASSISTANT]
When it pointed to the issue and suggested solutions, did it get anything wrong or partially off? If so, what did you do to check and correct it?

[USER]
As the AI model is still fairly new, and we're constantly working on it, it can make mistakes but in this case, there were no issues at all.

[ASSISTANT]
What went through your mind as you were using it on that bugâ€”did it feel like a relief, or more like you still had to be on guard and doubleâ€‘check everything?

[USER]
It's almost like a constant feel of security, because we know how much work we put into this AI model, and we know it's capabilities. We have a safety net to fall back on, if anything random happens and it has the ability to assist.

[ASSISTANT]
You mentioned â€œweâ€ a few times. How did using this tool change the way you and your teammates worked together on that bugâ€”did it shift who spoke up, who took the lead, or who others turned to for help?

[USER]
This bug specifically, it was only me and one other member of my team, but they are all equally versed with this AI and know it's abilities, so when working, we are all doing so, not just the 2 of us who were working with this most recent bug. It gives the team a freedom to work and not be too scared to make a mistake.

[ASSISTANT]
When this tool helps you move faster on a bug, what do you usually do with the time you free up?

[USER]
Other jobs to do with the project, if that means replying to the investors emails or working on the AI code itself.

[ASSISTANT]
On the emails and docs you mentioned, how do you split the work with AIâ€”who drafts, who reviews, and how do you handle it if the tone or details arenâ€™t quite right?

[USER]
We have the AI always summarise and make drafts for us. We then review it, and once we've made alterations, we then run it through the AI once more.

[ASSISTANT]
When the AI drafts those messages and youâ€™re reviewing them, whatâ€™s that experience like for youâ€”does it feel like helpful support or more like tedious cleanup?

[USER]
No, it's a needed thing to do, we have trust in the AI, and more often than not, there isn't a lot of editing that needs to be done to them. As we work more with the AI, we become more aware of it's style and what to look out for, that me may want to change with it's writing.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Thinking about the future: Is there any aspect of your job that you would never want to hand over to an AI, even if the AI could do it perfectly?

[USER]
When dealing with investors/stake holders, we'd never give the AI that part of the job. We want it to still feel personal, and not like they are just being put over to an AI, because we can't be bothered to speak to them. That's something we will never change.

[ASSISTANT]
Why is keeping those investor and stakeholder conversations personal so important to you?

[USER]
It creates a bond, on a personal level. We know each other, we speak on a personal level and I like to keep it like that. I typically do it face to face, or via Teams.

[ASSISTANT]
If an AI took over more of those conversations, what do you think it would do to your relationships with those investors and your role on the team?

[USER]
I think we would lose touch to the stakeholders. It would feel like there's nothing in the job beyond the work itself. I like to put a face to a name and I know they do too.

[ASSISTANT]
On the flip side, what is a part of your job you would happily give to AI tomorrow?

[USER]
I would give the AI all our debugging that is repetitive and just our routine code clean up, we tend to do at the end of the day

[ASSISTANT]
What makes those repetitive debugging and endâ€‘ofâ€‘day cleanups the kind of work youâ€™d gladly hand off?

[USER]
It's just a little boring and time consuming, it's something that isn't that important that we need a human to constantly check on it, and as I said before, we always go to the AI to help with the debugging if needed, anyway.

[ASSISTANT]
Weâ€™ve talked about your specific experiences. To close, I have a broad question. If a young person entering your field asked you what it means to have autonomy in your job today, what would you tell them?

[USER]
I think having the space to make decisions on how you approach your work, is really important and vital to keep in mind. You've been given a problem, and you have the choice to pick the required tools, how you structure it, and also the path you make to finding the solution without having someone hovering over you. It will also mean you will be trusted with important decisions, you are being trusted to manage your time efficiently, not being scared to ask for help when you realise you need it, and also to balance speed but keep that quality that is wanted and expected. Although we have AI and loads of new tools which assist us in a way that makes our job and lives a lot easier, autonomy is about keeping control over everything and all the key choices, which in turn is being able to be confident in the work you deliver.

[ASSISTANT]
Thatâ€™s a thoughtful answer. Can you give me a concrete example from your recent work where you had that space to choose the tools and path, and what that looked like day to day?

[USER]
There was something not too long ago where I had to personally build a small internal tool to help clean up some old data which could be potentially damaged. My manager basically told me, there's an issue, and this is what I need from you, go do your best and get the job done. I was given free reign, basically. I got to pick what tech I wanted, I also tried a few different approaches, and I got to change things around when something didn't work how I wanted it to. Everyday I was organising my own work, like I would when I'm team leading my own actual team, but I was doing it for myself only for this. So, I knew I didn't have the pressure of someone coming in and disturbing me, watching over me, making sure I'm doing the right thing, which was a relief and actually made me able to work better.

[ASSISTANT]
That moment you mention of feeling relieved and able to work better really stands out. When you realized no one would be looking over your shoulder on that tool, what was your gut response, and how did it show up in the way you structured your day or made decisions?

[USER]
It's just an instant sense of relief, knowing I can do what I do best, and work without distractions. I'm someone who, if I'm being talked to while working, or being told what to do, or even just knowing someone is watching me from afar, I won't perform, and I'll maybe miss things I normally wouldn't. I'd be able to come into work, not have any stress thinking, I need to hurry up, they are waiting on me. I figured out what I needed to do for the day, work out my tasks and when I wanted to do them, it was pure control and I thrived under it.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for sharing all of that. Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to add about how AI is affecting your work or your team?

[USER]
I think over the last year or so, the AI has become part of the team, and it's something we don't rely on, but the fact that it's there as a safety net, has been such a relief and help to the entire team. It saves us a lot of time, which then allows us to work on other things on the project, or the AI itself. It hasn't and I don't see it ever replacing the teamwork we have within the team or the personal interactions we have with clients, but it's helped with how we approach out conversations with those people. We focus a lot more on the important tasks while the AI takes over from the boring parts, but also plays a vital role in the team.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you for the thoughtful conversation and the concrete examples. I donâ€™t have any further questions. Do you feel thereâ€™s anything important we havenâ€™t covered about AIâ€™s impact on your work?

If not, thank you very much for your answers! [ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
I was doing a hardware update across the company, specifically new PCs and laptops, and migrating our on premises servers to the cloud.  From the start I gave AI all the information and asked if it could come up with a good project management plan including when to do things and the most efficient way of managing the data etc.  I used this as a first draft to then make changes as I needed to and then begin the project once I was prepared.

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
From my own knowledge I verified the information and confirmed anything I wasn't sure on with my own sources.  I suppose I did treat it similarly to a junior colleague who I trusted but needed to briefly verify

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]
More relief mainly, and the confidence that I had enough time to do a really good job

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[USER]

[USER]

[ASSISTANT]

[ASSISTANT]
Hello! I'm glad to have the opportunity to speak with you about AI and its impact on your work today. Could you start off by telling me about what you do for work?

[USER]
I work as a software developer for a small company that was just last year acquired by a much larger company. I have been working on a content calendar software called ContentCal that is now known as something different under the joint partnership with this new company. I also help run a small team of people who work on and around this project.

[ASSISTANT]
Thanks for sharing that. In your view, what are the core characteristics of a good job, in general, not necessarily your job?

[USER]
I believe the core characteristics of a good job should always start with the environment you work in, and the people you work alongside. I believe that this should always be the building blocks that are the foundations of any good company\start-up in my case.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say the environment and the people, what makes those good in practice for you? For example, what does a healthy environment look like day to day?

[USER]
A healthy environment is a place where you can express yourself, and put whatever skills you have to the test on a daily basis. A place where you aren't judged on anything besides the work you do, and also a place where you feel comfortable providing a service on a daily basis.

[ASSISTANT]
That makes sense. Besides the environment and people, is there anything else you see as essential for a good job, like how work is structured, recognition, growth, or something else?

[USER]
I believe every job should have a form of progression for the people who work there. I like to think hard work pays off, and you can climb that ladder and make something of yourself. For this to happen the job\work you do needs a fair and orginised structure that can provide you with the means to progress.

[ASSISTANT]
Thank you. Can you now please tell me about how AI impacts your work?

[USER]
AI plays a HUGE role in what I and my team do on a daily basis. We work alongside AI and it helps us form the software that we've created. Without AI we wouldn't have this incredible opportunity to develop such a great piece of software.

[ASSISTANT]
When you say AI helps you form the software, can you walk me through one concrete task you or your team do with AI on a typical day? For instance, whatâ€™s a recent example where you used it and what happened step by step?

[USER]
We currently updated our software to a newer version. This needs to be run through an AI software that basically represents the user end of that software, so for example.. We needed to test a AI daily content generator, but we used a conflicting AI software to run that process, to see what outcome a real world scenario could achieve. We did this by setting up a AI version of a end user (someone who would use the software for online social media content) and then we used a different AI program that would test the abilities of our own software, and we ran this 1000's of times until we could be sure that our software was doing a good job and AI generation user end daily content posts at specific times, which is what the software is able to do.

[ASSISTANT]
In that testing setup, which parts did the AI handle and which parts did you or your team do yourselves? For example, who wrote the test scenarios and prompts, who ran the batches, and who reviewed the outputs?
